response.explanation: Bryophytes are amphibians because they complete their vegetative phase on land but water is necessary for their reproductive phase.

input.question: Apophysis in the capsule of Funaria is

response.explanation: Capsule of Funaria is differentiated into: (1) Operculum – upper part - forms lid (2) Theca – Middle – fertile part (3) Apophysis – lower part -photosynthetic

input.question: Moss peristome takes part in

response.explanation: Peristome is a ring of tooth like structure around. These are in two rows and helps in the dispersal of the spores due to hygroscopic nature.

input.question: Sperms of both Funaria and Pteris were released together near the archegonia of Pteris. Only its sperms enter the archegonia as

options.b: Funaria sperms get killed by Pteris sperms
options.d: Pteris archegonia release chemical to attract its sperms

response.explanation: Archegonia of a particular species recognises antherozoids (sperms) of the same species through release of chemical. In Pteris, archegonia produces malic acid which attracts sperms of Pteris only for fertilization.

input.question: In bryophytes and pteridophytes, transport of male gametes requires

response.explanation: Bryophytes neither have pollen nor flowers and rely on water to carry the male gametes (sperm) to the female gametes (eggs). The antherozoids (male gametes of pteridophytes) are armed with hair-like or whip-like cilia or flagellate and are able to swim through water.

input.question: The plant body is thalloid in

response.explanation: The plant body of a liverwort is haploid (n), gametophytic, small, dorsoventrally flattened, thallose, dichotomously branched fixed by unicellular and unbranched rhizoids, e.g., Marchantia.

input.question: Selaginella and Salvinia are considered to represent a significant step towards evolution of seed habit because:

options.a: female gametophyte is free and gets dispersed like seeds
options.c: megaspores possess endosperm and embryo surrounded by seed coat
options.d: embryo develops in female gametophyte which is retained on parent sporophyte

response.explanation: Selaginella and Salvinia are advanced pteridophytes where embryo develops in female gametophyte which is retained on parent sporophyte.

input.question: In which one of the following, male and female gametophytes do not have free living independent existence?

response.explanation: Male and female gametophytes of Cedrus do not have free living independent existence. Cedrus belongs to conifer.

input.question: Which one of the following is heterosporous?

response.explanation: Salvinia is an heterosporous aquatic fern with both annual and perennial species. The heterosporous have two types of spores, microspores and megaspores.

input.question: In the prothallus of a vascular cryptogam, the antherozoids and eggs mature at different times. As a result

options.a: there is high degree of sterility
options.b: one can conclude that the plant is apomictic
options.d: there is no change in success rate of fertilization

response.explanation: In the prothallus of a vascular cryptogams the antherozoids and eggs mature at different times which result in failure of self-fertilisation.

input.question: In Ferns meiosis occurs when

response.explanation: Gametic meiosis is found in all animals. In sporic meiosis the sporophyte produces sporangia where as meiosis occurs producing haploid spores.

input.question: Dichotomous branching is found in

response.explanation: In mosses, branching is lateral but extra-axillary (Funaria). Marchantia is a dorsiventral dichotomously branched thalloid liverwort.

input.question: The 'walking' fern is so named because

options.a: it is dispersed through the agency of walking animals
options.b: it propagates vegetatively by its leaf tips
options.c: it knows how to walk by itself
options.d: its spores are able to walk

response.explanation: Vegetative reproduction occurs in ferns by fragmentation of rhizome and growth of adventitious buds. In Adiantum caudatum the adventitious buds occur at the leaf tips. Adiantum is also called the walking fern because of its ability to form new ferns whenever the leaf tip happens to come in contact with soil.

input.question: Multicellular branched rhizoids and leafy gametophytes are characteristic of

response.explanation: In pteridophytes, the gametophyte is independent living, small thalloid structure called prothallus. In pteridophytes, the primary roots are replaced by adventitious roots. Whereas in bryophytes, the gametophyte is leafy.

input.question: The 'amphibians' of plant kingdom are

options.d: pteridophytes with complex internal organization not reaching angiosperm level

response.explanation: Bryophytes are terrestrial plants but they require a thin film of water on the surface of their substratum during sexual reproduction, hence they are called amphibians of the plant kingdom.

input.question: Pteridophytes differ from mosses/bryophytes in possessing

response.explanation: Well developed vascular system is present in the members of Pteridophytes but absent in mosses as the plant body is sporophyte which is distinguished into true root, stem and leaves.

input.question: The plant group that produces spores and embryo but lacks vascular tissues and seeds is

response.explanation: Bryophytes are the plants which produces spores and embryo but no vascular tissues are present, although primitive type of conducting tissues are present in the form of hadrome and leptome.

input.question: Which one of the following is not common between Funaria and Selaginella?

response.explanation: Funaria, is a moss (Bryophyte) that possesses archegonium, embryo, flagellated sperms. These are also present in Selaginella (Pteridophyte) but it also has roots which are absent in Funaria.

input.question: Evolutionary important character of Selaginella is

response.explanation: Presence of two types of spores microspores and megaspores (heterospory) is the evolutionary characteristic feature in the life cycle of Selaginella.

input.question: Prothallus (gametophyte) gives rise to fern plant (sporophyte) without fertilization. It is

response.explanation: When prothallus of a fern gives rise to sporophyte directly from somatic cell without forming gametes it is apogamy. Such type of sporophyte is haploid in nature.

input.question: Which one of the following is considered important in the development of seed habit?

response.explanation: Heterospory is considered important in the development of seed habit. Heterospory was evolved from isospory independently by several plant groups in the Devonian period as part of the process of evolution of the timing of sex differentiation.

input.question: Plants reproducing by spores such as mosses and ferns are grouped under the general term

response.explanation: Plants reproducing by spores such as mosses and ferns are grouped under cryptogams.

input.question: Strobili or cones are found in

response.explanation: Strobili or cones are found in Equisetum.

input.question: Pinus seed cannot germinate and establish without fungal association. This is because:

options.b: it has obligate association with mycorrhizae
options.c: it has very hard seed coat
options.d: its seeds contain inhibitors that prevent germination

response.explanation: Pinus seed cannot germinate and establish without fungal association because it has obligate association with mycorrhizae.

input.question: Phloem in gymnosperms lacks:

options.d: Both sieve tubes and companion cells

response.explanation: Phloem in gymnosperms lacks both sieve tubes and companion cells.

input.question: Select the wrong statement:

options.a: Cell wall is present in members of Fungi and Plantae
options.c: Mitochondria are the powerhouse of the cell in all kingdoms except Monera
options.d: Pseudopodia are locomotory and feeding structures in Sporozoans

response.explanation: Pseudopodia are locomotory and feeding structures in Sporozoans is wrong statement.

input.question: Select the mismatch

response.explanation: Pinus is monoecious in which male & female cones are borne on different branches.

input.question: Select the correct statement:

options.a: Gymnosperms are both homosporous and heterosporous
options.b: Salvinia, Ginkgo and Pinus all are gymnosperms
options.c: Sequoia is one of the tallest trees
options.d: The leaves of gymnosperms are not well adapted to extremes of climate

response.explanation: Sequoia is one of the tallest trees is the correct statement.

input.question: In which of the following gametophyte is not independent free living?

response.explanation: Unlike bryophytes and pteridophytes, in gymnosperms the male and female gametophytes do not have an independent free-living existence. They remain within the sporangia retained on the sporophytes.

input.question: Read the following five statements (A to E) and select the option with all correct statements: (A) Mosses and Lichens are the first organisms to colonise a bare rock. (B) Selaginella is a homosporous pteridophyte (C) Coralloid roots in Cycas have VAM (D) Main plant body in bryophytes is gametophytic, whereas in pteridophytes it is sporophytic (E) In gymnosperms, male and female gametophytes are present within sporangia located on sporophyte

response.explanation: Statements A, D and E are correct: Mosses and Lichens are the first organisms to colonise a bare rock; Main plant body in bryophytes is gametophytic, whereas in pteridophytes it is sporophytic; In gymnosperms, male and female gametophytes are present within sporangia located on sporophyte.

input.question: Besides paddy fields cyanobacteria are also found inside vegetative part of:

response.explanation: Besides paddy fields cyanobacteria are also found inside vegetative part of Cycas.

input.question: Read the following statements (A-E) and answer the question which follows them. A. In liverworts, mosses and ferns gametophytes are free-living B. Gymnosperms and some ferns are heterosporous. C. Sexual reproduction in Fucus, Volvox and Albugo is oogamous D. The sporophyte in liverworts is more elaborate than that in mosses E. Both, Pinus and Marchantia are dioccious How many of the above statements are correct?

response.explanation: Three statements are correct: A, B and C are correct statements.

input.question: What is common in all the three, Funaria, Dryopteris and Ginkgo?

response.explanation: Presence of archegonia is common in all the three, Funaria, Dryopteris and Ginkgo.

input.question: Cycas and Adiantum resemble each other in having:

response.explanation: Cycas and Adiantum resemble each other in having motile sperms.

input.question: Which one of the following is a correct statement?

options.a: Pteridophyte gametophyte has a protonemal and leafy stage
options.b: In gymnosperms female gametophyte is free-living
options.c: Antheridiophores and archegoniophores are present in pteridophytes
options.d: Origin of seed habit can be traced in pteridophytes

response.explanation: Origin of seed habit can be traced in pteridophytes is the correct statement.

input.question: Read the following five statements (A - E) and answer the question. (A) In Equisetum the female gametophyte is retained on the parent sporophyte. (B) In Ginkgo male gametophyte is not independent. (C) The sporophyte in Riccia is more developed than that in Polytrichum. (D) Sexual reproduction in Volvox is isogamous. (E) The spores of slime molds lack cell walls. How many of the above statements are correct?

response.explanation: Two statements are correct: B and E are correct statements.

input.question: Which one of the following pairs is wrongly matched?

response.explanation: Ginkgo - Archegonia is wrongly matched as Ginkgo does not have archegonia.

input.question: Consider the following four statements whether they are correct or wrong? (A) The sporophyte in liverworts is more elaborate than that in mosses (B) Salvinia is heterosporous (C) The life cycle in all seed-bearing plants is diplomatic (D) In Pinus male and female cones are borne on different trees. The two wrong statements together are

response.explanation: The two wrong statements together are (A) and (D): The sporophyte in liverworts is not more elaborate than that in mosses, and in Pinus male and female cones are borne on the same tree (monoecious).

input.question: The gametophyte is not an independent, free living generation in:

response.explanation: The gametophyte is not an independent, free living generation in Pinus (gymnosperm).

input.question: Which one of the following plants is monoecious?

response.explanation: Pinus plant is monoecious i.e. both male and female cone are present in same plant but on different branches.

input.question: Which one of the following is a vascular cryptogam?

response.explanation: Equisetum is a vascular cryptogam. Equisetum is the only living genus in the Equisetaceae, a family of vascular plants that reproduce by spores rather than seeds.

input.question: Select one of the following pairs of important features distinguishing Gnetum from Cycas and Pinus and showing affinities with angiosperms

options.a: absence of resin duct and leaf venation
options.b: presence of vessel elements and absence of archegonia

response.explanation: The important features distinguishing Gnetum from Cycas and Pinus and showing affinities with angiosperms are presence of vessel elements and absence of archegonia.

input.question: Flagellated male gametes are present in all the three of which one of the following sets?

response.explanation: The male gametes of bryophytes are biflagellate and those of pteridophytes are multiflagellate, except Selaginella having biflagellates gametes. The male gametes of gymnosperms are non-motile except those of Cycas having multiciliate gametes.

input.question: In gymnosperms, the pollen chamber represents

options.a: a cavity in the ovule in which pollen grains are stored after pollination
options.b: an opening in the megagametophyte through which the pollen tube approaches the egg
options.c: the microsporangium in which pollen grains develop
options.d: a cell in the pollen grain in which the sperms are formed

response.explanation: In gymnosperms, the pollen chamber represents a cavity in the ovule in which pollen grains are stored after pollination within the pollen chamber.

input.question: Conifers differ from grasses in the

response.explanation: Conifers (Gymnosperms) differ from grasses (angiosperms) because in gymnosperms the female gametophyte is actually endosperm which is made before fertilisation.

input.question: Match items in Column I with those in Column II: Column I - (A) Peritrichous flagellation (B) Living fossil (C) Rhizophore (D) Smallest flowering plant (E) Largest perennial alga Column II - (J) Ginkgo (K) Macrocystis (L) Escherichia coli (M) Selaginella (N) Wolffia

response.explanation: Peritrichous flagellation: Escherichia coli; Living fossil: Ginkgo; Rhizophore: Selaginella; Smallest flowering plant: Wolffia; Largest perennial alga: Macrocystis

input.question: Which one of the following is a living fossil?

response.explanation: Cycas revoluta a native of China and Japan is commonly known as 'Tesso' or Sago palm. It is also called living fossil due to its primitive characters.

input.question: Which one of the following pairs of plants are not seed producers?

response.explanation: Pteridophytes (fern) and bryophytes (Funaria) are seedless plants. Gymnosperms (pines) and angiosperms (Ficus) are seed bearing plants.

input.question: Which one of the following is a living fossil?

response.explanation: Ginkgophyta is an ancient group, of which the sole living representative or living fossil is Ginkgo biloba or Maiden hair tree. It is native of South China.

input.question: Cycas has two cotyledons but not included in angiosperms because of

response.explanation: In Cycas (gymnosperm) the seed does not occur inside a fruit but lies naked or exposed on the surface of megasporophyll.

input.question: In which of the following would you place the plants having vascular tissue lacking seeds?

response.explanation: Pteridophytes are primitive seedless vascular plants. Bryophytes are non vascular embryophytes. Gymnosperms are seed plants.

input.question: Which one of the following statements about Cycas is incorrect?

options.a: It does not have a well-organized female flower
options.c: Its xylem is mainly composed of xylem vessels
options.d: Its roots contain some blue-green algae

response.explanation: In Cycas, conducting part of xylem consists of tracheids, not xylem vessels.

input.question: A well developed archegonium with neck consisting of 4-6 rows of neck canal cells, characterises

response.explanation: Archegonia is the female sex organ of bryophytes and pteridophytes. Its neck region is made up of 4-6 vertical rows of cells.

input.question: The 'wing' of Pinus seed is derived from

response.explanation: The upper surface of ovuliferous scale forms the membranous wings of the seed which helps in dispersal of the seed.

input.question: Which one is the most advanced from evolutionary point of view?

response.explanation: Pinus is a conifer, a member of gymnosperm has well developed conducting tissue and presence of seed, whereas Selaginella is a member of pteridophyte (heterospory), Funaria is a moss, Chlamydomonas is an alga.

input.question: A plant in which sporophytic generation is represented by zygote

response.explanation: The plant body of Chlamydomonas is gametophyte (haploid). It reproduces asexually by zoospore formation and sexually by gametes. Gametes are isogametes which fuse to produce diploid zygote which is the only structure representing sporophytic generation.

input.question: A plant having seeds but lacking flowers and fruits belongs to

response.explanation: Gymnosperms are vascular land plants having naked ovules i.e., ovules are not enclosed in a ovary hence, flower is absent. Ovules after fertilisation produce naked seeds.

input.question: In Pinus, the pollen grain has 6 chromosomes then in its endosperm will have

response.explanation: Pollen grains are haploid (n). If haploid no. of chromosomes are 6 then endosperm will also have 6 chromosomes as it is formed before fertilisation and is haploid.

input.question: Resin and turpentine are obtained from

response.explanation: Pinus species → Resins and turpentine; Cedrus → Timber for railway sleepers; Abies → Paper, Canada balsam; Cycas → Ornamental plant

input.question: In Pinus/gymnosperms, the haploid structure are

response.explanation: Pinus and in all other gymnosperms endosperm produced before fertilization and is haploid. Megaspore and pollen grain are initial structures of female gametophyte and male gametophyte respectively hence, they are haploid.

input.question: In gymnosperms like Pinus and Cycas, the endosperm is

response.explanation: In gymnosperms like Cycas/Pinus, endosperms of female gametophyte is haploid and formed before fertilisation. In angiosperms, endosperm is triploid and develops after fertilisation.

input.question: Double fertilization is exhibited by:

response.explanation: Double fertilisation is a unique feature exhibited only by angiosperms. It involves both syngamy and triple fusion.

input.question: Male gametophyte in angiosperms produces:

options.b: Single sperm and two vegetative cells
options.d: Two sperms and a vegetative cell

response.explanation: Two sperms and a vegetative cell are produced by male gametophyte in angiosperms.

input.question: In angiosperms, microsporogenesis and megasporogenesis:

response.explanation: In meiosis, the number of chromosomes are reduced by half producing haploid daughter cells. The microscope mother cell and the megaspore mother cell undergo meiosis to produce haploid microspore and megaspore respectively.

input.question: In angiosperms, functional megaspore develops into

response.explanation: During megagametogenesis functional megaspore (mostly chalazal) gives rise to embryo sac. This is the mature female gametophyte generation.

input.question: Compared with the gametophytes of the bryophytes the gametophytes of vascular plant are

options.a: smaller but have larger sex organs
options.b: larger but have smaller sex organs
options.c: larger and have larger sex organs
options.d: smaller and have smaller sex organs

response.explanation: The gametophyte of bryophytes are smaller but have large sex organs.

input.question: Male and female gametophytes are independent and free-living in:

response.explanation: Sphagnum is a bryophyte in which male and female gametophytes are independent and free living. In Pinus (a gymnosperm), mustard and castor (angiosperms), the main plant body is sporophytic.

input.question: Which one of the following has haplontic life cycle?

response.explanation: Ustilago has a haplontic life cycle. This is a simplest and most primitive type of life cycle. The other pattern of life-cycle have originated from this type.

input.question: Which one pair of examples will correctly represent the grouping Spermatophyta according to one of the schemes of classifying plants?

response.explanation: Spermatophytes are the seed plants. They are the plants bearing seeds containing a dormant embryo. It includes gymnosperms and angiosperms. Ginkgo belongs to group gymnosperms and Pisum belongs to group angiosperms.

input.question: Which of the following plants produces seeds but not flowers?

response.explanation: Maize, mint and peepal are flowering plants or angiosperms but Pinus is a gymnosperm in which seeds are produced but flowers are not produced or seeds are not enclosed in flowers.

input.question: Which of the following is without exception in angiosperms?

response.explanation: Vesselless angiosperms are Wintera, Trochodendron etc. Secondary growth is absent in some angiosperms. Angiospermic plants are autotrophic in nutrition. But some angiosperms are heterotrophic in nutrition. Double fertilisation is characteristic of all angiosperms.

input.question: The largest ovules, largest male and female gametes and largest plants are found among

response.explanation: Egg of Cycas (Gymnosperms) and its nucleus are the largest in the plant kingdom. The sperms of Cycas are also the largest in the plant kingdom.

input.question: Largest sperms in the plant world are found in

response.explanation: The sperms of Cycas are the largest in the plant kingdom reaching a size of 300 mm. Egg of Cycas and its nucleus are also the largest in the plant kingdom.

input.question: Seed-habit first originated in

response.explanation: Seed habit originated in Cycadophiles or pteridosperms.

input.question: Sunken stomata is the characteristic feature of

response.explanation: Sunken stomata is the characteristic feature of xerophytes which help in reducing loss of water from leaf surface. These type of stomata are found in Oleander or pine.

input.question: Pinus differs from mango in having

response.explanation: Pinus is a member of gymnosperm in which ovules are not enclosed in the ovary i.e. naked seed, whereas mango is a typical angiosperm whose ovules are enclosed in ovary i.e., presence of fruit.

input.question: Turpentine is obtained from

response.explanation: Turpentine is extracted from the wood (xylem) of Pinus (Gymnosperm). Turpentine is a fluid obtained by the complex distillation of resin obtained from trees, mainly various species of pine (Pinus).

input.question: Which one has the largest gametophyte?

response.explanation: As one moves from thallophyta → Bryophyta → Pteridophyta → Gymnosperm → Angiosperms, there is reduction in the gametophyte and elaboration of sporophyte. Hence, moss has largest gametophyte.

input.question: Bilaterally symmetrical and acoelomate animals are exemplified by

response.explanation: Platyhelminthes are bilaterally symmetrical, triploblastic and acoelomate animals with organ level of organisation.

input.question: Which of the following animals are true coelomates with bilateral symmetry?

response.explanation: Annelids exhibit bilateral symmetry with metameric segmentation where external segments correspond to internal segments. Adult echinoderms are bilaterally symmetrical. Aschelminthes are pseudocoelomates and platyhelminthes are acoelomates.

input.question: Consider following features: (a) Organ system level of organisation (b) Bilateral symmetry (c) True coelomates with segmentation of body. Select the correct option of animal groups which possess all the above characteristics.

response.explanation: Organ system of organisation, bilateral symmetry and true coelomates with segmented body are found in annelid, arthropoda and chordates. In mollusca, the body is unsegmented.

input.question: Which of the following characteristics is mainly responsible for diversification of insects on land?

response.explanation: The exoskeleton of insects consists of chitinous cuticle. It gets hardened due to deposition of calcium. It prevents dessication and gives protection.

input.question: Metagenesis refers to:

options.a: Alteration of generation between asexual and sexual phases of an organisms
options.b: Occurrence of a drastic change in form during post-embryonic development
options.c: Presence of a segmented body and parthenogenetic mode of reproduction

response.explanation: Metagenesis is defined as alternation of generation found in phylum cnidaria (eg. Obelia). In this phenomenon one generation of an organism reproduces asexually, followed by a sexually reproducing generation.

input.question: Which one of the following have the highest number of species in nature?

response.explanation: In nature insects have the highest number of species (30 million). Fungi have 100,000, angiosperms have 260000 and birds have 10,000 species.

input.question: Radial symmetry is usually associated with

response.explanation: Radial Symmetry is usually associated with sedentary mode of life (e.g. cnidarians). It permits an animal to detect food or danger approaching from any side.

input.question: True coelom is the space lying between the alimentary canal and body wall enclosed by the layers of

options.b: endoderm on one side and ectoderm on the other
options.c: mesoderm on one side and ectoderm on the other

response.explanation: Coelom is a fluid filled space between body wall and alimentary canal which is lined by parietal peritoneum (mesoderm) on the outer side and visceral peritoneum (mesoderm) on the inner side.

input.question: The organisms attached to the substratum, generally, possess

options.b: one single opening of digestive canal
options.d: cilia on surface to create water current

response.explanation: The organisms, which are attached to substratum, generally, possess radial symmetry in all vertical planes.

input.question: Radial symmetry is often exhibited by animals having

response.explanation: In radial symmetry – body is cut longitudinally through any radius into two equal halves. Present in sessile animals i.e. star fish that live in the sea bottom.

input.question: Coelom derived from blastocoel is known as

response.explanation: Coelom or body cavity, when derived from blastocoel is pseudocoelom as in nematodes, rotifers. In this type of cavity, mesoderm is lined by only one side i.e., towards the body wall. Schizocoel is true coelom derived from mesodermal segments.

input.question: Metamorphosis of insects is regulated through hormone

response.explanation: Metamorphosis of insects is regulated through ecdysone hormone. Ecdysone is a steroidal prohormone of the major insect molting hormone 20-hydroxyecdysone, which is secreted from the prothoracic glands.

input.question: Ecdysis is shedding of

response.explanation: Stratum corneum is the outermost, partially cornified layer of scale like cells. Small fragments of this layer are periodically shed off from the body known as ecdysis. The new layer is regularly formed by underlaying stratum germinativum.

input.question: In case of poriferans, the spongocoel is lined with flagellated cells called:

response.explanation: In poriferans (sponges) choanocytes (collar cells) form lining of spongocoel. Flagella present in collar cells provide circulation to water in water canal system.

input.question: Body having meshwork of cell, internal cavities lined with food filtering flagellated cells and indirect development are the characteristics of phylum.

response.explanation: The given characteristic features define the phylum porifera.

input.question: Select the Taxon mentioned that represents both marine and fresh water species:

response.explanation: Members of Ctenophora, Cephalochordata and Echinodermata are exclusively marine.

input.question: Which one of the following living organisms completely lacks a cell wall?

response.explanation: Gorgonia (sea-fan) is an animal. All animals lack cell wall. Gorgonia is a genus of soft corals, sea fans in the family Gorgoniidae.

input.question: Planaria possesses high capacity of:

response.explanation: Planaria is a flatworm which possesses a high capacity of regeneration.

input.question: Which one of the following groups of animals reproduces only by sexual means?

response.explanation: In Ctenophora, sexes are not separate. Reproduction takes place only by sexual means. In Cnidaria, which exist in both forms, polyps produce medusae asexually and medusae form the polyps sexually. Porifera (sponge) reproduce asexually by fragmentation and sexually by formation of gametes. Protozoans come under protista which reproduce asexually and sexually by cell fusion and zygote formation.

input.question: Which one of the following kinds of animals are triploblastic?

response.explanation: Triploblastic condition can be seen in flat worms. Ctenophores, sponges and corals are diploblastic.

input.question: Which one of the following groups of animals is bilaterally symmetrical and triploblastic?

response.explanation: Aschelminthes is bilaterally symmetrical and triploblastic. These are mostly aquatic, free living or parasitic. Their body is three layered which is ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm.

input.question: Ascaris is characterized by

options.a: absence of true coelom but presence of metamerism
options.b: presence of neither true coelom nor metamerism
options.c: presence of true coelom but absence of metamerism
options.d: presence of true coelom and metamerism (metamerisation)

response.explanation: Ascaris is a common parasite found in the large intestine of man. It is worldwide in distribution. The number of worms may be 500 or more in a single host. Ascaris is characterised by presence of neither true coelom nor metamerism.

input.question: From the following statements select the wrong one.

options.a: Prawn has two pairs of antennae
options.b: Nematocysts are characteristic of the Phylum Cnidaria
options.c: Millipedes have two pairs of appendages in each segment of the body
options.d: Animals belonging to Phylum Porifera are exclusively marine

response.explanation: Animals belonging to Phylum Porifera are mostly marine except a few which are found in fresh water- e.g. Spongilla, Euspongia.

input.question: In contrast to Annelids the Platyhelminths show:

response.explanation: Platyhelminthes includes flat worms. There is no body cavity. The animals are therefore acoelomates. Annelids also have bilateral symmetry. They are coelomate having a perivisceral cavity divided into compartments.

input.question: During its life-cycle, Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infects its intermediate host and primary host at the following larval stages respectively:

response.explanation: When in contact with water, the egg capsule form non feeding larva miracidium. Miracidium enters the body of snail to form sporocyst. The sporocyst develops into redia. Redia form cercaria and come out of snail. They get encysted forming metacercaria.

input.question: Sycon belongs to a group of animals, which are best described as

options.a: multicellular having tissue organization, but no body cavity

response.explanation: Sponges show cellular grade of organization. They do not have tissue system. Sycon is a sponge.

input.question: What is common between Ascaris lumbricoides and Anopheles stephensi?

response.explanation: Sexual dimorphism is common between Ascaris lumbricoides and Anopheles stephensi. Male and female round worms can be morphologically differentiated. Female Anopheles mosquito is sanguivorous whereas male Anopheles mosquito sucks nectar.

input.question: Most appropriate term to describe the life cycle of Obelia is

response.explanation: In Obelia polyps reproduce medusae asexually and medusae form the polyps sexually. Such alternation of asexual and sexual phases in the life cycle of Obelia is called metagenesis.

input.question: What is true about all sponges without exception?

options.c: They have a mixed skeleton consisting of spicules and spongin fibres
options.d: They reproduce only asexually by budding

response.explanation: Sponges are marine with the exception of family spongilidae, the members of which occur in fresh water e.g. Spongilla. Their endoskeleton is made of either spicules or spongin fibres or both. Sponges reproduce asexually by fragmentation or by budding or through gemmules and reduction bodies. Sponges also exhibit sexual reproduction.

input.question: Special character of Coelenterates is

input.question: Which one belongs to Platyhelminths?

response.explanation: Schistosoma (Blood Fluke) – Platyhelminthes; Trypanosoma – Aschelminthes; Wuchereria – Aschelminthes; Plasmodium – Protozoa

input.question: Budding is a normal mode of asexual reproduction in

response.explanation: Budding is an asexual mode of reproduction in Hydra & sponges. Bud is formed as an outgrowth on the body surface, then detached to form new animal.

input.question: What is true about Taenia saginata?

response.explanation: Rostellum and hooks are absent in Taenia saginata. A rostellum is a knob-like protrusion at the extreme anterior end of a tapeworm, as an extension of the tegument.

input.question: The simplest type of canal system in Porifera is

response.explanation: Presence of canal system - a network of channels for water transport - is an important feature in sponges. Ascon type of canal is simplest in Porifera which brings in food, oxygen and carries away CO2 and nitrogenous waste.

input.question: What is correct about Taenia?

options.b: Male organs occur in anterior proglottides
options.c: Female organs occur in anterior proglottides
options.d: Mature proglottides contain both male and female organs

response.explanation: The body of Taenia is ribbon like and is divided into segments called proglottids. Each proglottid has one or two sets of male and female reproductive organs.

input.question: Ascaris larva is called

response.explanation: Ascaris larva is also called rhabditiform. In the free-living cycle: Rhabditiform larvae are passed in the stool of an infected definitive host, develop into either infective filariform larvae or free-living adult males and females.

input.question: Bladderworm/cysticercus is the larval stage of

response.explanation: Bladderworm or cysticercus larva forms in tapeworm. Cysticercus is a scientific name given to the young tapeworms belonging to the genus Taenia. It is a small, sac-like vesicle resembling a bladder; hence, it is also known as bladder worm.

input.question: The excretory structures of flatworms/Taenia are

response.explanation: Excretory system of Taenia consists of a pair of peculiar flame cells, which absorb the waste material from the body and discharges it through excretory duct.

input.question: Classification of Porifera is based on

response.explanation: The term porifera was given by Grant, the phylum includes animals with pores in their body. Its classification is based on skeleton or spicules.

input.question: Ascaris lumbricoides infection occurs through

input.question: Taenia saginata differs from Taenia solium in

options.c: absence of scolex hooks and presence of both male and female reproductive organs

response.explanation: Taenia saginata lacks rostellum and scolex hooks.

response.explanation: Fossorial are the animals which live beneath the soil (in low temperature) and are found abundant in desert grasslands.

response.explanation: Commensalism is an association between two organisms in which one is benefitted but the other is not harmed.

input.question: If the head of cockroach is removed, it may live for few days because

options.a: the cockroach does not have nervous system.
options.b: the head holds a small proportion of a nervous system while the rest is situated along the ventral part of its body.
options.c: the head holds a 1/3rd of a nervous system while the rest is situated along the dorsal part of its body.
options.d: the supra-oesophageal ganglia of the cockroach are situated in ventral part of abdomen.

response.explanation: Cockroaches breathe passively through a network of pipes connected to holes called spiracles along the length of their body. They are independent of blood circulation to move oxygen around and their body fluids are at a much lower pressure. The sensory input from the eyes and antennae, along with many other behaviours, are transmitted and handled by their brain such as running and reacting to touch, handled by 'mini brains' called ganglia in each body segment. A decapitated cockroach will eventually starve to death but this can still take few days.

input.question: Which among these is the correct combination of aquatic mammals?

response.explanation: Sharks and Trygon (sting ray) are the members of cartilaginous fish while Whale, Dolphin and Seals are aquatic mammals belong to class mammalian.

input.question: Which of the following characteristic features always holds true for the corresponding group of animals?

options.c: Possess a mouth with an upper and a lower jaw - Chordata
options.d: 3-chambered heart with one incompletely divided ventricle - Reptilia

response.explanation: Chondrichthyes always have cartilaginous endoskeleton. Most mammals are viviparous, giving birth to young. However, the five species of monotreme, the platypuses and the echidnas, lay eggs. Chordates have jawless animals (Agnatha) as well. Most reptiles have 3 chambered heart. Crocodilians have 4 chambered hearts. Turtles have 3 chambered heart but with an incomplete wall in the single ventricle, so their hearts are functionally 4 chambered.

input.question: Which one of the following characteristics is not shared by birds and mammals?

response.explanation: Giving birth to young that develop within the mother's body rather than hatching from eggs. All mammals except the monotremes are viviparous.

input.question: Which of the following animals is not viviparous?

response.explanation: Platypus is an oviparous (egg laying animal). It belongs to class-mammalia.

input.question: Which of the following represents the correct combination without any exception?

options.a: Mouth ventral, gills without operculum; skin with placoid scales; persistent notochord - Chondrichthyes
options.b: Sucking and circular mouth; jaws absent, integument without scales; paired appendages - Cyclostomata
options.c: Body covered with feathers; skin moist and glandular; fore-limbs form wings; lungs with air sacs - Aves
options.d: Mammary gland; hair on body; pinnae; two pairs of Limbs - Mammalia

response.explanation: Aves possess dry skin, without glands except oil gland near the base of tail. Pinnae are not found in aquatic animals and egg laying mammals. In cyclostomes, unpaired appendages (joints) are found.

input.question: Match the name of the animal (column I), with one characteristics (column II), and the phylum/class (column III) to which it belongs:

input.question: The characteristics of class Reptilia are:

options.a: Body covered with dry and cornified skin, scales over the body are epidermal, they do not have external ears
options.b: Body covered with moist skin which is devoid of scales, the ear is represented by a tympanum, alimentary canal, urinary and reproductive tracts open into a common cloaca
options.c: Fresh water animals with bony endoskeleton, air-bladder to regulate buoyancy
options.d: Marine animals with cartilaginous endoskeleton, body covered with placoid scales

response.explanation: In option (a), all the characteristics belong to class Reptilia. In options (b), (c) and (d) the characteristics belong to the classes Amphibia, Osteichthyes and Chondrichthyes respectively.

input.question: Which one of the following categories of animals, is correctly described with no single exception in it?

options.a: All sponges are marine and have collared cells.
options.b: All mammals are viviparous and possess diaphragm for breathing.
options.c: All bony fishes have four pairs of gills and an operculum on each side.
options.d: All reptiles possess scales, have a three chambered heart and are cold blooded (poikilothermal).

response.explanation: All sponges are marine and have collared cells without any exception. Sponges are animals of the phylum Porifera. They are multicellular organisms which have bodies full of pores and channels allowing water to circulate through them, consisting of jelly-like mesohyl sandwiched between two thin layers of cells.

input.question: What will you look for to identify the sex of the following?

options.a: Female Ascaris- Sharply curved posterior end
options.b: Male frog- A copulatory pad on the first digit of the hind limb
options.d: Male shark-Claspers borne on pelvic fins

response.explanation: A male shark possesses a pair of claspers which are inserted into a female shark's cloaca (an opening on the underside of the body) at the time of mating. Claspers are located on the inner edge of the pelvic fins near the male's cloaca. The function of claspers is to introduce sperm into a female shark's body for the purpose of fertilizing her eggs. Female sharks do not have claspers.

input.question: Which one of the following groups of animals is correctly matched with its one characteristic feature without even a single exception?

options.a: Reptilia : possess 3-chambered heart with one incompletely divided ventricle
options.b: Chordata : possess a mouth provided with an upper and lower jaw
options.d: Mammalia : give birth to young one.

response.explanation: Chondrichthyes are the cartilaginous fish with a flexible skeleton made of cartilage rather than bone.

input.question: In which one of the following, the genus name, its two characters and its class/phylum are correctly matched?

input.question: Frogs differ from humans in possessing:

response.explanation: Human possesses enucleated RBCs in mature state. But frog blood has both white and red blood cells which are nucleated. Frog cells do not lack platelets.

response.explanation: Spongilla is a fresh water sponge that belongs to phylum porifera. It has special collared cells called choanocytes. Choanocytes are not found in leech, dolphin and penguin.

response.explanation: Bird vertebrae are heterocoelous. Acoelous vertebrae are found in mammals.

input.question: Pneumatophores occur in

response.explanation: Some lateral roots of mangroves become specialised as pneumatophores in saline mud flats. These are lateral roots that grow upward (negative geotropism) for varying distances and function as the site of oxygen intake for the submerged primary root system.

input.question: Plants which produce characteristic pneumatophores and show vivipary belong to:

response.explanation: Halophytes growing in saline soils show vivipary for seed germination and have pneumatophores for gaseous exchange.

input.question: Sweet potato is homologous to

response.explanation: Sweet potato and turnip both are roots that become modified for special functions, the most common being the formation of tuberous roots for food storage.

input.question: Roots of which plant contains an oxidising agent?

response.explanation: In the roots of soyabean plant, leghaemoglobin, a pigment with affinity for oxygen, is found. Symbolic hemoglobin (leghemoglobin) is a hemoprotein found in micromolar concentrations in infected cells of legume roots.

input.question: The plant, which bears clinging roots, is

response.explanation: Screw pine (Pandanus) bear stilt roots. Trapa bears assimilatory roots. Orchid bears clinging roots. Clinging roots are observed in epiphytes or space parasites, they are entities dwelling on the surface of other plants such as branches, and tree trunks etc. for space and shelter only.

input.question: Buttress roots are found in

response.explanation: Buttress roots are asymmetrically thickened prop roots found at the base of certain trees. They render additional mechanical support to the trees. e.g. Salmalia, Terminalia etc.

input.question: Velamen is found in

options.b: aerial and terrestrial roots of orchids

response.explanation: Aerial roots of orchids hang freely in the air and absorb moisture with the help of special sponge like tissue called velamen.

input.question: In Bougainvillea thorns are the modifications of:

response.explanation: Thorns are hard, pointed straight structures for protection against grazing animal. These are modified stem.

input.question: Which of the following is not a stem modification?

response.explanation: Pitcher of Nepenthes or pitcher plant is modification of leaf whereas thorns in citrus tendrils of cucumber and flattened structure of Opuntia are all stem modification.

input.question: An example of edible underground stem is:

response.explanation: Potato is an example of edible underground stem. It is differentiated into nodes and internodes. The 'eyes' on potato tuber indicate axillary buds at the nodes.

input.question: What is eye of potato?

response.explanation: Axillary bud is the bud arising in the axil of branch. Apical bud arises at the apex. Adventitious bud arises from any location other than its usual location.

input.question: Stems modified into flat green organs performing the functions of leaves are known as

response.explanation: Phylloclade refers to a portion of a flattened leaf-like stem or branch with multiple nodes and internodes, and cladode for a single internode of a phylloclade. In some plants, the petioles are flattened and widened, to become phyllodes or phyllodia.

input.question: Leaves become modified into spines in:-

response.explanation: In Opuntia, leaves become modified into spines to avoid transpiration so as to save water for desert adaptation. The stems of this plant appear like-leaf, termed as- phylloclades which perform the process of photosynthesis.

input.question: How many plants among China rose, Ocinnum, sunflower, mustard, Alstonia, guava, Calotropis and Nerium (Oleander) have opposite phyllotaxy?

response.explanation: Phyllotaxy is the pattern of arrangement of leaves on the stem or branch. Ocimum, Guava, Calotropis → Opposite phyllotaxy; China rose, Sunflower, mustard → Alternate phyllotaxy; Alstonia, Nerium (Oleander) → whorled phyllotaxy

input.question: Phyllode is present in:

response.explanation: Phyllode is present in Australian Acacia. It is modification of leaf in which lamina is absent and petiole becomes flattened and perform the function of food synthesis.

input.question: Whorled, simple leaves with reticulate venation are present in

response.explanation: Whorled phyllotaxy is a feature of Nerium and Alstonia. In Alstonia five leaves are present in a whorl while in Nerium three leaves are present in a whorl.

input.question: Heterospory and seed habit are often discussed in relation to a structure called

response.explanation: Heterospory, development of seed habit and ligulate leaves are important features of Selaginella. The reproductive structure in Selaginella is strobilus. A strobilus has many ligulate sporophylls.

input.question: Ray florets have

response.explanation: Ray floret have inferior ovary. Ray floret is condition in flower where any of a number of strap-shaped and typically sterile florets that form the ray e.g., Sunflower Epigynous flower are formed in family Asteraceae.

input.question: The ovary is half inferior in:

response.explanation: The ovary is half inferior in Plum. A half-inferior ovary is embedded or surrounded by the receptacle. Such flowers are termed perigynous or half-epigynous.

input.question: Match the placental types (column-I) with their examples (column-II).

response.explanation: Basal : Sunflower Axile : China rose Parietal : Mustard Free central : Dianthus In flowering plants, placentation is the attachment of ovules inside the ovary. The ovules inside a flower's ovary (which later become the seeds inside a fruit) are attached via funiculi, the plant part equivalent to an umbilical cord.

input.question: Bicarpellary ovary with obliquely placed septum is seen in:

response.explanation: Bicarpellary ovary with obliquely placed septum is seen in the members of family Solanaceae. e.g. Solanum tuberosum.

input.question: Placentation, in which ovules develop on the inner wall of the ovary or in peripheral part, is:

response.explanation: In parietal placentation the ovules develop on the inner wall of ovary or in peripheral part and number of placentae corresponds to the number of carpels. It occurs in bicarpellary or multicarpellary but unilocular ovary, e.g. mustard, Argemone etc.

input.question: Winged pollen grains are present in

response.explanation: Winged pollen grains are present in Pinus. Each pollen grain has two wing-like structures which enables it to float in air, as an adaptation for dispersal by the wind.

input.question: The standard petal of a papilionaceous corolla is also called

response.explanation: Papilionaceous flowers are flowers with the characteristic irregular and butterfly-like corolla. A single, large upper petal is known as the banner or vexillum and the name has been derived from an ancient military standard.

input.question: Proximal end of the filament of stamen is attached to the

response.explanation: The proximal end is attached to the thalamus whereas the distal end bears anther.

input.question: Perigynous flowers are found in:-

response.explanation: Ovary is partly superior and partly inferior in perigynous flower.

input.question: Axile placentation is present in

response.explanation: In a multilocular ovary, when the placenta is axial and ovules are attached to it is known as axile placentation.

input.question: When the margins of sepals or petals overlap one another without any particular direction, the condition is termed as:

response.explanation: If the margins of sepals or petals overlap one another but not in any particular direction as in Cassia and gulmohur, the aestivation is called imbricate.

input.question: Among bitter gourd, mustard, brinjal, pumpkin, china rose, lupin, cucumber, sunhemp, gram, guava, bean, chilli, plum, petunia, tomato, rose, withania, potato, onion, aloe and tulip how many plants have hypogynous flower?

response.explanation: Mustard (cruciferae), brinjal (solanaceae) china rose (malvaceae), lupin (leguminosae), gram (leguminosae), bean (leguminosae), chilli, Petunia, potato, tomato, Withania (solanaceae), onion, Aloe, tulip (liliaceae) have hypogynous flower while bittergourd, cucumber (cucurbiaceae), guava (mytraceae) have epigynous flower and rose has perigynous flower.

input.question: Among flowers of Calotropis, tulip, Sesbania, Asparagus, Colchicine, Sweet pea, Petunia, Indigofera, Mustard, Soyabean, Tobacco and groundnut how many plants have corolla with valvate aestivation?

response.explanation: Calotropis, tulip, Asparagus, colchicine, Petunia, mustard, tobacco have valvate aestivation while sweet pea, groundnut, soyabean, Indigofera, Sesbania have vexillary aestivation.

input.question: In a cymose inflorescence the main axis

options.d: Has unlimited growth but lateral branches end in flowers

response.explanation: In cymose inflorescence, the growth of the main axis is definite because the growing point of peduncle is used up in the formation of a flower. Further growth of flowering axis is continued by one or more lateral branches which also end in flower.

input.question: Inflorescence is racemose in

response.explanation: Inflorescence in family fabaceae (e.g., soyabean) is racemose. Inflorescence in family liliaceae (e.g., tulip, Aloe) is solitary/cymose; often umbellate. Inflorescence in family solanaceae (e.g., brinjal) is solitary, axillary or cymose as in Solanum.

input.question: Placentation in tomato and lemon is

response.explanation: Parietal Ex. - Mustard; Free central Ex. - Primula & Dianthus; Marginal Ex. - Pea; Axile Ex. - Tomato, lemon, Chinarose

input.question: Cymose inflorescence is present in:

response.explanation: Cymose inflorescence is present in Solanum. Cymose inflorescence is the name of determinate or definite inflorescence in which the tip of the main axis terminates in a flower and further growth continues by one or more lateral branches which also behaves like the main axis.

input.question: The gynoecium consists of many free pistils in flowers of

response.explanation: The female reproductive part of a flower is gynoecium. It is syncarpous or fused in tomato.

input.question: How many plants in the list given below have marginal placentation? Mustard, Gram, Tulip, Asparagus, Arhar, Sun hemp, Chilli, Colchicine, Onion, Moong, Pea, Tobacco, Lupin

response.explanation: Marginal placentation is a placentation with ovules borne on the wall along the ventral suture of a simple ovary. Gram, Athar, Sun hemp, Moong, Pea & Lupin belong to fabaceae family that bear marginal placentation.

input.question: Flowers are zygomorphic in:

response.explanation: When a flower can be divided into two similar halves only in one particular vertical plane, it is zygomorphic, e.g. pea, gulmohar, bean, etc.

input.question: Which one of the following diagrams represents the placentation in Dianthus?

response.explanation: Free central placentation occurs in Dianthus and Primula in which ovules are borne on central axis and septa are absent.

input.question: In unilocular ovary with a single ovule the placentation is:

response.explanation: In basal type of placentation, the ovary is unilocular with a single ovule. In this, the placenta is at the base of the ovary. It is seen in Polygonum.

input.question: Ovary is half-inferior in the flowers of:

response.explanation: A flower in which floral parts arise from around the ovary is called perigynous. In this, the ovary is half inferior and half superior. It can be seen in the flowers of plum, peach etc.

input.question: The technical term used for the androecium in a flower of China rose (Hibiscus rosa sinensis) is:

response.explanation: Hibiscus belongs to family Malvaceae. It possess numerous stamens that are called monadelphous.

input.question: An example of axile placentation is:

response.explanation: In flowering plants, placentation occurs where the ovules are attached inside the ovary. An example of axile placentation is citrus. In this type of placentation the ovary is sectioned by radial spokes with placentas in separate locules.

input.question: Replum is present in the ovary of flower of

response.explanation: Replum is present in the ovary of flower of mustard. A false septum called replum develops between the two parietal placentae in mustard and other members of family Brassicaceae. The ovary becomes bilocular.

input.question: Which of the following is a flowering plant with nodules containing filamentous nitrogen-fixing micro-organism

response.explanation: It is also known as Australian pine, which is a deciduous tree with a soft, wispy, pine-like appearance that can grow to 100 feet or more in height. Also known as ironwood, or beefwood. It bears a superficial resemblance to the conifer genus Pinus because of its small, round, cone-like fruits and its branchlets of scale-like leaves that look like pine needles.

input.question: Long filamentous threads protruding at the end of the young cob of maize are

response.explanation: Long filamentous threads of maize are the styles of the ovaries. In fact, these are the longest styles in plants.

input.question: Angiosperm to which the largest flowers belong is?

response.explanation: Rafflesia is an angiosperm, which produces the largest flowers. It is also a total root parasite. Rafflesia is a genus of parasitic flowering plants in the family Rafflesiaceae. It contains approximately 28 species, all found in Southeast Asia, mainly in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines.

input.question: The type of placentation in which ovary is syncarpous, unilocular and ovules on sutures is called

response.explanation: The arrangement of ovules inside the ovary of a flowering plant is called placentation. In marginal placentation, the ovule develop from a longitudinal suture where the margins of the ovary wall fuse. e.g., Pea, gram. In apical placentation a single ovule is born near the apex of the ovary. Here ovary is unilocular (Cannabis). In superficial placentation the ovary is unilocular simple or syncarpous e.g. Nymphaea.

input.question: Floral features are chiefly used in Angiosperms identification because

options.c: reproductive parts are more stable and conservative than vegetative parts
options.d: flowers are nice to work with

response.explanation: Reproductive parts (floral features) are more stable and conservative than vegetative parts, which exhibit changes due to the environmental factors quite readily. So floral features are more reliable.

input.question: Hypanthodium is

response.explanation: Hypanthodium is a special kind of inflorescence where the receptacle is usually fleshy and flask-shaped. e.g. Ficus. In angiosperms, a hypanthium or floral cup is a structure where basal portions of the calyx, the corolla, and the stamens form a cup-shaped tube.

input.question: Epipetalous stamens with free filaments and fused anthers occur in

response.explanation: Asteraceae possess five stamens with free filaments but anthers are united forming a tube around the style (syngenesious).

input.question: Coconut fruit is a:

response.explanation: Coconut fruit is a drupe. A drupe is a fleshy fruit with thin skin and central stone containing the seed.

input.question: The morphological nature of the edible part of coconut is:

response.explanation: The edible part of coconut is its endosperm. Coconut has double endosperm, liquid endosperm and cellular.

input.question: The coconut water from tender coconut represents

response.explanation: Coconut water is the clear liquid inside young green coconuts (fruits of the coconut palm). In early development, it serves as a suspension for the endosperm of the coconut during the nuclear phase of development. As growth continues, the endosperm matures into its cellular phase and deposits into the rind of the coconut meat.

input.question: Cotyledon of maize grain is called

response.explanation: The cotyledons are known as seed leaves, they are attached to the embryonic axis. Dicotyledons typically have two cotyledons and monocotyledons have only one cotyledon. The single shield-shaped cotyledon in grains known as scutellum.

input.question: Coconut water from a tender coconut is

options.b: Innermost layers of the seed coat

response.explanation: Coconut water is the free nuclear endosperm which is used.

input.question: Which one of the following fruits is parthenocarpic?

response.explanation: Parthenocarpic fruits (eg - banana) are produced without fertilization of ovule. Parthenogenesis is a natural form of asexual reproduction in which growth and development of embryos occur without fertilization by sperm.

input.question: The wheat grain has an embryo with one, large, shield-shaped cotyledon known as:

response.explanation: Scutellum is large, shield shaped cotyledon that helps in the absorption of nutrients from endosperm during germination.

input.question: Placenta and pericarp are both edible portions in:

response.explanation: In tomato the edible part is pericarp and placenta.

input.question: Which one of the following statements is correct?

options.a: The seed in grasses is not endospermic.
options.c: A proteinaceous aleurone layer is present in maize grain.
options.d: A sterile pistil is called a staminode.

response.explanation: Generally, monocotyledonous seeds (e.g., grasses) are endospermic but some as in orchids are non-endospermic. Mango is a drupe fruit that develops from multicarpillary, syncarpous, superior ovary having one or many seeds. A sterile stamen is called a staminode. In monocots, outer covering of endosperm separates the embryo by a proteinous layer called aleurone layer.

input.question: An aggregate fruit is one which develops from:

response.explanation: Aggregate fruits (etacrio) develop from the multicarpillary apocarpous ovary. They are of following types; etacrio of follicles, etacrio of achenes, etacrio of berries, etacrio of drupes.

input.question: How many plants in the list given below have composite fruits that develop from an inflorescence: Walnut, poppy, radish, fig, pineapple, apple, tomato, mulberry

response.explanation: Fig-develops from hypanthodium inflorescence; pineapple- develops from spike inflorescence; Mulberry-develops from catkin inflorescence.

input.question: The coconut water and the edible part of coconut are equivalent to:

response.explanation: Liquid endosperm is the edible part of coconut.

input.question: Which one of the following statements is correct?

options.a: In tomato, fruit is a capsule
options.b: Seeds of orchids have oil-rich endosperm
options.d: Flower of tulip is a modified shoot

response.explanation: Tulips are most popular and wildly grown flowers. Tulips are bulbs, possessing modified stems and leaves.

input.question: What would be the number of chromosomes of the aleurone cells of a plant with 42 chromosomes in its root tip cells?

response.explanation: Aleurone cells are the outer cell layer of the endosperm, usually only one cell thick in wheat and the only endosperm tissue alive at maturity. The cell layers of this layer are responsible for the de-novo synthesis of enzyme needed during germination. The chromosome number is 63 of a plant with 42 chromosome in its root tip cells.

input.question: In a cereal grain the single cotyledon of embryo is represented by

response.explanation: Single cotyledon of embryo in cereal grain is represented by scutellum. Coleoptile represents the covering of stem. Coleorrhiza represents the covering of root. Prophyll is a plant structure resembling a leaf (as a bracteole) or consisting of a modified or rudimentary leaf (as a foliar primordium).

input.question: Pineapple (ananas) fruit develops from

options.b: a cluster of compactly borne flowers on a common axis

response.explanation: Pineapple (Ananas sativus) is a sorosis fruit developed from a composite inflorescence which is actually a cluster of compactly borne flowers on a common axis.

input.question: Aril represents the edible part of

response.explanation: Aril develops from outer seed coat and is the edible part of litchi. An aril (or arillus) is a fleshy covering of certain seeds formed from the funiculus attachment point of the seed. The aril may create a fruit-like structure called a false-fruit and is produced by a few species of gymnosperms, notably the yews and related conifers in the families Taxaceae and Cephalotaxaceae.

input.question: Mango juice is got from

response.explanation: Mesocarp is the edible part of Mangifera indica (Mango).

input.question: Juicy hair-like structures observed in the lemon fruit develop from

response.explanation: The juicy hair – like structures in the lemon fruit develop from the inner side of endocarp (from the placenta).

input.question: The aleurone layer in maize grain is specially rich in

response.explanation: The aleurone layer in maize grain is specially rich in proteins. Aleurone is a protein found in the endosperm of many seeds. It forms the outermost layer of the seed coat in some grains. During seed germination, hydrolysis in the seed causes the aleurone cells to break down into amino acids.

input.question: Edible part of banana is

response.explanation: Banana (Musa paradisica) is a fleshly fruit with rich sugar content. Edible part is fleshy mesocarp and rudimentary endocarp, develops from trilocular, inferior ovary.

input.question: Which is correct pair for edible part?

response.explanation: In guava, mesocarp and endocarp form the edible part. In maize seed coat is fused with fruit wall.

input.question: The embryo in sunflower has

response.explanation: Sunflower is a dicotyledonous plant. Hence its embryo has two cotyledons. Plants like maize are monocotyledonous and hence have a single cotyledon in the embryo.

input.question: Which one of the following statements is correct with respect to the plant species and its use?

options.a: Oryza sativa – rich source of protein
options.b: Manihot utilissima – root tubers eaten especially in Kerala
options.d: Hibiscus esculentus – flowers eaten throughout the country.

response.explanation: Oryza sativa is rice. Ricinus communis is castor, a source of castor oil that acts as a purgative. Manihot is the scientific name for tapioca, a tuber rich in starch. Hibiscus esculentus is okra (bhindi).

input.question: Which one of the following is a true fruit?

response.explanation: The fruit is a mature or ripened ovary. When a fruit develops exclusively from the ovary, it is said to be true fruit. When in addition to the ovary, some other floral part also participates in the formation of fruits, then it is known as false fruit. Apple, pear, cashewnut, mulberry etc. are all false fruits.

input.question: Which part of the coconut produces coir?

response.explanation: Coir (Etymological origin: from Tamil and Malayalam - kayar - cord) is a coarse fibre extracted from the fibrous outer shell of a coconut. Coir fibres are found between the husk and the outer shell of a coconut. The individual fibre cells are narrow and hollow, with thick walls made of cellulose.

input.question: Vivipary is

options.d: seed germination inside the fruit while attached to the plant

response.explanation: Vivipary germination is the characteristic mode of seed germination in Rhizophora (Mangrove).

input.question: Germination of seed within fruit is

response.explanation: In plants, vivipary occurs when seeds or embryos begin to develop before they detach from the parent. Plants such as some Iridaceae and Agavoideae grow cormlets in the axils of their inflorescences. These fall and in favourable circumstances they have effectively a whole season's start over fallen seeds.

input.question: Fruit of Mangifera indica is

response.explanation: Drupe is a fleshy one seeded, indehiscent fruit eg. Mangifera indica.

input.question: New Banana plants develop from

response.explanation: Each pseudostem produces a single bunch of bananas, before dying and are replaced by a new pseudostem. The base of the plant is a rhizome (known as a corm). Cultivated bananas are parthenocarpic, which makes them sterile and unable to produce viable seeds. Lacking seeds, another form of propagation is required. This involves removing and transplanting part of the underground stem (called a corm). Usually this is done by carefully removing a sucker with some roots intact.

input.question: In Groundnut the food/oil reserve is present in

response.explanation: Groundnut is economically important plant as edible oil is obtained from the cotyledons. Peanuts are a rich source of protein (roughly 30 grams per cup after roasting) and monounsaturated fat.

input.question: Perisperm is

response.explanation: Normally endosperm formation is accompanied by degeneration of nucellus. Persistent nucellus is termed as perisperm. The dust-like seeds of orchids have no endosperm. Orchid seedlings are mycoheterotrophic in their early development. In some other species, such as coffee, the endosperm also does not develop. Instead the nucellus produces a nutritive tissue termed perisperm.

input.question: Fruit of Groundnut is

response.explanation: Legume is a dehiscent dry fruit produced from a monocarpellary superior ovary. Caryopsis is dry and one seeded fruit which developed from a superior monocarpellary ovary. In this the pericarp is closed and fused with seed coat. It is the characteristics of family Poaceae.

input.question: Tricarpellary syncarpous gynoecium is found in flowers of

response.explanation: The Liliaceae are a huge variety, comprising about 280 genera and 4000 species of perennial herbs mostly. It includes starchy rhizomes, corms or bulbs, characterized by alternate leaves which are whorled. The flowers are often showy, mostly bisexual and actinomorphic. Also, they exhibit tricarpellary syncarpous gynoecium. Example of such a class is the Erythronium montanum, the alpine fawn lily.

input.question: Floral formula is for

response.explanation: Floral formula of Petunia (solanaceae) is shown. Solanaceae, the nightshade, or potato, family of flowering plants (order Solanaes), with 102 genera and nearly 2,500 species, are of considerable economic importance as food and drug plants.

input.question: Keel is the characteristic feature of flower of:

response.explanation: Indigofera is a member of family fabaceae. It has keel type of floral structure in which two anterior fused petals are present.

input.question: Among china rose, mustard, brinjal, potato, guava, cucumber, onion and tulip, how many plants have superior ovary?

response.explanation: Superior ovary is found in china rose, mustard brinjal, potato, onion and tulip. Guava and cucumber have inferior ovary.

input.question: Flowers are unisexual in:

response.explanation: The flowers of cucumber are unisexual, it means they have only male flowers or only female flowers.

input.question: In china rose the flowers are :

response.explanation: In china rose (Hibiscus rosa-sinensis) flowers are actinomorphic , hypogynous with twisted aestivation in corolla.

input.question: Vexillary aestivation is characteristic of the family

response.explanation: This type of aestivation is seen in fabaceae. Here, the posterior largest petal overlaps the petals that are lateral, which in turn overlap the two anterior petals.

input.question: Which one of the following organisms is correctly matched with its three characteristics?

options.a: Pea: C3 pathway, Endospermic seed, Vexillary aestivation
options.b: Tomato: Twisted aestivation, Axile placentation, Berry
options.c: Onion: Bulb, Imbricate aestivation, Axile placentation
options.d: Maize: C3 pathway, Closed vascular bundles, Scutellum

response.explanation: Onion - Bulb - Underground stems -Imbricate aestivation -Axile placentation -Member of Liliaceae.

input.question: The correct floral formula of chilli is :

response.explanation: Floral formula of chilli is shown. The chili pepper is the fruit of plants from the genus Capsicum which are members of the nightshade family, Solanaceae. Chili peppers are widely used in many cuisines as a spice to add heat to dishes.

input.question: The ovary is half inferior in flowers of

response.explanation: The ovary is half-inferior in flowers of peach.

input.question: Keel is characteristic of the flowers of:

response.explanation: Keel is the characteristic of the flowers of family papilionaceae. For example, bean, gram, pea etc. The flowers of this family have butterfly shaped corolla. The outermost petals of these flowers are the largest and is called vexillum, the two largest petals are similar and have wings and the two anterior petals called keel are fused enclosing stamens and carpels.

input.question: The floral formula is that of:

response.explanation: The given floral formula is of tobacco. It belong to the family Solanaceae. The flower is actinomorphic, bisexual and has superior ovary. Soyabean and sunhenp have monocarpellary pistil and tulip has trimerous flower and perianth.

input.question: What type of placentation is seen in sweet pea?

response.explanation: In sweet pea, the gynoecium is monocarpellary and bears a single placenta along the junction of two fused margins, this is called marginal placentation.

input.question: Pentamerous, actinomorphic flowers, bicarpellate ovary with oblique septa and fruit a capsule of berry, are characteristic features of

response.explanation: Pentamerous, actinomorphic flowers, bicarpillary ovary with oblique septa, fruit either capsule or berry are the characteristic features of family solanaceae.

input.question: Bicarpellary gynoecium and oblique ovary occures in

response.explanation: In mustard, bicarpellary gynoecium with oblique ovary is present.

input.question: Tetradynamous stamens are found in family

response.explanation: Tetradynamous stamens consist of four long-sized stamens and two short-sized stamens. Such kind of stamens are found in family Cruciferae e.g. Sarsoo. Tetradynamous condition is characteristic of this family.

input.question: Match the following and indicate which is correct

response.explanation: Malvaceae - Cotton. Malvaceae, or the mallows, is a family of flowering plants estimated to contain 244 genera with 4225 known species. Well-known members of economic importance include okra, cotton, cacao and durian.

input.question: Pulses are obtained from

response.explanation: Pulses which are economically important belong to the family Fabaceae.

input.question: Floral formula of Tomato/Tobacco is

response.explanation: Tomato and Tobacco both belong to the family Solanaceae. Solanaceae has some identifying characteristics that include bicarpellary syncarpous superior ovary, axile placentation, fruit is berry or capsule.

input.question: Syngenesious condition is found in

response.explanation: When stamens are united by their anthers and filaments are free the condition is called syngenesious. It is found in family Asteraceae (Compositae). The condition is an adaptation for entomophily.

input.question: Floral formula is of

response.explanation: Fabaceae. The Fabaceae or Leguminosae, commonly known as the legume, pea, or bean family, are a large and economically important family of flowering plants. It includes trees, shrubs, and perennial or annual herbaceous plants, which are easily recognized by their fruit (legume) and their compound, stipulate leaves.

input.question: Botanical name of Cauliflower is

response.explanation: Cauliflower has the scientific name Brassica oleracea belonging to the variety botrytis.

input.question: A family delimited by head type of inflorescence is

response.explanation: Asteraceae possesses head or capitulum inflorescence which is racemose and is surrounded by an involucre of bracts.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Regeneration of damaged growing grass following grazing is largely due to:

response.explanation: Intercalary meristems are capable of cell division and they allow for rapid growth and regrowth of many monocots. Intercalary meristem, found in grasses, help to regenerate the parts removed by the grazing herbivores.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Xylem translocates:

options.c: Water, mineral salts and some organic nitrogen only
options.d: Water, mineral salts, some organic nitrogen and hormones

response.explanation: Xylem is a type of complex tissue. It translocates water, mineral salts, organic nitrogen and hormones.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Root hairs develop from the region of:

response.explanation: In roots, the root hairs develops from zone of maturation. This zone is differentiated zone thus bearing root hairs. The root hair develop in this region and lives for a day. The root hair develops form the single epidermal cells and help to absorb water from the soil.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Which of the following is made up of dead cells?

response.explanation: Cork cambium undergoes periclinal division and cuts off thick walled subcrised dead cells towards outside i.e. phellem (cork). A mature cork cell is non-living and has cell walls that are composed of a waxy substance that is highly impermeable to gases and water called suberin.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Transmission tissue is characteristic feature of:

response.explanation: A solid style has transmission tissue which has large intercellular spaces. It allows growth of pollen tube in pistil.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: In a ring girdled plant:

options.b: The shoot and root die together
options.c: Neither root nor shoot will die

response.explanation: In a ring girdled plant, roots die first due to damage of phloem causing inhibition of translocation of food.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Tracheids differ from other tracheary elements in:

response.explanation: The walls of vessels (tracheary elements) are lignified and less thicker than tracheids. The lumen is wider. Vessels differ from tracheids in having cell fusions arising through the dissolution of end walls.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Meristematic tissue responsible for increase in girth of tree trunk is

response.explanation: Lateral meristems are meristems which occur parallel to the circumference of the organs in which they develop. They undergo periclinal divisions producing secondary tissues on the outer and inner sides and increase the girth of the plant organs. Examples are vascular cambium and cork-cambium.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Companion cells are closely associated with:

response.explanation: Companion cells are narrow, elongated and thin walled living cells. They lie on the sides of the sieve tubes and are closely associated with them through compound plasmodesmata. It is supposed that the nuclei of the companion cells control the activities of the sieve tube through plasmodesmata.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Function of companion cells is

options.a: Providing energy to sieve elements for active transport
options.c: Loading of sucrose into sieve elements by passive transport
options.d: Loading of sucrose into sieve elements

response.explanation: Function of companion cell is to load sugar and amino acids into sieve elements. These cells use transmembrane proteins for uptake by active transport.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: The chief water conducting elements of xylem in gymnosperms are:

response.explanation: Tracheids are chief water conducting elements of xylem in gymnosperms. They are devoid of protoplasm and hence dead. The wall constituting the tracheids is hard, thick and lignified. These are elongated cells with tapering ends.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Reduction in vascular tissue, mechanical tissue and cuticle is characteristic of:
