response.explanation: Reduction in vascular tissue, mechanical tissue and cuticle is characteristic of hydrophytes.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: The length of different internodes in a culm of sugarcane is variable because of

options.c: Size of leaf lamina at the node below each internode

response.explanation: The length of different internodes in a culm of sugarcane is variable because of intercalary meristem. Intercalary meristem is not a part of apical meristem. It occurs in the internodes of grasses (sugarcane) between leaf nodes and enables longitudinal growth of the stem.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Passage cells are thin walled cells found in

options.a: Phloem elements that serve as entry points for substance for transport of other plant parts
options.b: Testa of seeds to enable emergence of growing embryonic axis during seed germination
options.c: Central region of style through which the pollen tube grows towards the ovary
options.d: Endodermis of roots facilitating rapid transport of water from cortex to pericycle

response.explanation: The innermost layer of the cortex is called endodermis. It comprises a single layer of barrel shaped cells without any intercellular spaces. In roots thick walled endodermal cells are interrupted by thin walled passage cells or transfusion tissue.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: A common structural feature of vessel elements and sieve tube elements are

response.explanation: In plants, conducting tissue xylem has an important integral cell as xylem vessel which is enucleate. The phloem on other hand has a row of sieve tubes which are also enucleate at maturity.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: In a woody dicotyledonous tree, which of the following parts will mainly consist of primary tissues?

response.explanation: Primary Meristems: They are those meristematic tissues which are derived directly from the meristems of the embryo and retain their meristematic activity. They are present at root, shoot tip and leaf primordia.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: In a longitudinal section of a root, starting from the tip upward, the four zones occur in the following order:

options.a: Root cap, cell division, cell enlargement, cell maturation
options.b: Root cap, cell division, cell maturation, cell enlargement
options.c: Cell division, cell enlargement, cell maturation, root cap
options.d: Cell division, cell maturation, cell enlargement, root cap

response.explanation: Root shows the following regions: Root cap or calyptra - caplike protective covering over tip of the root; Meristematic region is the subapical position; Zone of elongation - receives new cells from the growing point; Root hair zone - is the zone of differentiation; Zone of mature cells - having thick walled impermeable cells.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: The cells of the quiescent centre are characterised by

options.a: Dividing regularly to add to tunica
options.b: Having dense cytoplasm and prominent nuclei
options.c: Having light cytoplasm and small nuclei
options.d: Dividing regularly to add to the corpus

response.explanation: The cells of quiescent centre have lower concentration of DNA, RNA and protein as compared to other cells in the root apex. These cells do not divide, hence cytoplasm is light and nuclei are small in them. This concept is based upon quiescent centre theory proposed by Clowes (1961).

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: The apical meristem of the root is present

response.explanation: The apical meristem of the root is present at all the root tips. Apical meristem is subterminal in position of the growing root tips and responsible for terminal growth of the root in plants.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Chlorenchyma is known to develop in the

options.c: Mycelium of a green mould such as Aspergillus

response.explanation: Chlorenchyma cells are those parenchymatous cell which contain chloroplast in them. They are capable of photosynthesis. A spore capsule of moss can perform photosynthesis, thus chlorenchyma are present in them.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Vessels are found in

options.b: Most of angiosperms and few gymnosperms
options.c: All angiosperms, all gymnosperms and some pteridophyta

response.explanation: Generally gymnosperms do not have vessels but a few gymnosperms with vessels are Ephedra, Smilax etc. Most of angiosperms have vessels except of few e.g., Trochodendron.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Axillary bud and terminal bud are derived from the activity of

response.explanation: Apical meristem is located at the apex of stem, root and branches, and forms axillary and terminal bud. Intercalary meristems take part in linear growth. Lateral meristem occurs parallel to the circumference of the organs. They increase the girth of the plant.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Which of the following statements is true?

options.a: Vessels are multicellular with narrow lumen
options.b: Tracheids are multicellular with narrow lumen
options.c: Vessels are unicellular with wide lumen
options.d: Tracheids are unicellular with wide lumen

response.explanation: Vessels are elongated, multicellular water conducting channels with wide lumen formed by end to end fusion of a large number of vessel elements. Tracheids are elongated dead cells with tapering ends having lignified walls and large or wide lumen. Their main function is conduction of water and minerals from root to leaf.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Loading of phloem is related to

response.explanation: Phloem is involved in transport of organic food. According to mass flow hypothesis organic substances flow in the form of solution in sieve elements due to development of an osmotically generated pressure gradient.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: A leaf primordium grows into the adult leaf lamina by means of

options.d: At first by apical meristem and later largely by marginal meristems

response.explanation: A leaf primordium grows into the adult leaf lamina by means of apical meristem first and later marginal meristems.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: At maturity which of the following is enucleate?

response.explanation: Sieve tubes members do not have ribosomes or a nucleus and thus need companion cells to help them function as transport molecules. Companion cells provide Sieve tube members with proteins necessary for signalling and ATP in order to help them transfer molecules between different parts of the plant.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: What is not true about scleroids?

options.a: These are parenchyma cells with thickened lignified walls
options.b: These are elongated and flexible with tapered ends
options.c: These are commonly found in the shells of nuts and in the pulp of guava, pear, etc
options.d: These are also called the stone cells

response.explanation: Sclereids are small bundles of sclerenchyma tissue in plants that form durable layers, such as the cores of apples and the gritty texture of pears. Sclereids are variable in shape. The cells can be isodiametric, prosenchymatic, forked or fantastically branched. The cell walls fill nearly all the cell's volume.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Bordered pits are found in

response.explanation: The walls of xylem vessels are lignified and bordered pits are common in the walls.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Angular collenchyma occurs in

response.explanation: Along with providing mechanical strength, collenchyma also provides flexibility to the organ and allows their bending eg. : Cucurbita.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: An organised and differentiated cellular structure having cytoplasm but no nucleus is

response.explanation: Internally, sieve tubes possess peripheral layer of cytoplasm and are devoid of nucleus. They are living cells. Cell walls of sieve tubes are thickened than surrounding parenchyma cells.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Collenchyma occurs in

response.explanation: Collenchyma is abundant in climbing stems providing mechanical strength.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: For union between stock and scion in grafting which one is the first to occur?

response.explanation: In grafting, union between stock and scion produces undifferentiated mass of cells called callus. Grafting is a method of plant propagation widely used in horticulture, where the tissues of one plant are encouraged to fuse with those of another.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Organisation of stem apex into corpus and tunica is determined mainly by

response.explanation: Cells of tunica divide anticlinally to form the outer layer, cells of corpus undergo division in different planes.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Sieve tubes are suited for translocation of food because they possess

options.c: Broader lumen and perforated cross walls

response.explanation: Sieve tubes are elongated tubular conducting channels of phloem. The end walls possess many small pores and have thin cellulose wall. The lumen is broad in nature.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Tunica corpus theory is connected with

response.explanation: The shoot apex or stem apical meristem has two zones, outer tunica and inner corpus. This theory was given by Schmidt 1924.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Which meristem helps in increasing girth?

response.explanation: Lateral meristems occur on the sides of stem and help in increasing girth of stem and root. It divides only periclinally or radially and is responsible for increase in girth or diameter.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Meristematic Tissue/Simple and Complex Tissue

input.question: Which one yields fibres?

response.explanation: Commercial fibres are obtained from Cocos nucifera (coconut) also called surface fibres and occur on surface of seeds.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Tissue System (Epidermis/Ground Vascular)

input.question: Casparian strips occur in

response.explanation: Casparian strip is a band of cell wall material deposited in the radial and transverse walls of the endodermis. Casparian strip is made of suberin and sometimes lignin.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Tissue System (Epidermis/Ground Vascular)

input.question: Which of the following facilitates opening of stomatal aperture?

options.a: Decrease in turgidity of guard cells
options.b: Radial orientation of cellulose microfibrils in the cell wall of guard cells
options.c: Longitudinal orientation of cellulose microfibrils in the cell wall of guard cells
options.d: Contraction of outer wall of guard cells

response.explanation: Cellulose microfibrils are arranged radially rather than longitudinally which makes easy for the stomata to open.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Tissue System (Epidermis/Ground Vascular)

input.question: Which of the following statements is not true for stomatal apparatus?

options.a: Inner walls of guard cells are thick
options.b: Guard cells invariably possess chloroplasts and mitochondria
options.c: Guard cells are always surrounded by subsidiary cells
options.d: Stomata are involved in gaseous exchange

response.explanation: Sometimes, a few epidermal cells in the vicinity of the guard cells become specialised in their shape and size and are known as subsidiary cells or accessory cells.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Tissue System (Epidermis/Ground Vascular)

input.question: Ground tissue includes

options.b: All tissues except epidermis and vascular bundles

response.explanation: Ground tissue includes all tissues except epidermis and vascular bundles. The ground tissue comprises the bulk of the primary plant body. Parenchyma, collenchyma and sclerenchyma cells are common in the ground tissue.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Tissue System (Epidermis/Ground Vascular)

input.question: In land plants, the guard cells differ from other epidermal cells in having:

response.explanation: Guard cells differ from epidermal cells in having chloroplast. The cell wall of guard cells are not uniform, inner walls are thicker than the outer walls, epidermal cells are uniformly thin.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Tissue System (Epidermis/Ground Vascular)

input.question: Palisade parenchyma is absent in leaves of:

response.explanation: Palisade parenchyma is absent in leaves of sorghum. It is a leaf tissue composed of columnar cells containing numerous chloroplasts in which the long axis of each cell is perpendicular to the leaf surface. The palisade parenchyma is usually directly beneath the epidermis of the upper surface of the leaf.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Tissue System (Epidermis/Ground Vascular)

input.question: Vascular tissues in flowering plants develop from:

response.explanation: Vascular tissues in flowering plants develop from plerome. Plerome is a central core of primary meristem which gives rise to all cells of the stele from the pericycle inward.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Tissue System (Epidermis/Ground Vascular)

input.question: What happens during vascularization in plants?

options.a: Differentiation of procambium is immediately followed by the development of secondary xylem and phloem
options.b: Differentiation of procambium followed by the development of xylem and phloem
options.c: Differentiation of procambium, xylem and phloem is simultaneous
options.d: Differentiation of procambium followed by the development of primary phloem and then by primary xylem

response.explanation: Vascularization of plant means the development of vascular bundle in the plant, which develops from the cambium.

input.question: Identify the incorrect statement.

options.a: Sapwood is involved in conduction of water and minerals from root to leaf
options.b: Sapwood is the innermost secondary xylem and is lighter in colour
options.c: Due to deposition of tannins, resins, oils etc., heart wood is dark in colour
options.d: Heart wood does not conduct water but gives mechanical support

response.explanation: Correct statement: Sapwood is outermost secondary xylem. Outer secondary xylem or sapwood serves in water conduction, while the inner part called heartwood is composed of dead but structurally strong primary xylem.

input.question: The roots that originate from the base of the stem are

response.explanation: The roots that originate from the base of the stem are fibrous roots. A fibrous root system is the opposite of a taproot system. It is usually formed by thin, moderately branching roots growing from the stem. A fibrous root system is universal in monocotyledonous plants and ferns.

input.question: The transverse section of a plant shows following anatomical features: (i) Large number of scattered vascular bundles surrounded by bundle sheath (ii) Large conspicuous parenchymatous ground tissue (iii) Vascular bundles conjoint and closed (iv) Phloem parenchyma absent Identify the category of plant and its part:

response.explanation: The monocot stem is characterised by conjoint, collateral, and closed vascular bundles, scattered in the ground tissue containing the parenchyma. Each vascular bundle is surrounded by sclerenchymatous bundle-sheath cells. Phloem parenchyma and medullary rays are absent in monocot stems.

input.question: In the dicot root the vascular cambium originates from:

options.a: Intrafascicular and interfascicular tissue in a ring
options.b: Tissue located below the phloem bundles and a portion of pericycle tissue above protoxylem

response.explanation: Vascular cambium is a secondary meristematic tissue, in dicot roots. It is originated from tissue located below the phloem bundles and a portion of pericycle tissue above the protoxylem. The vascular cambium produces secondary xylem on the inside of the ring, and secondary phloem on the outside, pushing the primary xylem and phloem apart.

input.question: Secondary xylem and phloem in dicot stem are produced by

response.explanation: Secondary tissues are generated from the growth of a cambium. Vascular cambium gives rise to secondary xylem to the inside, and to secondary phloem to the outside.

input.question: A major characteristic of the monocot root is the presence of:

options.c: Cambium sandwiched between phloem and xylem along the radius

response.explanation: Monocot root shows radial and closed vascular bundle (xylem & phloem).

input.question: Vascular bundles in monocotyledons are considered closed because:

options.b: There are no vessels with perforations
options.c: Xylem is surrounded all around by phloem
options.d: A bundle sheath surrounds each bundle

response.explanation: Vascular bundles in monocotyledons are considered closed due to absence of cambium.

input.question: You are given a fairly old piece of dicot stem and a dicot root. Which of the following anatomical structures will you use to distinguish between the two?

response.explanation: Anatomically fairly old dicotyledonous root is distinguished from the dicotyledonous stem by position of the protoxylem. In dicot root, the protoxylem is located near the periphery of the vascular cylinder while in dicot stem the protoxylem is located near the centre of vascular bundle i.e., the xylem is endarch.

input.question: Closed vascular bundles lack

response.explanation: In closed vascular bundle cambium is absent between xylem and phloem.

input.question: Water containing cavities in vascular bundles are found in:

response.explanation: Stem of maize has water containing cavities in vascular bundles.

input.question: As compared to a dicot root, a monocot root has

response.explanation: The vascular bundles are arranged in a loose circle inside the endodermis of a monocot root. In a monocot root, more than six vascular bundles are present. It shows polyarch condition.

input.question: Which one of the following is wrongly matched?

response.explanation: Smut is a disease of cereals, corn, grasses and sorghum caused by many species of fungi. The smuts are multicellular fungi characterized by their large numbers of teliospores.

input.question: Some vascular bundles are described as open because these

options.a: Are surrounded by pericycle but not endodermis
options.b: Are capable of producing secondary xylem and phloem
options.c: Possess conjunctive tissue between xylem and phloem

response.explanation: Open vascular bundles means presence of cambium during secondary growth. Vascular cambium divides to form secondary xylem towards inner side while secondary phloem towards outside.

input.question: Anatomically fairly old dicotyledonous root is distinguished from the dicotyledonous stem by

response.explanation: Anatomically fairly old dicotyledonous root is distinguished from the dicotyledonous stem by position of protoxylem. In dicot root the protoxylem is located near the periphery of the vascular cylinder while in dicot stem the protoxylem is located near the centre of vascular bundle i.e. the xylem is endarch.

input.question: The annular and spirally thickened conducting elements generally develop in the protoxylem when the root or stem is:

response.explanation: The annular and spirally thickened conducting elements generally develop in the protoxylem when the root or stem is maturing.

input.question: In barley stem vascular bundles are:

response.explanation: In barley stem, vascular bundles are closed and scattered. They are open only for a hours in the day time and never open at night. e.g Cereals.

input.question: Four radial vascular bundles are found in

response.explanation: When xylem and phloem strands are present at different radii the vascular bundles are radial and 4 radial vascular bundles (tetrach condition) are present in dicot root. This is called tetrach conditions.

input.question: Transition of radial vascular bundle in root to conjoint vascular bundle in stem occurs in which zone?

response.explanation: Transition of radial vascular bundle in root to conjoint vascular bundle in stem occurs in transition zone which is generally hypocotyl. Hypocotyl is the part of embryonal axis below the level of cotyledons.

input.question: Where do the casparian bands occur?

response.explanation: Endodermis or innermost layer of cortex has casparian strips in roots. It is called starch sheath in dicot stems. It separates cortex from stele. The cell walls are thickened at the corners in angular collenchyma.

input.question: Plant having column of vascular tissues bearing fruits and having a tap root system is

response.explanation: Dicots possess tap root system.

input.question: A bicollateral vascular bundle is characterised by

response.explanation: Bicollateral vascular bundles have phloem in both outer and inner side of xylem. These type of bundles occur in cucurbitaceae.

input.question: Monocot leaves possess

response.explanation: Intercalary meristems are derived from apical meristems and separated from the same by permanent cells. They are responsible for localised growth.

input.question: Collenchyma occurs in the stem and petioles of

response.explanation: Collenchyma provides mechanical strength to young dicot stems, petioles and leaves.

input.question: Pericycle of roots produces

response.explanation: Pericycle in roots is active in the formation of root branches or lateral roots.

input.question: What is true about a monocot leaf?

options.b: Absence of bulliform cells from epidermis
options.c: Mesophyll not differentiated into palisade and spongy tissues

response.explanation: In monocot leaves, the mesophyll cells are undifferentiated.

input.question: Pith and cortex do not differentiate in

response.explanation: The ground tissue in monocot stem do not show distinction into cortex, endodermis, pericycle, pith and pith rays.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Which of the statements given below is not true about formation of annual rings in trees?

options.a: Annual ring is a combination of spring wood and autumn wood produced in a year
options.b: Differential activity of cambium causes light and dark bands of tissue - early and late wood respectively
options.c: Activity of cambium depends upon variation in climate
options.d: Annual rings are not prominent in trees of temperate region

response.explanation: Growth rings are formed by the seasonal activity of cambium. In plants of temperate regions, cambium is more active in spring (less lignin deposition in xylem) and less active in autumn (more lignin deposition in xylem) seasons. In temperate regions climatic conditions are not uniform throughout the year. However in tropics climatic conditions are uniform throughout the year.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Plants having little or no secondary growth are

response.explanation: Grasses are monocots and monocots usually do not have secondary growth. Palm like monocots have anomalous secondary growth.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: The vascular cambium normally gives rise to:

response.explanation: During secondary growth in plants vascular cambium gives rise to secondary xylem and secondary phloem. Phelloderm is formed by cork cambium. Periderm is the corky outer layer formed in secondary thickening.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Identify the wrong statement in context of heartwood:

options.b: It conducts water and minerals efficiently
options.c: It comprises dead elements with highly lignified walls
options.d: Organic compounds are deposited in it

response.explanation: Heartwood is inactive physiologically due to deposition of organic compounds and formation of tyloses so it will not conduct water and minerals.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Read the different components from (a) to (D) in the list given below and tell the correct order of the components with reference to their arrangement from outer side to inner side in a woody dicot stem. (A) Secondary cortex (B) Wood (C) Secondary phloem (D) Phellem The correct order is:

response.explanation: The correct sequence from outerside to inner side in a woody dicot stem is as follows: Phellem → Secondary cortex → Secondary phloem → Wood, [(D) → (A) → (C) → (B)]

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Age of a tree can be estimated by:

response.explanation: Age of a tree can be estimated by number of annual rings. Annual ring constitute alternate concentric rings of spring wood and autumn wood.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Lenticels are involved in:

response.explanation: Lenticels are lens shaped openings occuring in stems of most of the woody trees. It permits the exchange of gases between the outer atmosphere and the internal tissue of the stem.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Interfascicular cambium develops from the cells of:

response.explanation: At the time of secondary growth interfascicular cambium is formed by parenchymatous medullary rays. Interfascicular cambium along with intrafascicular cambium (formed from cambium cells present between xylem and phloem) constitute continuous cambium ring.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: The common bottle cork is a product of:

response.explanation: The common bottle cork is the product of phellogen. Phellogen produces cork or phellem on the outer side. It consists of dead and compactly arranged rectangular cells that possess suberised cell walls.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Gymnosperms are also called soft wood spermatophytes because they lack:

response.explanation: Xylem fibres provide rigidity to the plant.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: The cork cambium, cork and secondary cortex are collectively called:

response.explanation: Phellem, phellogen and phelloderm are collectively called periderm.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Which one of the following is not a lateral meristem?

response.explanation: Meristem is divided on the basis of position in plant bodies into apical meristem, lateral meristem and intercalary meristem. Lateral meristem is present on the lateral sides, that is fascicular and interfascicular cambium and cork cambium (phellogen).

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Heartwood differs from sapwood in:

options.d: Being susceptible to pests and pathogens

response.explanation: Heartwood differs from sapwood in having dead and non-conducting elements. In old trees, the inner region that comprises dead elements with highly lignified walls is called heartwood. Heartwood does not conduct water but gives mechanical support to the stem.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Which one of the following is resistant to enzyme action?

response.explanation: Pollen exine is resistant to enzyme action. The hard outer layer called the exine is made up of sporopollenin which is one of the most resistant organic material known. It can withstand high temperatures and strong acids and alkali. No enzymes that degrade sporopollenin are so far known.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: For a critical study of secondary growth in plants. Which one of the following pairs is suitable?

response.explanation: Teak and pine are most suitable for the study of critical secondary growth because in secondary growth, secondary tissues are formed from lateral meristem which is well developed in these two cases and secondary growth occurs in gymnosperms and dicots.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Ectophilic siphonostele is found in

response.explanation: The central pith is surrounded by xylem, phloem, pericycle and endodermis. The phloem occurs only outside the xylem e.g. Equisetum, Osmunda.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Main function of lenticel is

response.explanation: Lenticels are pores present in woody stem through which transpiration or loss of water vapour takes place. Lenticel formation begins during the development of the first periderm.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Which of the following meristems is responsible for extrastellar secondary growth in dicotyledonous stem?

response.explanation: Intrafascicular cambium occurs inside the vascular bundles in between xylem and phloem. Interfascicular cambium develops in the form of strips at the level of intrafascicular cambium of vascular bundles. Intercalary meristem lie in between areas of permanent tissues.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Procambium forms

options.d: Primary vascular bundles and vascular cambium

response.explanation: Procambium is the derivative of shoot apical meristem and forms vascular strand.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: As the secondary growth takes place (proceeds) in a tree, thickness of

response.explanation: Heartwood is the central wood of mature dicot stem and is the nonfunctional part of secondary xylem.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Abnormal/anomalous secondary growth occurs in

response.explanation: Abnormal secondary growth occurs in some arborescent monocots (eg. : Dracaena, Yucca)

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Which exposed wood will decay faster?

response.explanation: Sapwood is less durable because it is susceptible to attack by pathogen and insects. It is physiologically active and conduction of water takes place through it. Heartwood is not attacked by pathogens and insects as it is physiologically inactive.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: A narrow layer of thin walled cells found between phloem/bark and wood of a dicot is

response.explanation: Vascular cambium is produced by two types of meristems, fascicular and interfascicular cambium.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Periderm is produced by

response.explanation: Secondary ground tissue or periderm is formed from phellogen or cork cambium. The phellogen forms phellem on the outer face and phelloderm on the inner. The three layers i.e., phellem, phellogen and phelloderm jointly constitute the periderm.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Vascular cambium produces

response.explanation: Vascular cambium produces secondary xylem on the inner side and secondary phloem to the outer side.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Commercial cork is obtained from

response.explanation: Quercus suber (cork oak or bottle cork) possess cork cells. Cork cells are dead, suberized and impervious to water and air, compactly arranged with no intercellular spaces.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Cork cambium and vascular cambium are

options.a: Parts of secondary xylem and phloem

response.explanation: Cork cambium and vascular cambium are responsible for secondary growth which increases the girth of the stem.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Which is the correct fact about diffuse or ring porous wood?

options.a: Ring porous wood, carries more water for short period
options.b: Diffuse porous wood carries more water
options.c: Ring porous wood carries more water when need is higher
options.d: Diffuse porous wood is less specialised but conducts water rapidly throughout

response.explanation: Ring porous wood is more advanced than diffuse porous wood as it provides for better translocation when requirement of plant is high.

topic: Anatomy of Flowering Plants - Secondary Growth

input.question: Cork is formed from

response.explanation: Phellogen present in outer cortical cells produce cork or phellem on the outer side which consists of dead and compactly arranged rectangular cells that possess suberised cell walls which causes them to become buoyant. Phellogen also cuts off cells on innerside called as phelloderm or secondary cortex.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: Cuboidal epithelium with brush border of microvilli is found in

response.explanation: Cuboidal epithelium with brush border of microvilli is found in proximal convoluted tubule of nephron (PCT).

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: Choose the correctly matched pair:

options.a: Inner lining of salivary ducts – Ciliated epithelium
options.b: Moist surface of buccal cavity – Glandular epithelium
options.c: Tubular parts of nephrons – Cuboidal epithelium
options.d: Inner surface of bronchioles – Squamous epithelium

response.explanation: (i) Inner lining of salivary ducts - Compound epithelium; (ii) Moist surface of buccal cavity - Compound epithelium; (iii) Tubular parts of nephrons - Cuboidal epithelium; (iv) Inner surface of bronchioles - Ciliated epithelium.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: The ciliated columnar epithelial cells in humans are known to occur in:

response.explanation: Ciliated epithelium is usually found in the respiratory tract of fallopian tubes. Ciliated epithelium is a thin tissue that has hair-like structures on it. These hairs, called cilia, move back and forth to help move particles out of our body. We find ciliated epithelial tissue in our respiratory tract and in the fallopian tubes of women.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: The kind of epithelium which forms the inner walls of blood vessels is:

response.explanation: Squamous epithelium is formed of thin discoidal and polygonal cells that fit like tiles in a floor, so is also called pavement epithelium. It is found in the walls of blood vessels, in the alveoli of lung for exchange of gas, and in Bowman's capsule of nephron for ultra filtration.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: The epithelial tissue present on the inner surface of bronchioles and fallopian tube is:

response.explanation: Ciliated epithelium has simple columnar epithelial cells, but in addition, they posses fine hair-like outgrowths, cilia on their free surfaces. These cilia are capable of rapid, rhythmic, wavelike beatings in a certain direction.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: The cell junctions called tight, adhering and gap junctions are found in

response.explanation: The cell junctions known as tight, adhering and gap junctions are found in epithelial tissue. Epithelial tissue covers the whole surface of the body. It is made up of cells closely packed and ranged in one or more layers.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: Simple epithelium is a tissue in which the cells are

options.a: Hardened and provide support to the organs
options.b: Cemented directly to one another to form a single layer
options.c: Continuously dividing to provide form to an organ
options.d: Loosely connected to one another to form an irregular organ

response.explanation: Simple epithelium is a tissue made of a single layer of compactly arranged cells all of which rest over a noncellular basement membrane.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: Stratum germinativum is an example of which kind of epithelium?

response.explanation: The simple cuboidal epithelium consists of a single layer of polygonal cells which appear cuboidal in vertical section. Cuboidal epithelium occurs in terminal respiratory bronchioles. Columnar epithelium is made of tall cylindrical cells and it occurs in the lining of stomach.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: Basement membrane is made up of

options.d: No cell at all, but is a product of epithelial cells

response.explanation: Basement membrane is a delicate noncellular layer made of extracellular material that lies below the epithelium in contact with its basal surface. Besides this the basal lamina consists of mucopoly saccharides and very fine fibres.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: Epithelial tissue with thin flat cells appearing like packed tiles occurs on

response.explanation: Squamous epithelial cells have the appearance of thin, flat plates. The shape of the nucleus usually corresponds to the cell form and helps to identify the type of epithelium. Squamous cells, for example, tend to have horizontal flattened, elliptical nuclei because of the thin flattened form of the cell. They form the lining of cavities such as the mouth, blood vessels, heart and lungs and make up the outer layers of the skin.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: The layer of actively dividing cells of skin is termed as

response.explanation: It is the innermost one called thick layer made up of columnar epithelial cells. It lies on a basement. These cells are active & continuously produce new cells by mitotic division and is thus called germinative layer or stratum germinativum.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Tissue/Epithelial Tissue

input.question: Hair present in the skin are

options.a: Epidermal in origin and made of dead cells
options.b: Epidermal in origin and made of living cells
options.c: Dermal in origin and made of living cells
options.d: Dermal in origin and made of dead cells

response.explanation: Each hair is present in a tubular pit called hair follicle. Living cells are only present at the base of hair known as hair papilla, rest of the hair is dead and divisible into outer cuticle, middle cortex & inner medulla.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Match the following cell structure with its characteristic feature: (a) Tight junctions (i) Cement neighbouring cells together to form sheet (b) Adhering junctions (ii) Transmit information through chemical to another cells. (c) Gap junctions (iii) Establish a barrier to prevent leakage of fluid across epithelial cells. (d) Synaptic junctions (iv) Cytoplasmic channels to facilitate communication between adjacent cells.

response.explanation: Tight junctions provide a barrier which prevents leakage of fluid across epithelial cells. Adherens junctions aid to cement adjacent cells to form a sheet. Gap junctions provide cytoplasmic channels to facilitate communication between adjacent cells. Synaptic junctions help in transmission of information through chemicals.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Which type of tissue correctly matches with its location?

response.explanation: Wall of intestine is made of smooth muscle. Tendons consist of dense regular connective tissue fascicles encased in dense irregular connective tissue sheaths. Tip of nose consists of squamous epithelium. Lining of epithelium is made of columnar epithelium.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Choose the correctly matched pair:

response.explanation: Tendon is dense regular connective tissue. Adipose tissue is a type of loose connective tissue located mainly beneath the cells. Cartilage is a type of specialised connective tissue.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Given below is the diagrammatic sketch of a certain type of connective tissue. Identify the parts labeled A, B, C and D, and select the correct answer from the given option.

options.a: Macrophage, Fibroblast, Collagen fibres, Mast cells
options.b: Mast cell, Macrophage, Fibroblast fibres, Collagen fibres
options.c: Macrophage, Collagen fibres, Fibroblast fibres, Mast cell
options.d: Mast cell, Collagen fibres, Fibroblast fibres, Macrophage

response.explanation: Connective tissue is the most diverse of the four tissue types with a wide variety of functions. Connective tissue is made up of cells and fibers in a 'jelly-like' ground substance.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: The supportive skeletal structures in the human external ears and in the nose tip are examples of

response.explanation: Cartilage is a type of connective tissue which is present in external ears and in the nose tip of humans.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: The cells lining the blood vessels belong to the category of:

response.explanation: The lining of a blood vessel is with simple squamous epithelium. Inner most lining of blood vessels is called endothelium. 'Squamous' refers to the fact that the cells are flat.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: The kind of tissue that forms the supportive structure in our pinna (external ears) is also found in:

response.explanation: The kind of tissue that forms the supportive structure in our pinna (external ears) is also found in tip of the nose. External pinna is made up of elastic cartilage. It is the passage towards middle ear.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: In which one of the following preparations are your likely to come across cell junctions most frequently?

response.explanation: It is ciliated epithelium which bears numerous delicate hair like outgrowths, the cilia, arising from basal granules. The cilia remains in rhythmic motion and creates current to transport the materials which comes in contact with them.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Areolar connective tissue joins

response.explanation: Areolar connective tissue has rich supply of nerve fibres and blood vessels. It joins skin epithelia with muscles, nerves & blood vessels. Binding of body parts together is the main function of areolar connective tissue.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Mast cells secrete

response.explanation: At the site of infection, the infectious organisms release some chemical to increase the flow of mast cells towards the inflammation site. Mast cell release histamine which increases the permeability of blood vessels at the site of inflammation so that more blood supply takes place. The site gets warm and red due to this.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Which cartilage is present at the end of long bones?

response.explanation: Hyaline cartilage is present at the end of long articular bones. It provides a smooth articular surface to permit movement at joints. Elastic cartilage is found where support with flexibility is needed such as in external ears. Fibro cartilage is a very tough substance and is used in places of the body where shock absorbers are needed.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: During an injury nasal septum gets damaged and for its recovery which cartilage is preferred?

response.explanation: Hyaline cartilage is firm but slightly elastic with clear matrix. It is present in larynx, trachea, bronchi, nose. Elastic cartilage occurs in external ear. Calcified cartilage occurs in suprascapula. Fibrous cartilage occurs in intervertebral discs.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: The polysaccharide present in the matrix of cartilage is known as

response.explanation: The chief component of ground substance of cartilage is chondromuco protein which is formed of chondriotin sulphate, keratin sulphate and hyaluronic acid.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Protein present in the matrix of cartilage is known as

response.explanation: Chondrin is a gelatin-like substance and can be obtained by boiling cartilage in water. The cartilage is a connective tissue that contains cells embedded in a matrix of chondrin.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Formation of cartilage bones involves

options.a: Deposition of bony matter by osteoblasts and resorption chondroblasts
options.b: Deposition of bony matter by osteoclasts and resorption by chondroblasts
options.c: Deposition of bony matter by osteoclasts only
options.d: Deposition of bony matter by osteoblasts only

response.explanation: Deposition of bony matter by osteoblasts and resorption chondroblasts.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Blood capillary consists of

options.b: Endothelium and thin coat of connective tissue
options.c: Endothelium and thin coat of muscle fibres
options.d: Endothelium and thin coat of connective tissue plus muscle fibres

response.explanation: The wall of capillaries are very thin (usually less than one micron) and have numerous minute pores and made up of only endothelium. Exchange of material takes place between blood and tissue fluid across the endothelial membrane of capillaries through active diffusion.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Connective Tissue

input.question: Histamine secreting cells are found in

response.explanation: In connective tissues, histamine is an organic nitrogen compound involved in local immune responses and regulating physiological function in the gut and it acts as a neurotransmitter. Histamine is produced by basophils and mast cells found in nearby connective tissues.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Muscular Tissue

input.question: Identify the tissue shown in the diagram and match with its characteristics and its location

options.a: Skeletal muscle, shows striations and closely attached with the bones of the limbs
options.b: Smooth muscles, show branching, found in the walls of the heart
options.c: Cardiac muscles, unbranched muscles, found in the walls of the heart
options.d: Striated muscles, tapering at both-ends, attached with the bones of the ribs

response.explanation: Skeletal muscle tissue is closely attached to skeletal bones. In a typical muscle such as the biceps, striated (striped) skeletal muscle fibres are bundled together in a parallel fashion.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Muscular Tissue

input.question: The four sketches (1, 2, 3 and 4) given below, represent four different types of animal tissues. Which one of these is correctly identified in the options given, along with its correct location and function?

options.b: (3) Collagen fibres - Cartilage - Attach skeletal muscles to bones
options.c: (4) Smooth muscle tissue - Heart - Heart contraction
options.d: (1) Columnar epithelium - Nephron - Secretion and absorption

response.explanation: Glandular epithelium invaginates epithelia into connective tissue which differentiate into secretory units. Examples include sebaceous glands of the skin and glands in the intestinal lining (exocrine glands), and many endocrine glands releasing hormones, such as the thyroid follicle.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Muscular Tissue

input.question: The type of muscles present in our:

options.a: Heart are involuntary and unstriated smooth muscles
options.d: Upper arm are smooth muscle fibres fusiform in shape

response.explanation: Thigh muscles are skeletal muscles that are striated and voluntary.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Muscular Tissue

input.question: Which one of the following is correct pairing of a body part and the kind of muscle tissue that moves it?

options.a: Biceps of upper arm–Smooth muscle fibres

response.explanation: The structure of the abdominal wall is similar in principle to the thoracic wall. There are three layers, an external, internal and innermost layer. The vessels and nerves lie between the internal and innermost layers.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Muscular Tissue

input.question: Which of the following is not exclusively supplied with involuntary muscles?

options.b: Muscles of the ducts of glands

response.explanation: Voluntary muscles - under control of our will. Involuntary muscles - Not under the control of our will. Muscles of urethra also remain under voluntary control after infancy.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Neural Tissue

input.question: Which one of the following contains the largest quantity of extracellular material?

response.explanation: Areolar tissue is the least specialized connective tissue. It has a large amount of ground substance (extracellular material) and possesses rich blood and nerve supplies. It spreads extensively throughout the body, under the skin and epithelia, in between and around muscles, nerves and blood vessels and in the submucosa of respiratory and gastrointestinal tract.

topic: Structural Organisation in Animals - Neural Tissue

input.question: Which cells do not form layer and remain structurally separate?

response.explanation: Only nerve cells do not form layers. These also remain structurally separate from each other. Nerve cells or neurons are the cells specialized to conduct an electrochemical current. Nerve tissue is made up of these cells and supporting cells.

input.question: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

options.a: Female cockroach possesses sixteen ovarioles in the ovaries
options.b: Cockroaches exhibit mosaic vision with less sensitivity and more resolution
options.c: A mushroom-shaped gland is present in the 6th-7th abdominal segments of male cockroach
options.d: A pair of spermatheca is present in the 6th segment of female cockroach

response.explanation: Cockroaches receive several images of an object with the help of ommatidia. This kind of vision possessed by cockroaches is known as mosaic vision which has more sensitivity but less resolution.

input.question: Frog's heart when taken out of the body continues to beat for sometime. Select the best option from the following statements. (a) Frog is a poikilotherm. (b) Frog does not have any coronary circulation. (c) Heart is 'myogenic' in nature. (d) Heart is autoexcitable

response.explanation: The vertebrates process myogenic heart which is self contractile system or autoexcitable; it will thus keep working outside the body for some time.

input.question: Which of the following features is not present in Periplaneia americana?

options.b: Indeterminate and radial cleavage during embryonic development

response.explanation: Periplanata americana shows spiral and determinate types of cleavage during embryonic development which is a feature of Protostomes.

input.question: The body cells in cockroach discharge their nitrogenous waste in the haemolymph mainly in the form of:

response.explanation: The body cells in cockroach discharge their nitrogenous waste in the haemolymph as a solution of sodium or potassium urate (a weak alkaline fluid).

input.question: The terga, stema and pleura of cockroach body are joined by:

response.explanation: Between the various sclerite, a flexible membrane exists which is known as arthrodial membrane.

input.question: What external changes are visible after the last moult of a cockroach nymph?

options.b: Both fore wings and hind wings develop

response.explanation: The development of cockroach is paurometabolous meaning that their development is through nymphal stage. The nymphs look very much like adults. The nymph grows by moulting about 13 times to reach adult form. The last nymphal stage has wingpads while adult cockroaches have wings.

input.question: Select the correct option with respect to cockroaches

options.a: The fore wings are tegmina which are used in flight
options.b: Malpighian tubules convert nitrogenous wastes into urea
options.c: Males bear short anal styles not present in females
options.d: Nervous system comprises of a dorsal nerve cord and ten pairs of ganglion

response.explanation: In cockroaches, males bear a pair of short, thread like anal styles which are absent in females.

input.question: Compared to those of humans, the erythrocytes in frog are

response.explanation: The erythrocytes or RBCs in frog are large, oval-and-biconvex-nucleated-cells-with respiratory red pigment haemoglobin in its cytoplasm.

input.question: Select the correct statement from the ones given below with respect to Periplaneta americana.

options.a: Nervous system located dorsally, consists of segmentally arranged ganglia joined by a pair of longitudinal connectives
options.b: Males bear a pair of short thread like anal styles
options.c: There are 16 very long Malpighian tubules present at the junctions of midgut and hindgut
options.d: Grinding of food is carried out only by the mouth parts

response.explanation: The anal styles in males cockroaches help in copulation. The tenth abdominal segment carries two pairs of abdominal appendage in male cockroach as segmented anal cerci and unsegmented anal styles or caudal styles. In case of females, the tenth abdominal segment carries only one pair of abdominal appendages and many segmented anal cerci.

input.question: One very special feature in the earthworm Pheretima is that

options.a: Fertilisation for eggs occurs inside the body
options.b: The typhlosole greatly increases the effective absorption area of the digested food in the intestine
options.c: The S-shaped setae embedded in the integrument are the defensive weapons used against the enemies
options.d: It has a long dorsal tubular heart

response.explanation: The intestine of an earthworm has a peculiar fold of tissue that forms a pocket in the intestine that is visible when viewing a cross section. This space, which runs almost the whole length of the body dorsally is known as the typhlosole and it serves to increase the surface area of the intestine for absorption.

input.question: Which of the following is correctly stated as it happens in the common cockroach?

options.a: Malpighian tubules are excretory organs projecting out from the colon
options.b: Oxygen is transported by haemoglobin in blood
options.d: The food is ground by mandibles and gizzard

response.explanation: Cockroach intake the food after grounding it by its mandibles and gizzard.

input.question: Consider the following four statements (A-D) related to the common frog Rana tigrina, and select the correct option stating which ones are true (T) and which ones are false (F) (A) On dry land it would die due to lack of O2 its mouth is forcibly kept closed for a few days (B) It has four-chambered heart (C) On dry land it turns unicotelic from uroetelic (D) Its life-history is carried out in pond water

response.explanation: (A) Dry skin causes ceased cutaneous respiration; (B) Three chambered heart; (C) Frog never becomes uricotelic; (D) External fertilization occurs in water

input.question: Which one of the following structures in Pheretima is correctly matched with its function?

response.explanation: Clitellum - secretes cocoon during breeding season of earthworm. Gizzard is used for grinding of food particles. Setae help in locomotion. Typhlosole increases the absorption area in intestine.

input.question: If a live earthworm is pricked with a needle on it outer surface without damaging its gut, the fluid that comes out is:

response.explanation: If a live earthworm is pricked with a needle on its outer surface without damaging its gut, the fluid that comes out is coelomic fluid because coelomic fluid lies between body wall and alimentary canal.

input.question: Which one of the following correctly describes the location of some body parts in the earthworm Pheretima?

options.a: Four pairs of spermathecae in 4 - 7 segments
options.b: One pair of ovaries attached at intersegmental septum of 14th and 15th segments
options.c: Two pairs of testes in 10th and 11th segments
options.d: Two pairs of accessory glands in 16 - 18 segments

response.explanation: In Pheretima two pairs of testes sacs are situated in the 10th and 11th segments. Each testes sac of the 10th segment encloses a testes and a seminal funnel. Each testes sac of the 11th segment encloses a testes, a seminal vesicle and a seminal funnel.

input.question: Earthworms have no skeleton but during burrowing, the anterior end becomes turgid and acts as a hydraulic skeleton. It is due to

response.explanation: Earthworms have no skeleton but during burrowing, anterior end becomes turgid and acts as a hydraulic skeleton. It is due to coelomic fluid. The coelom is filled with an alkaline milky coelomic fluid. This coelomic fluid contains water, salts, proteins and 4 types of cells namely amoebocytes, mucocytes, circular cells and chloragogen cells.

input.question: A piece of bone such as femur of frog if kept in dilute HCl for about a week will

response.explanation: When a bone is kept in dilute acids like HCl for a few days, the Ca²⁺ salts get dissolved leaving only the soft and flexible organic matrix. This process is called decalcification. If a bone is kept in KOH it remains unaffected and only the surrounding muscles and connective tissues get dissolved so that the bone now appears clean.

input.question: A. Periplaneta americana is nocturnal, omnivorous, household pest. R. It is because it acts as scavenger

options.a: A is true but R is false
options.b: A is false but R is true
options.c: Both A and R are true and R is correct explanation of A
options.d: Both A and R are true but R is not correct explanation of A

response.explanation: Periplaneta americana (cockroach) cannot act as a scavenger, it does not feed upon dead animals.

input.question: Earthworm possesses hearts

response.explanation: Earthworm has 4 pairs of heart i.e., 2 pairs-Lateral hearts and 2 pairs-Lateral oesophageal hearts present in 7th and 9th and 12th and 13th segments respectively.

input.question: Male and female cockroaches can be distinguished externally through

options.c: Anal style and antennae in females

response.explanation: Sexual dimorphism is found in cockroach. A pair of anal style are present in male cockroach only. Female has broader abdominal segments.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organization

input.question: Identify the correct order of organisation of genetic material from largest to smallest:

response.explanation: Genome > chromosomes > gene > nucleotide. Genome represents the entire genetic material, chromosomes are structures containing genes, genes are segments of DNA, and nucleotides are the basic building blocks.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Structure

input.question: A protoplast is a cell:

response.explanation: Protoplast is a biological term coined by Hanstein in 1880 to refer to the entire cell excluding the cell wall. Protoplasts can be generated by stripping the cell wall from plant, bacterial, or fungal cells by mechanical, chemical or enzymatic means.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Microscopy

input.question: A major break through in the studies of cells came with the development of electron microscope. This is because

options.a: the resolving power of the electron microscope is 200-350 nm as compared to 0.1-0.2 for the light microscope
options.b: electron beam can pass through thick materials, whereas light microscopy requires thin sections
options.c: the electron microscope is more powerful than the light microscope as it uses a beam of electrons which has wavelength much longer than that of photons
options.d: the resolution power of the electron microscope is much higher than that of the light microscope

response.explanation: A major breakthrough in cell studies came with the development of EM having great resolution power due to which we can see the ultrastructures of cell organelles. Electron microscope uses a beam of electrons and their wave-like characteristics to magnify an object's image.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Microscopy

input.question: A student wishes to study the cell structure under a light microscope having 10X eyepiece and 45X objective. He should illuminate the object by which one of the following colours of light so as to get the best possible resolution?

response.explanation: Resolving power or limit of resolution is the ability of the eye to distinguish two close objects as separate. Its value is calculated by Abbe's equation, Lm = 0.61λ/NA where λ is the wavelength of light. Blue light has shorter wavelength, providing better resolution.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Theory

input.question: Names of Schleiden and Schwann are associated with

options.a: protoplasm as the physical basis of life
options.d: nucleus functions as control centre of cell

response.explanation: Cell theory was proposed by Schleiden and Schwann (1839) according to which 'All living organisms are composed of cells.' Cell theory is also known as cell principle, cell doctrine etc.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Theory

input.question: Which is correct about cell theory in view of current status of our knowledge about cell structure

options.a: It needs modification due to discovery of subcellular structures like chloroplasts and mitochondria
options.b: Modified cell theory means that all living beings are composed of cells capable of reproducing
options.c: Cell theory does not hold good because all living beings (e.g., viruses) do not have cellular organisation
options.d: Cell theory means that all living objects consist of cells whether or not capable of reproducing

response.explanation: The exceptions to cell theory are viruses which do not possess a cellular machinery. They consist of DNA or RNA core surrounded by a protein sheath and lack cellular organisation.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Measurements

input.question: Angstrom (Å) is equal to

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Microscopy

input.question: Electron microscope has a high resolution power. This is due to

options.b: very low wavelength of electron beam
options.c: low wavelength of light source used
options.d: high numerical aperture of glass lenses used

response.explanation: Resolution is a power of a microscope to distinguish between two particles that are closely situated. Electron microscope has high resolution power due to very low wavelength of electron beam.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Microscopy

input.question: Resolution power is the ability to

response.explanation: The ability to distinguish two close objects is called power of resolution.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Microscopy

input.question: Magnification of compound microscope is not connected with

response.explanation: Magnification is defined as the power of enlargement. Magnification of compound microscope is the product of magnification of objective lens and magnification of ocular lens. It is not connected with numerical aperture.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Fractionation

input.question: Organelles can be separated from cell homogenate through

response.explanation: Centrifuge is an instrument used to create a centrifugal force. The homogenate of the cell organelles is allowed to undergo centrifugation by which different cell organelles get separated. This process is known as differential centrifugation.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Prokaryotic Cells

input.question: Which of the following statements about inclusion bodies is incorrect?

options.a: These are involved in ingestion of food particles
options.b: They lie free in the cytoplasm
options.c: These represent reserve material in cytoplasm
options.d: They are not bound by any membrane

response.explanation: Inclusion bodies are nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates which are stainable substances, usually proteins, and formed due to viral multiplication or genetic disorders. These are not involved in ingestion of food particles.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Prokaryotic Cells

input.question: Which of the following nucleic acids is present in an organism having 70S ribosomes only?

options.a: Double stranded circular DNA with histone proteins
options.b: Single stranded DNA with protein coat
options.d: Double stranded DNA enclosed in nuclear membrane

response.explanation: The organisms which have ribosomes of 70S type are prokaryotes. Prokaryotes have double stranded DNA which is not enclosed in membrane and is circular and naked (without histones).

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Prokaryotic Cells

input.question: Which one of the following is not an inclusion body found in prokaryotes?

response.explanation: Polysomes are defined as a cluster of ribosomes attached to a mRNA molecule. They are not inclusion bodies. Inclusion bodies are storage structures like cyanophycean granules, glycogen granules, etc.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Wall

input.question: Cell wall is absent in:

response.explanation: Mycoplasma lacks cell wall. Mycoplasma's lack of cell wall characteristic makes them naturally resistant to antibiotics that target cell wall synthesis.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Prokaryotic Cells

input.question: Which structures perform the function of mitochondria in bacteria?

response.explanation: In some bacteria (e.g., Bacillus subtilis) the plasma membrane form certain invaginations or infoldings called mesosomes in the cytoplasm. The mesosomes have various functions, viz., respiratory, secretory etc.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Prokaryotic Cells

input.question: The term 'glycocalyx' is used for

options.a: A layer surrounding the cell wall of bacteria
options.b: A layer present between cell wall and membrane of bacteria
options.d: Bacterial cell glyco-engineered to possess N-glycosylated proteins

response.explanation: Glycocalyx or mucilage is the outermost coating of bacterial cells/cell wall which is rich in polysaccharides. A thick and tougher mucilage is called capsule which gives gummy or sticky trait to cells.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Prokaryotic Cells

input.question: Why is a capsule advantageous to a bacterium?

options.a: It allows the bacterium to attach to the surface
options.b: It protects the bacterium from desiccation
options.d: It allows bacterium to 'hide' from host's immune system

response.explanation: Capsule is a layer that lies outside the cell wall of bacteria. The capsule can protect cells from engulfment by eukaryotic cells, such as macrophages. They also exclude bacterial viruses and most hydrophobic toxic materials.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Comparison

input.question: Which one of the following does not differ in E.coli and Chlamydomonas?

response.explanation: Cell membrane of E.coli, a bacteria and Chlamydomonas a unicellular green alga does not differ. As in both cell membrane is composed of lipids and proteins.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Nuclear Membrane

input.question: Nuclear membrane is absent in

response.explanation: Nostoc is a prokaryote while rest are eukaryotes. Nuclear membrane is absent in prokaryotes.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cilia and Flagella

input.question: Which of the following statements regarding cilia is not correct?

options.b: Microtubules of cilia are composed of tubulin
options.c: Cilia contain an outer ring of nine doublet microtubules surrounding two single microtubules
options.d: The organized beating of cilia is controlled by fluxes of Ca2+ across the membrane

response.explanation: Eukaryotic cilia are made up of tubulin protein. Cilia have a core of 2 microtubules and around there are 9 doublet microtubules. These are not at all hair like structures.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Prokaryotic Cells

input.question: The prokaryotic flagella possess

response.explanation: The prokaryotic flagellum is single stranded made up of several parallel protein fibrils and helical in shape while in eukaryotes it is made up of axonema and sheath with 9+2 microtubular arrangement.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Golgi Apparatus

input.question: Golgi apparatus is absent in

response.explanation: Golgi complex is absent in prokaryotic cell i.e (PPLO, bacteria and blue green algae). It is present in all eukaryotic cells except sieve tubes of plants, sperms of bryophytes and pteridophytes and red blood corpuscles.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Nucleus

input.question: Experiments on Acetabularia by Hammerling proved the role of

response.explanation: Presence of hereditary information in the nucleus was proved by the work of Hammerling on single celled alga Acetabularia. In his experiments, the cap that developed matched the species of the foot (containing nucleus) rather than that of the stalk.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Golgi Apparatus

input.question: Golgi bodies are site of formation of

response.explanation: Golgi bodies are site of formation of glycoproteins and glycolipids in eukaryotic cells. Glycolipids are lipids with a carbohydrate attached by a glycosidic bond.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles
instruction: Answer the following NEET-style MCQ by matching columns.

input.question:
Match the column I with column II:
Column I
(a) Golgi apparatus
(b) Lysosomes
(c) Vacuoles
(d) Ribosomes

Column II
(i) Synthesis of protein
(ii) Trap waste and excretory products
(iii) Formation of glycoproteins and glycolipids
(iv) Digesting biomolecules

response.explanation: Golgi apparatus is involved in formation of glycoproteins and glycolipids. Lysosomes digest biomolecules. Vacuoles trap waste and excretory products. Ribosomes synthesize proteins.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Which of the following cell organelles is present in the highest number in secretory cells?

response.explanation: The important function of Golgi apparatus is to process, package and transport the materials for secretion. Therefore secretory cells have Golgi apparatus in highest number.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Which of the following cell organelles is responsible for extracting energy from carbohydrates to form ATP?

response.explanation: The site of aerobic oxidation of carbohydrates in cells to generate ATP are mitochondria.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Semi-autonomous Organelles

input.question:
Mitochondria and chloroplast are:
(a) semi-autonomous organelles
(b) formed by division of pre-existing organelles and they contain DNA but lack protein synthesizing machinery

Which one of the following options is correct?

response.explanation: Mitochondria & chloroplast are semi-autonomous cell organelles which are formed by division of pre-existing organelle & contain DNA but they also contain protein synthesizing machinery, thus (a) is true & (b) is false.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cytoskeleton

input.question: Microtubules are the constituents of

response.explanation: Roles of the microtubule cytoskeleton include mechanical support, organization of the cytoplasm, transport, motility and chromosome segregation so they are present in cilia and flagella for cellular movement, centrioles for chromosomal movement and spindle fibres for structural organization.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Which one of the following cell organelles is enclosed by a single membrane?

response.explanation: Double Membrane bound Organelles: Mitochondria, Chloroplasts, Endoplasmic Reticulum, Golgi Body, and Nucleus. Single Membrane bound Organelles: Lysosomes, Peroxisomes, and Vacuoles.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - DNA Location

input.question: DNA is not present in:

response.explanation: Ribosomes are composed of ribonucleic acid and proteins and are not surrounded by any membrane. These are the site for protein synthesis and do not contain DNA.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Nuclear Envelope

input.question: Nuclear envelope is a derivative of:

response.explanation: In late prophase, nuclear envelope disappears and reappears in late telophase from rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER).

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Endoplasmic Reticulum

input.question: Select the correct matching in the following pairs:

options.c: Rough ER – Oxidation of fatty acids

response.explanation: Lipid synthesis takes place in smooth endoplasmic reticulum. The outer membrane of the rER is studded with ribosomes and plays a major role in protein synthesis.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Which of the following are not membrane-bound?

response.explanation: Ribosomes are not membrane-bound cell organelle. They are not membrane-enclosed, instead they are macromolecules made of both RNA and proteins.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Junctions

input.question: The function of the gap junction is to

options.a: facilitate communication between adjoining cells by connecting the cytoplasm for rapid transfer of ions, small molecules and some large molecules
options.b: separate two cells from each other
options.c: stop substance from leading across a tissue
options.d: performing cementing to keep neighbouring cells together

response.explanation: The function of the gap junction is to facilitate communication between adjoining cells by connecting the cytoplasm for rapid transfer of ions, small molecules and some large molecules.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Chromosomes

input.question: Balbiani rings are sites of:

response.explanation: RNA and protein synthesis occur in Balbiani rings. Balbiani rings are exceptionally large puffs on the polytene chromosomes in the dipteran Chironomus tentans.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles
instruction: Answer the following NEET-style MCQ by matching columns.

input.question:
Match the columns and identify the correct option:
Column I
(1) Thylakoids
(2) Cristae
(3) Cisternae
(4) Chromatin

Column II
(i) Disc-shaped sacs in Golgi apparatus
(ii) Threads of DNA and protein
(iii) Flattened membranous sacs in chloroplasts
(iv) Infoldings in mitochondria

response.explanation: Thylakoids are flattened membranous sacs in chloroplasts, Cristae are infoldings in mitochondria, Cisternae are disc-shaped sacs in Golgi apparatus, Chromatin are threads of DNA and protein.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Cellular organelles with membranes are:

response.explanation: Lysosomes, golgi apparatus and mitochondria are the cell organelles which have membranes. Ribosomes and chromosomes are not membrane-bound.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cytoskeleton

input.question: The solid linear cytoskeletal elements having a diameter of 6 nm and made up of a single type of monomer are known as:

response.explanation: Microtubule, microfilament and intermediate filaments along with ER form cytoskeleton. Microfilaments are non-living, solid and consist of actin protein. They are 4-6 nm in diameter.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: The osmotic expansion of a cell kept in water is chiefly regulated by:

response.explanation: The vacuole is bound by a single membrane called tonoplast. It also functions as semipermeable membrane. It segregates vacuolar contents from cytoplasm, allows osmotic entry or exit of water, concentration and storage of nutrients as well as wastes.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles
instruction: Answer the following NEET-style MCQ by matching columns.

input.question:
Match the following and select the correct answer:
(1) Centriole
(2) Chlorophyll
(3) Cristae
(4) Ribozymes

(i) Infoldings in mitochondria
(ii) Thylakoids
(iii) Nucleic acids
(iv) Basal body cilia or flagella

response.explanation: Centriole forms basal body of cilia or flagella, Chlorophyll is present in thylakoids, Cristae are infoldings in mitochondria, Ribozymes are nucleic acids with enzymatic activity.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Which one of the following organelle in the figure correctly matches with its function?

options.d: Rough endoplasmic reticulum, formation of glycoproteins

response.explanation: Rough endoplasmic reticulum is a network or reticulum of tiny tubular structures scattered in the cytoplasm and bear ribosomes on their outer surface. These are involved in protein synthesis and secretion.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Golgi Apparatus

input.question: The Golgi complex plays a major role

options.c: in post translational modification of proteins and glycosidation of lipids
options.d: in trapping the light and transforming it into chemical energy

response.explanation: Golgi apparatus plays a major role in post translational modification of proteins forming glycoprotein and glycosidation of lipid forming glycolipids.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Endoplasmic Reticulum

input.question: A major site for synthesis of lipids is:

response.explanation: The smooth endoplasmic reticulum is the major site for synthesis of lipid. In animal cells lipid like steroidal hormones are synthesised in SER.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Plastids

input.question: Which of the following type of plastids does not contain stored food material?

response.explanation: Chromoplasts are non-photosynthetic coloured plastids which synthesise and store carotenoid pigments. They do not store food material unlike amyloplasts (store starch), aleuroplasts (store proteins) and elaioplasts (store oil droplets and fats).

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Mitochondria

input.question: Select the alternative giving correct identification and function of the organelle 'A' in the diagram

options.b: Mitochondria - Powerhouse of cell producing ATP

response.explanation: The mitochondria are bounded by two membranes, i.e., outer membrane and inner membrane. Mitochondria are referred as 'powerhouse' of the cell as they produce 95% of ATP. This energy is produced during the break down of food molecules.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Nucleolus

input.question: Ribosomal RNA is actively synthesized in

response.explanation: Ribosomal RNA is actively synthesized in nucleolus. Nucleolus is also known as ribosomal factory.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Ribosomes

input.question: Ribosomes are:
