response.explanation: Ribosomes are amembraneous (i.e. without membrane) cell organelle composed of rRNA and protein. These are found in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Membrane

input.question: Fluid mosaic membrane model was proposed by

response.explanation: Fluid mosaic membrane model was proposed by Singer and Nicholson in 1972. It is most accepted model of structure of biomembrane.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Which one of the following structures is an organelle within an organelle?

response.explanation: Ribosome are small naked (non membrane bound) particles made of r-RNA and proteins. Ribosomes are also seen in the organelles like mitochondria and chloroplasts, making them organelles within organelles.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Which one of the following cellular parts is correctly described?

options.a: Centrioles - Sites for active RNA synthesis
options.b: Lysosomes - Optimally active at a pH of about 8.5
options.c: Thylakoids - Flattened membranous sacs forming the grana of chloroplasts
options.d: Ribosomes - Those on chloroplasts are larger (80S) while those in the cytoplasm are smaller (70S)

response.explanation: Thylakoids are membrane-bound organelles found within chloroplasts. The thylakoid membrane forms many flattened, fluid-filled tubules that enclose a single convoluted compartment. These tubules tend to stack on top of each other to form a structure called a granum.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Golgi Apparatus

input.question: Important site for formation of glycoproteins and glycolipids is

response.explanation: Golgi apparatus is the important site for formation of glycoprotein and glycolipid.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Protein Synthesis

input.question: Peptide synthesis inside a cell takes place in:

response.explanation: Peptide synthesis takes place in ribosome of the cell.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Chromosomes

input.question: What are those structures that appear as beads-on-string in the chromosomes when viewed under electron microscope?

response.explanation: Under electron microscope the nucleosomes appear as beads on a string in chromosome, due to a short length of DNA wrapped around a core of histone proteins. The nucleosome is the fundamental subunit of chromatin.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Mitochondria

input.question: The figure below shows the structure of a mitochondrion with its four parts labelled (A), (B), (C) and (D). Select the part correctly matched with its function.

options.a: Part (D): Outer membrane – gives rise to inner membrane by splitting
options.b: Part (B): Inner membrane – forms infoldings called cristae
options.c: Part (C): Cristae – possess single circular DNA molecule and ribosomes
options.d: Part (A): Matrix – major site for respiratory chain enzymes

response.explanation: The mitochondrial inner membrane forms infoldings known as cristae, which allow greater surface area for protein such as cytochrome to function properly and efficiently.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Mitochondria

input.question: In mitochondria, proteins accumulate in the

response.explanation: The inner membrane of mitochondria contains more than 151 different polypeptides, and has a very high protein-to-phospholipid ratio.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Endomembrane System

input.question: Which one of the following is not considered as a part of the endomembrane system?

response.explanation: Except peroxisome the remaining three and ER are the parts of endomembrane system.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Connections

input.question: Which one of the following structures between two adjacent cells is an effective transport pathway?

response.explanation: Plasmodesmata are the structures present between two adjacent cells that permits the transport and communication between them. They are the fine cytoplasmic strands that connect the protoplasts of adjacent plant cells by passing through the cell walls.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - DNA containing Organelles

input.question: Which one of the following has its own DNA?

response.explanation: Mitochondria has its own DNA. It is a structure within cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells that carries out aerobic respiration. It is the site of Kreb's cycle and ETS.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cytoplasm

input.question: The main arena of various types of activities of a cell is:

response.explanation: The main arena of various types of activities of a cell is cytoplasm. It forms the living protoplasm of a cell excluding the nucleus. It consists of proteins, fats, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, vitamins, waste metabolites and all organelles.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Plasma Membrane

input.question: The plasma membrane consists mainly of:

options.a: phospholipids embedded in a protein bilayer
options.b: proteins embedded in a phospholipid bilayer
options.c: proteins embedded in a polymer of glucose molecules
options.d: proteins embedded in a carbohydrate bilayer

response.explanation: Plasma membrane comprises of mainly proteins embedded in a phospholipid bilayer. Protein molecules occur at places both inside and outer side of the lipid bilayer.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Plasmodesmata

input.question: Plasmodesmata are:

options.b: membranes connecting the nucleus with plasmalemma

response.explanation: Plasmodesmata are connections between adjacent cells. Plasmodesmata are narrow channels that act as intercellular cytoplasmic bridges to facilitate communication and transport of materials between plant cells.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cytoskeleton

input.question: Cytoskeleton is made up of:

response.explanation: The cytoskeleton is made up of three kinds of protein filaments: actin filaments (also called microfilaments), intermediate filaments and microtubules whose major constituents are actin and tubulin respectively.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Chloroplasts

input.question: Stroma in the chloroplasts of higher plant contains:

response.explanation: Stroma in the chloroplasts of higher plant contains light independent reaction enzymes. Within the stroma are stacks of thylakoids, the suborganelles which are the site of photosynthesis.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Wall

input.question: Middle lamella is composed mainly of:

response.explanation: Middle lamella is mainly composed of calcium pectate. Calcium is deposited in plants cell walls during their formation - it is required for the stability and function of cell membranes and acts as a type of 'cementing agent' in the cell walls.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Membrane

input.question: Keeping in view the fluid mosaic model for the structure of cell membrane, which one of the following statements is correct with respect to the movement of lipids and proteins from one lipid monolayer to the other (described as flip-flop movement)?

options.a: Both lipids and proteins can flip-flop
options.b: While lipids can rarely flip-flop, protein can not
options.c: While proteins can flip-flop, lipids can not
options.d: Neither lipids, nor proteins can flip-flop

response.explanation: Keeping in view of the 'Fluid mosaic model' for the structure of cell membrane, the movement of lipids and proteins from one lipid monolayer to the other, lipid can rarely flip-flop, protein can not.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Wall

input.question: Cellulose is the major component of cell walls of

response.explanation: Cellulose is a major component of cell wall of Pythium. Pythium is a genus of parasitic Oomycete.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Ribosomes

input.question: The two sub-units of ribosome remain united at a critical ion level of

response.explanation: The two subunits of ribosome remain united at a critical ion level of magnesium. The presence of magnesium and its amount plays an important role in the appearance and structure of the ribosomes.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Vacuoles

input.question: Vacuole in a plant cell

options.a: is membrane-bound and contains storage proteins and lipids
options.b: is membrane-bound and contains water and excretory substances
options.d: lacks membrane and contains water and excretory substances

response.explanation: Vacuole in a plant cell is membrane bound and contains water and excretory substance. Vacuole is a space within the cytoplasm of living cell that is filled with air, water or other liquid, cell sap or food particles.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Select the wrong statement from the following

options.a: Both chloroplasts and mitochondria have an internal compartment, the thylakoid space bounded by the thylakoid membrane
options.b: Both chloroplasts and mitochondria contain DNA
options.c: The chloroplasts are generally much larger than mitochondria
options.d: Both chloroplasts and mitochondria contain an inner and an outer membrane

response.explanation: Both chloroplasts and mitochondria have an internal compartment, but in mitochondria it's the matrix and in chloroplasts it's the stroma. Thylakoid space is specific to chloroplasts only.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Membrane

input.question: Which one of the following is not a constituent of cell membrane?

response.explanation: Proline (symbol Pro or P) is a proteinogenic amino acid that is used in the biosynthesis of proteins. It is not a constituent of cell membrane.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Mitochondria

input.question: Which of the following statement regarding mitochondrial membrane is not correct?

options.a: The enzymes of the electron transfer chain are embedded in the outer membrane
options.b: The inner membrane is highly convoluted forming a series of infoldings
options.c: The outer membrane resembles a sieve
options.d: The outer membrane is permeable to all kinds of molecules

response.explanation: The enzymes of electron transport system are present in inner mitochondrial membrane, not the outer membrane.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Protein Transport

input.question: The main organelle involved in modification and routing of newly synthesized proteins to their destinations is

response.explanation: Endoplasmic reticulum transport proteins and enzymes to their destinations i.e. within the cell and outside the cell.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Membrane

input.question: According to widely accepted 'fluid mosaic model' cell membranes are semi-fluid, where lipids and integral proteins can diffuse randomly. In recent years, this model has been modified in several respects. In this regard, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.a: Proteins in cell membranes can travel within the lipid bilayer
options.b: Proteins can also undergo flip-flop movements in the lipid bilayer
options.c: Proteins can remain confined within certain domains of the membrane
options.d: Many proteins remain completely embedded within the lipid bilayer

response.explanation: Flip-Flop movement is due to migration of lipid molecules from one lipid monolayer to other monolayer of lipid bilayer. Proteins cannot undergo flip-flop movements.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Chromosomes

input.question: Centromere is required for:

response.explanation: During anaphase APC (anaphase promoting complex) develops. It degenerates proteins binding the two chromatids in the region of centromere. As a result, the centromere of each chromosome divides. This converts the two chromatids into daughter chromosomes.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Protein Synthesis

input.question: Protein synthesis in an animal cell occurs

options.a: only on the ribosomes present in cytosol
options.b: only on ribosomes attached to the nuclear envelope and endoplasmic reticulum
options.c: on ribosomes present in the nucleolus as well as in cytoplasm
options.d: on ribosomes present in cytoplasm as well as in mitochondria

response.explanation: Protein synthesis in an animal cell occurs on ribosomes present in cytoplasm as well as in mitochondria because mitochondria and chloroplast also have their own DNA, RNA and ribosome so can synthesize half of their required proteins.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Flagella

input.question: Flagella of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells differ in

options.a: type of movement and placement in cell
options.b: location in cell and mode of functioning
options.c: microtubular organization and type of movement

response.explanation: Prokaryotes have simple flagella without microtubules whereas eukaryotes have complex cilia and flagella which consists of microtubules arranged in 9+2 fashion (an outer ring of nine pairs surrounding 1 center pair).

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Chloroplasts

input.question: In chloroplasts, chlorophyll is present in the

response.explanation: The thylakoid membranes possess the chlorophylls. The outer membrane is permeable to a number of solutes. Inner membrane has a number of carrier proteins. Stroma forms the matrix containing the enzyme for Calvin cycle.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Membrane

input.question: In fluid mosaic model of plasma membrane

options.a: upper layer is non-polar and hydrophilic
options.b: upper layer is polar and hydrophobic
options.c: phospholipids form a bimolecular layer in middle part

response.explanation: Fluid mosaic model of plasma membrane proposes that plasma membrane comprises of a phospholipid bilayer wherein icebergs of proteins float in the sea of phospholipids.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Chromosomes

input.question: Which of the following occurs more than one and less than five in a chromosome?

response.explanation: A chromatid is one of two identical strands of DNA making up a chromosome that are joined at their centromeres, for the process of nuclear division (mitosis or meiosis). The term is used till the centromeres remain in contact.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Ribosomes

input.question: Ribosomes are produced in

response.explanation: Ribosomes are produced in nucleolus. Golgi bodies take part in elaboration and secretion of complex biochemicals. Mitochondria are the site of ATP synthesis.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cytoskeleton

input.question: Mitotic spindle is mainly composed of which protein?

response.explanation: Mitotic spindles are composed of microtubules which are made of tubulin dimers. Actin and myosin are the contractile proteins of muscle fibres. Myoglobin is oxygen carrying pigment found in muscle.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cytoskeleton

input.question: Microtubules absent in

response.explanation: Microtubules are formed of dimers of tubulin. Microtubules are present in centriole, flagella, spindle fibres but not in mitochondria.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Wall

input.question: Element necessary for middle lamella is

response.explanation: Zinc is an activator of enzymes like carbonic anhydrase. Copper takes part in electron transport as plastocyanin. Potassium maintains membrane permeability. Calcium is essential for middle lamella formation.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Protein Modification

input.question: The cell organelle involved in glycosylation of protein is

response.explanation: Glycosylation is the process or result of addition of saccharides to proteins and lipids. The majority of proteins synthesized in the rough ER undergo glycosylation.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Lysosomes

input.question: Lysosomes have a high content of

response.explanation: Lysosomes are single membrane bound vesicular organelles rich in acid hydrolases. They are involved in phagocytosis.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Some of the enzymes, which are associated in converting fats into carbohydrates, are present in

response.explanation: Golgi bodies are cytoplasmic organelle which take part in elaboration and secretion of complex biochemicals. Microsomes are small single membraned cell organelles that absorb oxygen and perform direct oxidation of substrates. Glyoxysomes contain enzymes for β-oxidation of fatty acids.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Organelles

input.question: Which of the following organ has single membrane?

response.explanation: Nucleus is enclosed by a double layered envelope. Sphaerosomes are small spherical single membrane bound cell organelles specialized to synthesize and store fat. Mitochondria is also surrounded by a two layered membrane.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Protein Synthesis

input.question: The proteins are synthesised at

response.explanation: Ribosomes are the sites of protein synthesis. Mitochondria is the site of ATP synthesis. Golgi complex takes part in elaboration and secretion of complex biochemicals.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Mitochondrial DNA

input.question: Genes located on mitochondrial DNA

options.b: are always inherited from the male parent
options.c: show biparental inheritance like the nuclear genes

response.explanation: Genes located on the mitochondrial DNA are inherited through the cytoplasm. The zygote receives cytoplasm from the female gamete, hence it involves maternal inheritance.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Endoplasmic Reticulum

input.question: The function of rough endoplasmic reticulum is

response.explanation: Rough endoplasmic reticulum bears ribosomes on its outer surface. These ribosomes take part in protein synthesis.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Chromosomes

input.question: The point, at which polytene chromosomes appears to be attached together, is called

response.explanation: Granules of condensed chromatin (heterochromatin), are found scattered in interphase nuclei. At chromocentre, the polytene chromosomes appear attached.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Junctions

input.question: The desmosomes are concerned with

response.explanation: Desmosomes are cementing substances, which adhere to each other and keep the latter tightly packed and they also prevent leakage of fluid from interphase.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Mitochondria

input.question: Inner membrane convolutions of a mitochondrion are known as

response.explanation: The inner membrane of mitochondria is infolded to form involutions called cristae. They are meant for increasing the active area of the inner membrane.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Mitochondria

input.question: Mitochondrial cristae are sites of

response.explanation: Mitochondrial cristae possess small particles called elementary particles which contain ATP-ase. Therefore, they are the centers of ATP synthesis during oxidative phosphorylation.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Golgi Apparatus

input.question: Organelle having flattened membrane bound cisternae and lying near the nucleus is

response.explanation: Organelle that has flattened membrane bound cisternae and lies near the nucleus is Golgi apparatus.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Lysosomes

input.question: Membranous bag with hydrolytic enzymes which is used for controlling intracellular digestion of macro-molecules is

response.explanation: Lysosomes are membranous bag with hydrolytic enzymes used for controlling intracellular digestion of macro-molecules.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Chromosomes

input.question: In salivary gland chromosomes/polytene chromosomes, pairing is

response.explanation: In salivary gland chromosomes / polytene chromosomes, somatic pairing is formed between homologous chromosomes and repeated replication of their chromonemata.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Recognition

input.question: Cell recognition and adhesion occur due to biochemicals of cell membranes named

response.explanation: Cell recognition and adhesion occurs due to biochemicals named glycoproteins and glycolipids of cell membranes. These are formed due to the small carbohydrate molecules present on lipids and extrinsic protein.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Peroxisomes

input.question: In plant cells, peroxisomes are associated with

response.explanation: In plant peroxisomes are associated with photorespiration. Peroxisomes are ubiquitous organelles in eukaryotes that function to rid the cell of toxic substances.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Chromosomes

input.question: Balbiani rings (puffs) are sites of

response.explanation: In the region of Balbiani ring the DNA strands uncoil, become active and produce number of copies of messenger RNA.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Ribosomes

input.question: Ribosomes are the centre for

response.explanation: Ribosomes are the workhouses of protein biosynthesis, the process of translating messenger RNA (mRNA) into protein.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Mitochondria

input.question: Oxysomes of F0-F1 particles occur on

response.explanation: The inner membrane of mitochondria possess small tennis racket like particles called elementary particle, F0-F1 particles or oxysomes.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Plastids

input.question: All plastids have similar structure because they can

options.b: get transformed from one type to another

response.explanation: All plastids are similar in structure. So they can easily get transformed from one type to another. Depending upon the colours there are three types of plastids- leucoplasts, chromoplasts and chloroplasts.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Nucleolus

input.question: An outer covering membrane is absent over

response.explanation: A covering membrane is absent around nucleolus. Calcium seems to be essential for maintaining its configuration.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Golgi Apparatus

input.question: Which one is apparato reticolare?

response.explanation: Apparato reticolare interno means 'internal reticular apparatus'. Camillo Golgi referred the Golgi apparatus as 'apparato reticolare' after observing the cellular organelle under the microscope.

topic: Cell: The Unit of Life - Cell Membrane

input.question: Fluid mosaic model of cell membrane was put forward by

response.explanation: Fluid Mosaic Model of cell membrane was put forward by Singer and Nicolson.

input.question: Identify the substances having glycosidic bond and peptide bond, respectively in their structure

response.explanation: Inulin is a mixture of linear fructose polymers with different chain length and a glucose molecule at each C2 end. Adjacent fructose units are linked through glycosidic bond. Insulin is a protein composed of 51 amino acids and acts as a hormone which is secreted by beta-cells of pancreas. Adjacent amino acids are attached through peptide bond.

input.question: The two functional groups characteristic of sugars are

response.explanation: Sugar is a carbohydrate. These are polyhydroxy aldehyde, ketone or their derivatives, which means they have carbonyl and hydroxyl groups in its structure.

input.question: About 98 percent of the mass of every living organism is composed of just six elements including carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen and

response.explanation: Calcium and phosphorus are the remaining elements that complete the six major elements constituting about 98% of the mass of every living organism along with carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and oxygen.

input.question: Enzymes, vitamins and hormones can be classified into a single category of biological chemicals, because all of these

options.b: are exclusively synthesized in the body of a living organism as at present

response.explanation: The major life processes are controlled by enzymes as they enhance the rate of biological reactions. Vitamins are required in limited amounts by organisms for regulation of metabolism and growth. Hormones are organic compounds produced by certain organs in small quantities. They act physiologically far from their site of origin.

input.question: Carbohydrates, the most abundant bio-molecules on earth, are produced by :

options.a: some bacteria, algae and green plant cells
options.b: fungi, algae and green plant cells

response.explanation: Some bacteria (such as Rhodopseudomonas), algae and green plants cell produce carbohydrates through photosynthesis and other metabolic processes.

input.question: Most abundant organic compound on earth is

response.explanation: Cellulose is the most abundant organic compound, polysaccharide and biopolymer found on earth. It forms the structural component of plant cell walls.

input.question: Most diverse macromolecules, found in the cell both physically and chemically are

response.explanation: Proteins are polymers of amino acids. There are only 20 amino acids which can be arranged in different orders in a polypeptide chain to form a wide array of proteins with diverse structures and functions.

input.question: The four elements making 99% of living system are

response.explanation: Principal or major elements include oxygen, carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen. They are so named because they alone constitute 99% of living system.

input.question: Living cell contains 60 – 75% water. Water present in human body is

response.explanation: Water is the most abundant compound in the most majority of cells. About 65-70% of human body is water. Major portion of water found in human body occurs in the cells as intracellular water.

input.question: "Ramachandran plot" is used to confirm the structure of

response.explanation: A Ramachandran plot is a way to visualise energetically allowed regions for backbone dihedral angles ψ against φ of amino acid residues to protein structure. It is used to analyse the structure of a protein, the conformation of the amino acids present in the protein and close contacts between the atoms.

input.question: The two polypeptides of human insulin are linked together by

response.explanation: The two polypeptides of human insulin are linked together by disulphide bridges between cysteine residues, forming the active insulin molecule.

input.question: The amino acid Tryptophan is the precursor for the synthesis of

response.explanation: Tryptophan is a precursor to neurotransmitters serotonin and melatonin. Thyroxine is produced by follicular cells of the thyroid gland. Estrogen is biosynthesized from progesterone. Cortisone and cortisol are steroid hormones produced in the adrenal cortex.

input.question: The figure shows a hypothetical tetrapeptide portion of a protein with parts labelled A-D. Which one of the following option is correct?

options.a: A is the sulphur containing amino acid - methionine
options.b: D is the acidic amino acid - glutamic acid
options.c: C is an aromatic amino acid - tryptophan
options.d: A is the C - terminal amino acid and D is N terminal amino acid

response.explanation: Glutamic acid and aspartic acid are acidic amino acids with two carboxylic groups and one amino group. In the tetrapeptide structure shown, position D corresponds to glutamic acid which is an acidic amino acid.

input.question: Which one is the most abundant protein in the animal world

response.explanation: Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal world. Rubisco (ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase-oxygenase) is not only the most abundant protein in plants but also in the whole biosphere.

input.question: Which one out of A-D given below correctly represents the structural formula of the basic amino acid

response.explanation: Option D represents the structural formula of basic amino acid lysine. Lysine is an α-amino acid that contains an α-amino group, an α-carboxylic acid group, and a side chain lysyl, classifying it as a basic, charged, aliphatic amino acid.

input.question: Which one of the following biomolecules is correctly characterized?

options.a: Lecithin - A phosphorylated glyceride found in cell membrane.
options.b: Palmitic acid - An unsaturated fatty acid with 18 carbon atoms.
options.c: Adenylic acid - Adenosine with a glucose phosphate molecule.
options.d: Alanine amino acid - Contains an amino group and an acidic group anywhere in the molecule.

response.explanation: Lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) is a phosphorylated glyceride found in cell membranes. Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid with 16 carbons. Adenylic acid is a nucleotide consisting of adenine, ribose or deoxyribose, and a phosphate group. Amino acids have amino and carboxylic groups attached to the same carbon atom.

input.question: Which of the following is the simplest amino acid?

response.explanation: The general structure of an amino acid is NH₂-CHR-COOH where R is an alkyl or aryl group. In Glycine, R is a hydrogen atom, making it the simplest amino acid with no side chain beyond the hydrogen atom.

input.question: Collagen is

response.explanation: Collagen is a major fibrous protein of connective tissue occurring as white fibres produced by fibroblast. It provides structural support to various tissues in the body.

input.question: Conjugated proteins containing carbohydrates as prosthetic group are known as

response.explanation: Besides polypeptides, conjugated proteins possess additional groups, metals or ions. Glycoproteins are proteins with a simple or complex sugar residue at their N-terminal. Nucleoproteins are proteins associated with nucleic acids, lipoproteins with lipids, and chromoproteins with pigments.

input.question: Which is an essential amino acid?

response.explanation: Essential amino acids are those which cannot be synthesized in the body from precursors. These amino acids must be present in our diet. They are valine, leucine, isoleucine, lysine, methionine, phenylalanine, tryptophan and threonine.

input.question: The secondary structure of that portion of an integral protein that is buried in the lipid bilayer of a cell membrane is

response.explanation: Secondary structure is development of new steric relationships amongst the amino acids through formation of intra and inter polypeptide hydrogen bonds. The α-helix structure is commonly found in transmembrane proteins as it allows hydrophobic side chains to interact with the lipid bilayer.

input.question: The enormous diversity of protein molecules is due mainly to the diversity of

options.a: amino groups on the amino acids
options.b: R groups on the amino acids
options.c: amino acid sequences within the protein molecule

response.explanation: There are only 20 amino acids. These can be arranged in different order in the polypeptide chain to form a diverse array of proteins. The sequence of amino acids determines the protein's structure and function.

input.question: Genes are packed into a bacterial chromosome by

response.explanation: In bacteria the chromosome or nucleoid is a naked double stranded DNA. The bacterial DNA is folded with the help of RNAs forming a super coiled circular complex. The coiling is stabilized with the help of non-histonic polyamines and a number of positively charged ions. Eukaryotic DNA is associated with histone proteins.

input.question: Protein synthesis in an animal cell takes place

options.b: in the nucleolus as well as in cytoplasm
options.c: in cytoplasm as well as in mitochondria
options.d: only on ribosomes attached to the nuclear envelope

response.explanation: In the cytoplasm protein synthesis is restricted to the ribosomes. Mitochondria being a semiautonomous organelle, has its own genetic machinery to synthesize its proteins using mitochondrial ribosomes.

input.question: Amino acids are produced from

response.explanation: An amino acid molecule consists of a central carbon bonded to an amino group (−NH₂), a carboxylic group (−COOH), a hydrogen atom and a carbon chain or ring on its sides. Amino acids can be synthesized from α-keto acids through transamination reactions.

input.question: Which one of the following is the most abundant protein in the animals?

response.explanation: Collagen is the most abundant protein in animal world. Collagen is the major insoluble fibrous protein found in the extracellular matrix and in connective tissue. RuBisCO is the most abundant protein in the whole of the Biosphere.

input.question: Which of the following organic compounds is the main constituent of lecithin?

response.explanation: Lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) a naturally occurring fatty substance referred to as phospholipid. It is important in cell structure and metabolism as a component of cell membranes.

input.question: Concanavalin A is:

response.explanation: Concanavalin A is a secondary metabolite, e.g. lectin. Lectin is a mannose/glucose-binding protein isolated from Jack beans (Canavalia ensiformis). They are not antibodies and do not originate in an immune system but bind specifically to carbohydrate-containing receptors on cell surfaces.

input.question: A typical fat molecule is made up of

options.a: three glycerol molecules and one fatty acid molecule
options.b: one glycerol and three fatty acid molecules
options.c: one glycerol and one fatty acid molecule
options.d: three glycerol and three fatty acid molecules

response.explanation: Fat molecules are made of atoms of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen. A typical fat molecule has one glycerol and three fatty acid molecules, forming a triglyceride through ester linkages.

input.question: A phosphoglyceride is always made up of:

options.a: only an unsaturated fatty acid esterified to a glycerol molecule to which a phosphate group is also attached
options.b: a saturated or unsaturated fatty acid esterified to a glycerol molecule to which a phosphate group is also attached
options.c: a saturated or unsaturated fatty acid esterified to a phosphate group which is also attached to a glycerol molecule.
options.d: only a saturated fatty acid esterified to a glycerol molecule to which a phosphate group is also attached

response.explanation: A saturated or unsaturated fatty acid esterified to a glycerol molecule to which a phosphate group is also attached forms phosphoglycerides. Phosphoglycerides are major structural components of cell membranes and are therefore called membrane lipids.

input.question: Lipids are insoluble in water because lipid molecules are

response.explanation: Water attracting molecules are called hydrophilic. Water repelling molecules are called hydrophobic. Lipids are compounds of C, H, O but the ratio of H and O is more than 2:1. Lipids are insoluble in water but soluble in non-polar solvents such as benzene, chloroform etc.

input.question: Spoilage of oil can be detected by which fatty acid?

response.explanation: Erucic acid is a monounsaturated omega-9 fatty acid, denoted 22:1 ω-9. It is prevalent in rapeseed, wallflower seed, and mustard seed, making up 40 to 50 percent of their oils. The presence of erucic acid can indicate spoilage or poor quality of oils.

input.question: Purines found both in DNA and RNA are:

response.explanation: Purines, a heterocyclic compound, such as adenine and guanine are found both in DNA and RNA. Thymine is found only in DNA, while uracil is found only in RNA.

input.question: Given below is the diagrammatic representation of one of the categories of small molecular weight organic compounds in the living tissues. Identify the category shown and the one blank component 'X' in it.

response.explanation: A combination of a nitrogen base with a pentose sugar is known as nucleoside. The nitrogen base combines with the sugar molecule at its 1' carbon atom in a glycosidic bond. Depending upon the type of pentose sugar, nucleosides are differentiated into ribonucleosides and deoxyribonucleosides.

input.question: Which one of the following structural formulae of two organic compounds is correctly identified along with its related function?

options.a: B : Adenine — a nucleotide that makes up nucleic acids
options.b: A: Triglyceride — major source of energy
options.c: B : Uracil — a component of DNA
options.d: A: Lecithin — a component of cell membrane

response.explanation: Lecithin is a fat like substance (a phospholipid), which is a part of plasma membrane. Structure A represents lecithin which is a phospholipid component of cell membranes.

input.question: Length of one turn of the helix in a β-form DNA is approximately

response.explanation: Length of one turn of DNA helix is 34Å. 1Å = 10⁻¹ nm, therefore 34Å = 3.4 nm. This represents the distance for one complete turn of the DNA double helix in B-form.

input.question: Which one of the following hydrolyses internal phosphodiester bonds in a polynucleotide chain?

response.explanation: Endonucleases hydrolyse internal phosphodiester bonds in a polynucleotide chain (DNA). While exonucleases hydrolyse terminal phosphodiester bonds in a polynucleotide chain (DNA). Lipases break down lipids, proteases break down proteins.

input.question: Antiparallel strands of a DNA molecule means that

options.a: the phosphate groups of two DNA strands, at their ends, share the same position
options.b: the phosphate groups at the start of two DNA strands are in opposite position (pole)

response.explanation: Antiparallel strands of DNA have two strands having phosphate groups at same positions in space. The antiparallel structure of DNA is important in DNA replication because it replicates the leading strand one way and the lagging strand the other way.

input.question: A nucleotide is formed of

response.explanation: The nucleic acid (DNA and RNA) are repeating units of nucleotides i.e. polynucleotides. Each nucleotide comprises of nitrogenous heterocyclic bases viz. purines or pyrimidines, pentose sugar and phosphoric acid.

input.question: One of the similarities between DNA and RNA is that both

response.explanation: DNA and RNA are both polymers of nucleotides. DNA has deoxyribose sugar while RNA has ribose sugar. DNA has thymine while RNA has uracil in place of thymine. Only DNA is capable of self-replication in living systems.

input.question: DNA synthesis can be specifically measured by estimating the incorporation of radio labelled

response.explanation: Thymidine is used to assess the rate of DNA synthesis, since thymine is unique to DNA (not found in RNA). The incorporation of radioactive thymidine into newly synthesized DNA can be measured to quantify DNA replication rates.

input.question: The nitrogenous organic base purine occuring in RNA is

response.explanation: Purines are adenine and guanine, found in both DNA and RNA. Pyrimidines are cytosine (in both DNA and RNA), thymine (only in DNA) and uracil (only in RNA).

input.question: In DNA, when the total amount of adenine and thymine is 60%, the amount of guanine shall be

response.explanation: According to Chargaff's rule, in DNA, A = T and G = C. If A + T = 60%, then G + C = 40%. Since G = C, each would be 20%.

input.question: Which one of the following is a chain growth polymer?

response.explanation: Chain growth polymers are formed by the repeated addition of monomer units to the growing chain. Polystyrene is formed by chain growth polymerization of styrene monomers. Nucleic acids, proteins, and starch are step-growth polymers formed by condensation reactions.

input.question: In DNA, the complementary bases are

options.a: uracil and adenine; cytosine and guanine
options.b: adenine and thymine; guanine and cytosine
options.c: adenine and thymine; guanine and uracil
options.d: adenine and guanine; thymine and cytosine

response.explanation: In DNA, adenine pairs with thymine via two hydrogen bonds, and guanine pairs with cytosine via three hydrogen bonds. This complementary base pairing is fundamental to DNA structure and function.

input.question: Which of the following is not a polysaccharide?

response.explanation: Lactose is a disaccharide composed of glucose and galactose. Starch, cellulose, and glycogen are all polysaccharides made up of repeating glucose units.

input.question: Which of the following is the storage form of glucose in animals?

response.explanation: Glycogen is the storage polysaccharide of glucose in animals, primarily stored in the liver and muscles. Starch is the storage form in plants, cellulose is a structural polysaccharide in plants, and inulin is a storage polysaccharide in some plants.

input.question: Which of the following is a reducing sugar?

response.explanation: Lactose is a reducing sugar because it has a free aldehyde group that can reduce certain chemicals. Sucrose is non-reducing because both anomeric carbons are involved in the glycosidic bond. Trehalose is also non-reducing, and starch is a polysaccharide that doesn't exhibit reducing properties.

input.question: The most abundant carbohydrate found in nature is:

response.explanation: Cellulose is the most abundant carbohydrate and organic compound on Earth. It forms the structural framework of plant cell walls and is produced in enormous quantities by photosynthetic organisms.

input.question: Which of the following is not a carbohydrate?

response.explanation: Glycerol is a trihydric alcohol (triol) and is a component of lipids, not carbohydrates. Fructose is a monosaccharide, ribose is a pentose sugar, and sucrose is a disaccharide - all are carbohydrates.

input.question: The sugar present in milk is:

response.explanation: Lactose, also known as milk sugar, is a disaccharide composed of glucose and galactose. It is the primary carbohydrate found in mammalian milk.

input.question: Which of the following is an example of heteropolysaccharide?

response.explanation: Hyaluronic acid is a heteropolysaccharide composed of repeating units of D-glucuronic acid and N-acetyl-D-glucosamine. Cellulose, glycogen, and starch are homopolysaccharides as they contain only glucose units.

input.question: The carbohydrate that cannot be hydrolyzed is called:

response.explanation: Monosaccharides are the simplest carbohydrates that cannot be hydrolyzed into smaller carbohydrate units. Disaccharides, oligosaccharides, and polysaccharides can all be hydrolyzed into smaller sugar units.

input.question: Which of the following is a ketohexose?

response.explanation: Fructose is a ketohexose because it has a ketone functional group and contains six carbon atoms. Glucose and galactose are aldohexoses (aldehyde group), and ribose is an aldopentose (five carbons).

input.question: The sweetest natural sugar is:

response.explanation: Fructose is the sweetest natural sugar, approximately 1.7 times sweeter than sucrose. Glucose is less sweet than sucrose, and maltose is the least sweet among common sugars.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is used as storage molecule in animals is:

response.explanation: Glycogen is the storage polysaccharide in animals, primarily stored in the liver and muscles. Starch is the storage polysaccharide in plants, cellulose is a structural polysaccharide, and inulin is a storage polysaccharide in some plants like dahlias.

input.question: Which of the following is not a disaccharide?

response.explanation: Galactose is a monosaccharide (hexose sugar). Maltose, lactose, and sucrose are all disaccharides composed of two monosaccharide units each.

input.question: The carbohydrate that forms the exoskeleton of arthropods is:

response.explanation: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide that forms the exoskeleton of arthropods (insects, crustaceans) and cell walls of fungi. It is composed of N-acetylglucosamine units.

input.question: Which of the following is a non-reducing sugar?

response.explanation: Sucrose is a non-reducing sugar because both anomeric carbons (C1 of glucose and C2 of fructose) are involved in the glycosidic bond, leaving no free aldehyde or ketone group to act as a reducing agent.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is present in DNA is:

response.explanation: Deoxyribose is the pentose sugar present in DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Ribose is found in RNA, while glucose and fructose are hexose sugars not typically found in nucleic acids.

input.question: Which of the following carbohydrates is a trisaccharide?

response.explanation: Raffinose is a trisaccharide composed of galactose, glucose, and fructose. Maltose and lactose are disaccharides, and sucrose is also a disaccharide.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is used in the preparation of jellies is:

response.explanation: Pectin is a heteropolysaccharide found in plant cell walls that forms gels when combined with sugar and acid, making it ideal for jelly preparation. Starch is used for thickening, cellulose for structural support, and glycogen for energy storage.

input.question: Which of the following is a storage polysaccharide in plants?

response.explanation: Starch is the main storage polysaccharide in plants, stored in seeds, tubers, and other plant parts. Cellulose is a structural polysaccharide, chitin forms exoskeletons, and glycogen is the storage polysaccharide in animals.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is also known as fruit sugar is:

response.explanation: Fructose is commonly known as fruit sugar because it is the main sugar found in many fruits and is responsible for their sweet taste. Glucose is blood sugar, galactose is milk sugar component, and sucrose is table sugar.

input.question: Which of the following is not a polysaccharide?

response.explanation: Raffinose is a trisaccharide (composed of three monosaccharide units), not a polysaccharide. Agar, dextrin, and inulin are all polysaccharides with many repeating sugar units.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is present in the cell walls of fungi is:

response.explanation: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide that forms the cell walls of fungi, as well as the exoskeletons of arthropods. Cellulose is found in plant cell walls, starch and glycogen are storage polysaccharides.

input.question: Which of the following carbohydrates is a pentose?

response.explanation: Ribose is a pentose sugar with 5 carbon atoms. Glucose, fructose, and galactose are all hexose sugars with 6 carbon atoms each.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is used as an anticoagulant is:

response.explanation: Heparin is a glycosaminoglycan (a type of carbohydrate) that acts as a natural anticoagulant by preventing blood clotting. It is commonly used in medical settings to prevent thrombosis.

input.question: Which of the following is a homopolysaccharide?

response.explanation: Glycogen is a homopolysaccharide composed only of glucose units. Hyaluronic acid, heparin, and chondroitin sulfate are all heteropolysaccharides composed of different types of sugar units.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is also known as dextrose is:

response.explanation: Glucose is also known as dextrose because it rotates plane-polarized light to the right (dextrorotatory). It is the primary blood sugar and a key energy source for cells.

input.question: Which of the following is a structural polysaccharide?

response.explanation: Cellulose is a structural polysaccharide that forms the primary component of plant cell walls. Starch, glycogen, and inulin are all storage polysaccharides used for energy storage.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is present in honey is:

response.explanation: Honey primarily contains a mixture of fructose and glucose, along with small amounts of other sugars. The high fructose content contributes to honey's sweetness and its liquid consistency.

input.question: Which of the following is not a carbohydrate?

response.explanation: Glycerol is a trihydric alcohol (C3H8O3) and is not classified as a carbohydrate. Glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone are trioses (3-carbon sugars), and erythrose is a tetrose (4-carbon sugar) - all are carbohydrates.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is used in the production of beer is:

response.explanation: Maltose, derived from the hydrolysis of starch in barley, is the primary sugar fermented by yeast in beer production. The malting process converts starch to maltose, which is then fermented to produce alcohol.

input.question: Which of the following carbohydrates is a non-reducing sugar?

response.explanation: Trehalose is a non-reducing disaccharide because both glucose units are linked through their anomeric carbons, leaving no free aldehyde group. Maltose, lactose, and cellobiose all have free anomeric carbons and are reducing sugars.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is used as a plasma expander is:

response.explanation: Dextran is a polysaccharide produced by bacteria that is used as a plasma expander in medical treatments to increase blood volume. It helps maintain blood pressure in cases of shock or severe blood loss.

input.question: Which of the following is an example of an aldose sugar?

response.explanation: Glucose is an aldose sugar because it contains an aldehyde functional group. Fructose and ribulose are ketose sugars (contain ketone groups), and dihydroxyacetone is the simplest ketose sugar.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is also known as animal starch is:

response.explanation: Glycogen is often called 'animal starch' because it serves the same energy storage function in animals that starch serves in plants. Both are polymers of glucose, but glycogen is more highly branched than starch.

input.question: Which of the following is a carbohydrate with β-1,4 glycosidic linkages?

response.explanation: Cellulose is composed of glucose units linked by β-1,4 glycosidic bonds. Starch, glycogen, and amylopectin all contain α-1,4 glycosidic linkages in their main chains, with additional α-1,6 linkages at branch points.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is used in the preparation of agar plates for microbial culture is:

response.explanation: Agarose, derived from red algae, is used to prepare solid culture media for microbiology. It forms a gel that provides a stable surface for microbial growth while allowing nutrient diffusion.

input.question: Which of the following carbohydrates is a component of RNA?

response.explanation: Ribose is the pentose sugar that forms the backbone of RNA (ribonucleic acid). Deoxyribose is found in DNA, while glucose and fructose are hexose sugars not typically found in nucleic acids.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is used as a sweetener in diabetic foods is:

response.explanation: Fructose is often used as a sweetener in diabetic foods because it has a lower glycemic index than glucose or sucrose. It provides sweetness without causing rapid spikes in blood sugar levels.

input.question: Which of the following is a carbohydrate with α-1,6 glycosidic linkages?

response.explanation: Glycogen contains α-1,6 glycosidic linkages at its branch points, in addition to the α-1,4 linkages in its main chains. Amylose has only α-1,4 linkages, cellulose has β-1,4 linkages, and chitin has β-1,4 linkages between N-acetylglucosamine units.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is used in the production of rayon is:

response.explanation: Cellulose is used to produce rayon through chemical processing that converts cellulose into a soluble compound, which is then extruded to form fibers. Rayon is sometimes called 'artificial silk' due to its properties.

input.question: Which of the following carbohydrates is a reducing disaccharide?

response.explanation: Lactose is a reducing disaccharide because it has a free anomeric carbon on the glucose unit that can reduce certain chemicals. Sucrose and trehalose are non-reducing disaccharides, and raffinose is a trisaccharide.

input.question: The carbohydrate that is used as a storage molecule in brown algae is:

response.explanation: Laminarin is a storage polysaccharide found in brown algae, composed mainly of glucose units with some mannitol. Starch is stored in green plants, glycogen in animals, and inulin in some plants like dahlias.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: Some dividing cells exit the cell cycle and enter vegetative inactive stage. This is called quiescent stage (G₀). This process occurs at the end of

response.explanation: Some dividing cells exit the cell cycle and enter vegetative inactive stage, called quiescent stage (G₀). This process occurs at the end of M-phase and beginning of G₁ phase.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: Identify the correct statement with regard to G₁ phase (Gap 1) of interphase.

options.a: Reorganisation of all cell components takes place.
options.b: Cell is metabolically active, grows but does not replicate its DNA.
options.d: DNA synthesis or replication takes place.

response.explanation: During G₁ phase the cell is metabolically active and continuously grows but does not replicate its DNA. DNA synthesis takes place in S phase. Nuclear division occurs during Karyokinesis.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: Cells in G₀ phase:

response.explanation: G₀ or resting phase is a non-growing state distinct from interphase. It is a period in the cell cycle in which cells exist in a quiescent state outside of the cell cycle.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: The correct sequence of phases of cell cycle is:

response.explanation: Cell cycle is the complete series of events from one cell division to the next. The correct sequence of phases of cell cycle is G₁ → S → G₂ → M.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: DNA replication in bacteria occurs:

response.explanation: In bacteria DNA replication occurs in cytoplasm prior to fission. Prokaryotes due to their primitive nature do not show well marked S-phase.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: A somatic cell that has just completed the S phase of its cell cycle, as compared to gamete of the same species, has:

options.a: same number of chromosomes but twice the amount of DNA
options.b: twice the number of chromosomes and four times the amount of DNA
options.c: four times the number of chromosomes and twice the amount of DNA
options.d: twice the number of chromosomes and twice the amount of DNA

response.explanation: When S-phase completes, a somatic cell contains 2n number of chromosomes and 4C content of DNA. Gamete has n chromosomes and 1C DNA content.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: During which phase(s) of cell cycle, amount of DNA in a cell remains at 4C level if the initial amount is denoted as 2C?

response.explanation: In M-phase both 4C and 2C of DNA are present in different stages. Only G₂ phase maintains 4C DNA content consistently.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: In 'S' phase of the cell cycle:

options.a: Amount of DNA doubles in each cell.
options.b: Amount of DNA remains same in each cell.
options.d: Amount of DNA is reduced to half in each cell.

response.explanation: During S or synthesis phase, replication or duplication of chromosomal DNA and synthesis of histone proteins takes place. During this time the amount of DNA per cell doubles.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: Given below is a schematic break-up of the phases / stages of cell cycle. Which one of the following is the correct indication of the stage/phase in the cell cycle?

response.explanation: In schematic break-up of the phases/stages of cell cycle, D synthetic phase is the correct indication of the stage/phase in the cell cycle.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: At what stage of the cell cycle are histone proteins synthesized in a eukaryotic cell?

response.explanation: Histone proteins are synthesized during S-phase of cell cycle. S-phase or synthetic phase is when synthesis of DNA takes place.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: In the somatic cell cycle

options.a: In G₁ phase DNA content is double the amount of DNA present in the original cell
options.b: DNA replication takes place in S-phase
options.c: a short interphase is followed by a long mitotic phase

response.explanation: DNA replication is restricted to S-phase of interphase. G₂ phase is followed by the mitotic phase which is shorter than the interphase.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: In cell cycle, DNA replication takes place in

response.explanation: G1 phase is characterized by increase in cell size. In the S phase or synthetic phase DNA molecules replicate. G2 is the second growth phase with intensive formation of RNAs and proteins.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Phases of cell cycle – Interphase

input.question: A bacterium divides every 35 minutes. If a culture containing 10⁵ cells per ml is grown for 175 minutes, what will be the cell concentration per ml after 175 minutes?

response.explanation: 175 min = 5 divisions (175/35). Number of cells formed = (2)⁵ × 10⁵ = 32 × 10⁵ cells per ml.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Which one of the following structures will not be common to mitotic cells of higher plants?

response.explanation: Plants cells do not have centrioles. Cell plate appears during cytokinesis in dividing cells. Centromere holds the sister chromatids in a chromosome. Spindle fibres appear during metaphase.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Match the following with respect to meiosis: (A) Zygotene, (B) Pachytene, (C) Diplotene, (D) Diakinesis

response.explanation: Zygotene → Synapsis, Pachytene → Crossing over, Diplotene → Chiasmata formation, Diakinesis → Terminalisation

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Dissolution of the synaptonemal complex occurs during

response.explanation: Dissolution of the synaptonemal complex occurs during diplotene stage of Prophase-I of Meiosis-I. The beginning of diplotene is recognized by the dissolution of the synaptonemal complex.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Which of the following options gives the correct sequence of events during mitosis?

options.a: Condensation → nuclear membrane disassembly → arrangement at equator → centromere division → segregation → telophase
options.b: Condensation → crossing over → nuclear membrane disassembly → segregation → telophase
options.c: Condensation → arrangement at equator → centromere division → segregation → telophase
options.d: Condensation → nuclear membrane disassembly → crossing over → segregation → telophase

response.explanation: The correct sequence: DNA condensation → nuclear membrane disassembly → chromosomes align at equator → centromere division → segregation → telophase.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Anaphase Promoting Complex (APC) is a protein degradation machinery necessary for proper mitosis of animal cells. If APC is defective in a human cell, which of the following is expected to occur?

options.c: Recombination of chromosome arms will occur

response.explanation: During anaphase, Anaphase Promoting Complex (APC) is necessary for separation of daughter chromosomes. A defective APC will cause the chromosomes fail to segregate during anaphase.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Spindle fibres attach on to

response.explanation: Attachment of microtubules to chromosomes is mediated by kinetochores, which actively monitor spindle formation and prevent premature anaphase onset during mitosis.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature during mitosis in somatic cells?

response.explanation: Synapsis is the pairing of two homologous chromosomes that occurs during meiosis. It allows matching-up of homologous pairs prior to their segregation, and occurs during prophase I of meiosis.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: A stage in cell division is shown in the figure. Select the answer which gives correct identification of the stage with its characteristics.

options.a: Late anaphase - Chromosomes move away from equatorial plate, Golgi complex not present
options.b: Cytokinesis - Cell plate formed, mitochondria distributed between two daughter cells
options.c: Telophase - Endoplasmic reticulum and nucleolus not reformed yet
options.d: Telophase - Nuclear envelop reforms, golgi complex reforms

response.explanation: Telophase is the stage of reconstitution of nuclei. Nuclear envelope assembles around chromatin mass. Nucleolus, Golgi complex and ER reform.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: The complex formed by a pair of synapsed homologous chromosomes is called

response.explanation: During zygotene, homologous chromosomes start pairing together forming synaptonemal complex. The complex formed by a pair of synapsed homologous chromosome is called a bivalent or a tetrad.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: During the metaphase stage of mitosis spindle fibres attach to chromosomes at

options.d: Centromere, kinetochore and areas adjoining centromere

response.explanation: Kinetochores are small disc-shaped structures at the surface of the centromeres which serve as the sites of attachment of spindle fibres to the chromosomes.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: A stage of mitosis is shown in the diagram. Which stage is it and what are its characteristics?

options.a: Late prophase – chromosomes move to spindle equator
options.b: Metaphase – spindle fibres attached to kinetochores, centromeres split and chromatids separate
options.c: Metaphase – chromosomes moved to spindle equator chromosomes made up of two sister chromatids
options.d: Anaphase – centromeres split and chromatids separate and start moving away

response.explanation: Metaphase chromosome is made up of two sister chromatids which are held together by the centromere. Chromosomes are moved to spindle equator and get aligned along metaphase plate.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Select the correct option with respect to mitosis.

options.a: Chromatids separate but remain in the centre of the cell in anaphase.
options.b: Chromatids start moving towards opposite poles in telophase.
options.c: Golgi complex and endoplasmic reticulum are still visible at the end of prophase.
options.d: Chromosomes move to the spindle equator and get aligned along equatorial plate in metaphase

response.explanation: In mitosis, chromosomes move to the equator and get aligned along equatorial plate in metaphase. Chromatids separate and move to poles in anaphase, not telophase.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: At metaphase, chromosomes are attached to the spindle fibres by their:

response.explanation: Kinetochores are large protein complexes that bind the centromeres of chromosomes to the microtubules of mitotic spindle fibres, during metaphase in the cell cycle.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: During mitosis ER and nucleolus begin to disappear at:

response.explanation: During mitosis, endoplasmic reticulum and nucleolus begin to disappear at early prophase. Also, nucleus and cell become spherical and DNA molecules condense to form shortened chromosome.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Which stages of cell division do the following figures A and B represent respectively?

response.explanation: The figure A represents late anaphase while figure B represents prophase stage of mitosis.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Synapsis occurs between:

options.d: a male and a female gamete

response.explanation: Synapsis is the pairing of two homologous chromosomes that occurs during prophase I (zygotene stage) of meiosis. The resulting structure is called a bivalent.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: If you are provided with root-tips of onion in your class and are asked to count the chromosomes, which of the following stages can you most conveniently look into?

response.explanation: Chromosomes are most distinct in the metaphase stage. In the telophase stage they regain their coiled composition. In anaphase the chromatids separate and move towards opposite poles.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Which one of the following precedes re-formation of the nuclear envelope during M phase of the cell cycle

options.a: Decondensation from chromosomes, and reassembly of the nuclear lamina
options.b: Transcription from chromosomes, and reassembly of the nuclear lamina
options.c: Formation of the contractile ring, and formation of the phragmoplast
options.d: Formation of the contractile ring, and transcription from chromosomes

response.explanation: At the telophase of M phase or mitotic phase, the nuclear membrane and nucleolus appear. The decondensation of chromosomes occur.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Best material for the study of mitosis in laboratory is

response.explanation: Root tip is the best material for studying mitosis as it has actively dividing cells. Anther cells are used to study meiosis.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: If a diploid cell is treated with colchicine then it becomes

response.explanation: Colchicine inhibits spindle formation, due to which chromatids are unable to separate during anaphase which results in doubling of chromosomes. So, if a diploid cell is treated with colchicine, it becomes tetraploid.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: During cell division, the spindle fibres attach to the chromosome at a region called

response.explanation: Kinetochore is the proteinaceous covering of centriole, to which spindle fibers attach. Kinetochores form in the central region, or centromere, of a duplicated chromosome.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Microtubule is involved in the

response.explanation: The spindle fibres involved in cell division is made of microtubules.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: How many mitotic divisions are needed for a single cell to make 128 cells?

response.explanation: In mitosis a single cell divides to form two daughter cells. Number of divisions = log₂(128) = 7 divisions (2⁷ = 128).

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: During cell division in apical meristem the nuclear membrane appears in

response.explanation: Nuclear membrane reforms during telophase. Metaphase is characterized by spindle fibres. Anaphase involves movement of chromatids. Cytokinesis marks cytoplasmic division.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Colchicine is employed to diploidize a haploid cell as it

options.c: allows replication of DNA twice in one cell cycle

response.explanation: Colchicine is a mitotic poison which inhibits the formation of spindle fibres, preventing chromosome separation and resulting in polyploidy.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Best stage to observe shape, size and number of chromosomes is

response.explanation: During metaphase, the centromeres of the chromosome lie on the equatorial plate according to their size and spatial arrangement. So it is the best time to count the number and study the morphology of chromosomes.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Number of chromatids at metaphase is

options.a: two each in mitosis and meiosis
options.b: two in mitosis and one in meiosis
options.c: two in mitosis and four in meiosis
options.d: one in mitosis and two in meiosis

response.explanation: In both mitotic and meiotic metaphase, the number of chromatids per chromosome is two.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - M-phase / cytokinesis

input.question: Mitotic anaphase differs from metaphase in possessing

options.a: same number of chromosomes and same number of chromatids
options.b: half number of chromosomes and half number of chromatids
options.c: half number of chromosomes and same number of chromatids
options.d: same number of chromosomes and half number of chromatids

response.explanation: In mitotic anaphase, the sister chromatids separate from each other and begin to move towards the opposite poles, so chromosome number remains same but chromatid number halves.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Match the following with respect to meiosis: (a) Zygotene, (b) Pachytene, (c) Diplotene, (d) Diakinesis

response.explanation: Zygotene → Synapsis (iv), Pachytene → Crossing over (iii), Diplotene → Chiasmata formation (ii), Diakinesis → Terminalisation (i)

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Meiotic division of the secondary oocyte is completed

options.c: At the time of fusion of a sperm with an ovum

response.explanation: Meiotic division of secondary oocyte is completed after the entry of sperm in secondary oocyte which lead to the formation of a large ovum and a tiny 2nd polar body.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Crossing over takes place between which chromatids and in which stage of the cell cycle?

options.a: Non-sister chromatids of non-homologous chromosomes at Pachytene stage of prophase I.
options.b: Non-sister chromatids of non-homologous chromosomes at Zygotene stage of prophase I.
options.c: Non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes at Pachytene stage of prophase I.
options.d: Non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes at Zygotene stage of prophase I.

response.explanation: Crossing over is the exchange of gene which takes place between non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes at pachytene stage of meiosis I resulting in new allelic combinations in the daughter cells.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: After meiosis I, the resultant daughter cells have

options.a: four times the amount of DNA in comparison to haploid gamete.
options.b: same amount of DNA as in the parent cell in S phase.
options.c: twice the amount of DNA in comparison to haploid gamete.
options.d: same amount of DNA in comparison to haploid gamete.

response.explanation: Meiosis I is reductional division thus the resultant cell just after meiosis I will have half the number of chromosomes as compared to diploid parent cells. Therefore if the parent cell has 4C amount of DNA the daughter cell will have 2C amount of DNA and each gamete will have 1C amount of DNA.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: The stage during which separation of the paired homologous chromosomes begins is

response.explanation: Diplotene is a stage of meiotic prophase which follows the pachytene and during which the paired homologous chromosomes begin to separate and chiasmata become visible.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: In meiosis crossing over is initiated at

response.explanation: Crossing over is the process by which two chromosomes exchange some distal part of their DNA. This process occurs in the Pachytene stage of Prophase I of meiosis.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Select the correct option: A-Synapsis aligns homologous chromosomes, B-Synthesis of RNA and protein, C-Action of enzyme recombinase, D-Centromeres do not separate but chromatids move towards opposite poles

options.a: A-Zygotene, B-G₂ phase, C-Pachytene, D-Anaphase I
options.b: A-Pachytene, B-S phase, C-Zygotene, D-Anaphase II
options.c: A-Leptotene, B-G₁ phase, C-Diplotene, D-Metaphase I
options.d: A-Diakinesis, B-M phase, C-Pachytene, D-Telophase I

response.explanation: Pachytene - Crossing over mediated by recombinase enzyme. Zygotene - Pairing of homologous chromosomes. G₂ phase - Synthesis of RNA and protein. Anaphase I - Centromeres do not separate but chromatids move towards opposite poles.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Choose the correct option for the following events of meiosis in correct sequence: (A) Crossing over (B) Synapsis (C) Terminalisation of chiasmata (D) Disappearance of nucleolus

response.explanation: Correct sequence: Synapsis → Crossing over → Terminalisation of chiasmata → Disappearance of nucleolus.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: The enzyme recombinase is required at which stage of meiosis:

response.explanation: The enzyme recombinase is required at Pachytene stage of meiosis. It catalyzes the exchange of short pieces of DNA between two long DNA strands, particularly the exchange of homologous regions between the paired maternal and paternal chromosomes.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: During meiosis I, the chromosomes start pairing at

response.explanation: During zygotene, a substage of Prophase I of meiosis I, chromosomes start pairing together by a process called synapsis. Such paired chromosomes are called as homologous chromosomes.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: During gamete formation, the enzyme recombinase participates during

response.explanation: Recombinase enzyme catalyzes the exchange of short pieces of DNA between two long DNA strands, particularly the exchange of homologous regions between the paired maternal and paternal chromosome in prophase - I of meiosis I.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Given below is the representation of a certain event at a particular stage of a type of cell division. Which is this stage?

options.d: Both prophase and metaphase of mitosis

response.explanation: The given diagram represents crossing over that takes place in pachytene stage of prophase - I during meiosis.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Identify the meiotic stage in which the homologous chromosomes separate while the sister chromatids remain associated at their centromeres?

response.explanation: Anaphase I begins when the two chromosomes of each bivalent (tetrad) separate and start moving toward opposite poles of the cell. In anaphase I, the sister chromatids remain attached at their centromeres and move together toward the poles.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Genetic map is one that

options.a: shows the distribution of various species in a region
options.b: establishes sites of the genes on a chromosome
options.c: establishes the various stages in gene evolution
options.d: show the stages during the cell division

response.explanation: Genetic mapping help in studying the architecture of the chromosomes and of entire genome. Genetic mapping provides clues about which chromosome contains the gene and precisely where the gene lies on that chromosome.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: The exchange of genetic material between chromatids of paired homologous chromosomes during first meiotic division is called

response.explanation: The exchange of genetic material between chromatids of paired homologous chromosomes is called crossing over. The points of attachment after separation are called chiasmata. The process of pairing is called synapsis.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Lamphrush chromosomes occur during

response.explanation: Lamphrush chromosomes are highly elongated bivalent chromosomes of diplotene stage, which are held together by chiasmata and have a large number of lateral loops for rapid transcription.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Meiosis is evolutionary significant because it result in

response.explanation: Meiosis provides a chance for new combinations of chromosomes mainly by the phenomenon of crossing over and random distribution of homologous chromosomes between daughter cells.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Meiosis II performs

response.explanation: Meiosis II is homotypic division specially for maintenance of the haploid number, separating the chromatids from each other in a chromosome.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: In meiosis, the daughter cells differ from parent cell as well as amongst themselves due to

options.a: segregation, independent assortment and crossing over

response.explanation: Due to segregation, independent assortment and crossing over at the time of meiosis, daughter cells exhibit variation.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Segregation of mendelian factor (Aa) occurs during

response.explanation: The paired homologous chromosomes separate in Anaphase I of meiosis I so that each gamete receives one chromosome of each homologous pair.

topic: Cell Cycle and Cell Division - Meiosis I/II

input.question: Meiosis I is reductional division. Meiosis II is equational division due to

response.explanation: Meiosis II is an equational division which is meant for maintaining the haploid number produced by meiosis I and separating the two chromatids of a chromosome.

input.question: The process responsible for facilitating loss of water in liquid form from the tip of grass blades at night and in early morning is

response.explanation: Root pressure is positive hydrostatic pressure. It develops in tracheary element at night and in early morning. Root pressure is caused by active distribution of mineral nutrient ions into the root xylem.

input.question: Which of the following is not a feature of active transport of solutes in plants?

response.explanation: Active transport is uphill transport against the electrochemical potential gradient and requires ATP. It is highly selective, not non-selective.

input.question: What will be the direction of flow of water when a plant cell is placed in a hypotonic solution?

options.a: No flow of water in any direction.
options.b: Water will flow in both directions.
options.c: Water will flow out of the cell.
options.d: Water will flow into the cell.

response.explanation: When a plant cell is placed in hypotonic solution water will flow into the cell as water moves from high water potential to low water potential.

input.question: The main difference between active and passive transport across cell membrane is :

options.a: active transport occurs more rapidly than passive transport.
options.b: passive transport is non-selective whereas active transport is selective.
options.c: passive transport requires a concentration gradient across a biological membrane whereas active transport requires energy to move solutes.
options.d: passive transport is confined to anionic carrier proteins whereas active transport is confined to cationic channel proteins.

response.explanation: In active transport, materials are transported across a membrane with the help of mobile carrier protein and ATP. In passive transport, substances move along the concentration gradient without energy expenditure.

input.question: Water vapour comes out from the plant leaf through the stomatal opening. Through the same stomatal opening carbon dioxide diffuses into the plant during photosynthesis. Reason out the above statements using one of following options

options.b: Both processes can happen together because the diffusion coefficient of water and CO₂ is different.
