The rate of growth of a plant or plant part is not always the same during its life span. If we plot the increase in cell number (growth rate) against time, a typical S-shaped curve is obtained. This is called growth curve or sigmoid growth curve.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: Coiling of garden pea tendrils around any support is an example of:

response.explanation: The coiling of garden pea tendrils around any support is an example of thigmotropism. Thigmotropism is the growth movement in response to touch. The stems and tendrils of the climbers are positively thigmotrophic in their response.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: Senescence as an active developmental cellular process in the growth and functioning of a flowering plant, is indicated in

response.explanation: Senescence is an active developmental cellular process in the growth and functioning of a flowering plant, indicated in lead abscission. Senescence is the changes that occur in an organism between maturity and death, i.e., ageing. Characteristically there is a deterioration in functioning as the cells become less efficient in maintaining and replacing vital cells components.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: Opening of floral buds into flowers, is a type of

response.explanation: Opening of floral buds into flowers, is a type of autonomic movement of growth which is due to epinasty. Epinasty is caused by ethylene that is released by the leaves when the roots are flooded.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: Anthesis is a phenomenon which refers to

response.explanation: Anthesis is the period during which a flower is fully open and functional. It may also refer to the onset of that period.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: Movement of leaves of Sensitive Plant, Mimosa pudica are due to

response.explanation: Mimosa pudica (touch me not) leaves show seismonastic movement in response to physical contact. The movement is because of turgor changes due to ejection of water by cells of pulvinus (swollen leaf base) on touching it. It causes folding and drooping of leaves.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: If a tree, flowers thrice in a year (Oct., Jan. and July) in Northern India, it is said to be

response.explanation: In northern India, during these months maximum variation in light intensity, duration and temperature is observed. Hence, only plants that are photo-and thermoinsensitive can flower during these months.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: Thigmotropic movement is best shown by

response.explanation: The phenomenon of thigmotropism is a response to contact with a solid object. It is exhibited by tendrils of climbing plants that grow around a pole or the stem of another plant.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: Klinostat is employed in the study of

response.explanation: Klinostat = Clinostat is an apparatus used to nullify the effect of geotropism. It has a clock on the main axis which is attached to a rod. The Top of the rod is attached to a flower pot. The klinostat is kept in horizontal position and allowed to rotate (to nullify the geotropism) and plant growth is observed.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: Phytohormones are:

options.c: hormones regulating growth from seed to adulthood
options.d: regulators synthesised by plants and influencing physiological processes

response.explanation: Phytohormones are plant hormones which are synthesized by the plants and act as regulators and influence physiological process like growth, movements etc. auxins, gibberellins etc. are the phytohormones.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Growth/Differentiation, Dedifferentiation & Redifferentiation/ Development

input.question: Leaves of many grasses are capable of folding and unfolding because they

response.explanation: Monocot leaves have some specialized cells in the epidermal cells of their leaves called bulliform cells (motor cells) which lose or gain turgidity due to which their leaves show coiling and uncoiling.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Which of the following is not an inhibitory substance governing seed dormancy?

response.explanation: Gibberellic acid breaks seed dormancy. It activate synthesis of alpha-amylase which breakdown starch into simple sugar. The Phytohormones gibberellic acid (GA) has essential signaling functions in multiple processes during plant development.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Name the plant growth regulator which upon spraying on sugarcane crop, increases the length of stem, thus increasing the yield of sugarcane crop.

response.explanation: Spraying sugarcane crop with gibberellins increases the length of the stem, thus increasing the yield by as much as 20 tonnes per acre.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Removal of shoot tips is a very useful technique to boost the production of tealeaves. This is because:

options.b: Gibberellins prevent bolting and are inactivated.
options.c: Auxins prevent leaf drop at early stages.
options.d: Effect of auxins is removed and growth of lateral buds is enhanced.

response.explanation: Auxin shows apical dominance. Removal of auxin by removal of shoot tips prevents the apical dominance and promotes the growth of lateral buds which is a very useful in tea leaves production.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: In order to increase the yield of sugarcane crop, which of the following plant growth regulators should be sprayed?

response.explanation: Gibberellins (GAs) regulate various developmental processes, including stem elongation, germination, dormancy, flowering, flower development and leaf and fruit senescence. When gibberellin is sprayed on sugarcane crop, the length of the stem increases.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: It takes very long time for pineapple plants to produce flowers. Which combination of hormones can be applied to artificially induce flowering in pineapple plants throughout the year to increase yield?

response.explanation: A pineapple plant flowers only once, and produces one pineapple. Then it dies. But before it dies it also produces offspring. Auxin and ethylene can be applied to artificially induce flowering in pineapple to increase yield throughout the year.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Fruit and leaf drop at early stages can be prevented by the application of:

response.explanation: Auxins helps to prevent premature leaf and fruit fall.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: The Avena curvature is used for bioassay of

response.explanation: Auxin has been clearly demonstrated in the leaf sheath or coleoptile of oat plant (Avena sativa). This plant coleoptile has been used for the test of hormone Auxin (IAA) participating in the growth of the plant.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: What causes a green plant exposed to the light on only one side, to bend toward the source of light as it grows?

options.a: Green plants seek light because they are phototropic
options.b: Light stimulates plant cells on the lighted side to grow faster
options.c: Auxin accumulates on the shaded side, stimulating greater cell elongation there.
options.d: Green plants need light to perform photosynthesis

response.explanation: Auxin stimulates cell elongation. It accumulates on shaded side which results in more elongation of cells towards shaded side of the plant. This causes bending of the plant towards source of light.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Auxin can be bioassayed by:

response.explanation: Avena coleoptile curvature is used for the bioassay of auxin.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Dr. F. Went noted that if coleoptile tips were removed and placed on agar for one hour, the agar would produce a bending when placed on one side of freshly-cut coleoptile stumps. Of what significance is this experiment?

options.a: It made possible the isolation and exact identification of auxin.
options.b: It is the basis for quantitative determination of small amounts of growth-promoting substances.
options.c: It supports the hypothesis that IAA is auxin.
options.d: It demonstrated polar movement of auxins.

response.explanation: Charles Darwin and his son Francis Darwin observed that the coleoptiles of Oat (Avena sativa) and canary grass (Phalaris canariensis) responded to unilateral illumination by growing towards the light source (phototropic curvature or phototropism). After a series of experiments, it was concluded that the tip of the coleoptile was the site of production of a substance, that caused the bending of coleoptile.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: A few normal seedlings of tomato were kept in a dark room. After a few days they were found to have become white-coloured like albinos. Which of the following terms will you use to describe them?

response.explanation: Etiolation is depigmentation of leaf when plant is placed in dark for more than 36 hrs.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Which one of the following growth regulators is known as 'stress hormone'?

response.explanation: Abscisic Acid (ABA) is called stress hormone which works in adverse environmental condition when there is low water content in atmosphere or in drought conditions. ABA causes the stomatal closure of leaves due to which the water loss by the plant is minimized.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: During seed germination its stored food is mobilized

response.explanation: Gibberellins stimulate the synthesis of α-amylase and protease enzyme in germinating grains of cereals. They are involved in the conversion of starch into sugar. The proteases convert an inactive β-amylase to the active form. The active β-amylase and α-amylase together digest starch to glucose which is mobilized to meet the metabolic demands of embryo.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: The pineapple which under natural conditions is difficult to blossom has been made to produce fruits throughout the year by application of

response.explanation: Plants which are difficult to flower can be made to do so by spraying them with 2, 4, -D (2, 4 – dichlorophenoxy acetic acid) and NAA (napthalene acetic acid) which are synthetic auxins, e.g., litchi, pineapple.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Which one of the following generally acts as an antagonist to gibberellins?

response.explanation: Gibberellins & ABA are antagonistic to each other. ABA counteracts many effects of gibberellins like induction of hydrolases and alpha- amylases in barley seedlings.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Phototropic curvature is the result of uneven distribution of:

response.explanation: Phototrophic curvature is the result of uneven distribution of auxin. The experiments conducted by Charles Darwin concluded that the tip of colcoptile of canary grass contain auxin that causes the bending of the entire colcoptile towards the light source.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: One of the synthetic auxin is:

response.explanation: NAA is a synthetic auxin. Some of the most widely used weed killers are synthetic auxins. Synthetic auxin analogs include 1-naphthalenecacetic acid (NAA), 2, 4-dichlorophenoxy acetic acid (2, 4-D) and 2,4,5-trichlorophenoxy acetic acid (2,4,5- T).

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Which one of the following acids is a derivative of carotenoids?

response.explanation: Abscisic acid (ABA), also known as abscisin II and dormin, is a plant hormone. It functions in many plant developmental processes, including bud dormancy. Abscisic acid is a derivative of carotenoids.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Which one of the following pairs, is not correctly matched?

response.explanation: Gibberllic acid stimulates cell growth of leaves and stem causing their expansion, elongation respectively and leaf fall is controlled by ABA.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: "Foolish seedling" disease of rice led to the discovery of

response.explanation: The effect of gibberellins had been known in Japan since early 1800 where certain rice plants were found to suffer from bakane or bakanae (foolish seedling) disease. Such rice plants were thin, pale green, spindle-shaped, longer by 50% than the healthy plants, and were sterile.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: An enzyme that can stimulate germination of barley seeds is

response.explanation: α-amylase enzyme stimulates the germination of barley seed.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: How does pruning help in making the hedge dense?

options.a: It frees axillary buds from apical dominance
options.b: The apical shoot grows faster after pruning
options.d: It induces the differentiation of new shoots from the rootstock

response.explanation: When an apical bud is present on a plant, it suppresses the growth of axillary buds, this is called apical dominance. When in pruning apical bud is cut off the axillary buds start growing & hedge become dense.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Cell elongation in internodal regions of the green plants takes place due to

response.explanation: Gibberellins induces elongation of internodes. Some of the major physiological effects of gibberellins are as follows: Gibberellins are weakly acidic growth hormones having gibbane ring structure which cause cell elongation of intact plants in general and increased internodal length of genetically dwarfed plants (e.g., Pea, Corn), in particular.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Differentiation of shoot is controlled by

response.explanation: Differentiation of root is controlled by high auxin concentration. While in tissue culture, auxin concentration is made high to promote rooting.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Plants deficient of element zinc, show its effect on the biosynthesis of plant growth hormone

response.explanation: Zinc is one of the components of auxin. Zinc deficiency occurs when plant growth is limited because the plant cannot take up sufficient quantities of this essential micronutrient from its growing medium.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: What reason will you assign for coconut milk used in tissue culture?

response.explanation: The medium in tissue culture provides all the essential nutrients required for growth and division of callus. Coconut milk contains cytokinins which is useful in tissue culture.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Seed dormancy is due to the

response.explanation: Ethylene breaks dormancy of different plants. Abscisic acid induces dormancy in seeds, buds and underground storage organs.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Dwarfness can be controlled by treating the plant with

response.explanation: One of the most important effects of gibberellins is the reversal of dwarfism (even in genetically dwarf plants). Dwarf pea & dwarf corn attain almost normal size when treated with gibberellins. It has been proven that dwarf plants have lower level of GA which causes the dwarfism. Thus the external supply causes rapid elongation of internodes. GA does not have any effect on elongation of normal (non dwarf or tall) plant.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: What breaks bud dormancy of potato tuber?

response.explanation: IAA promotes apical dominance. ABA induces dormancy in buds. Presence of cytokinin in an area causes preferential movement of nutrients towards it. When applied to lateral buds, they help in their growth despite the presence of apical bud. They thus act antagonistically to auxin which promotes apical dominance. Therefore cytokinin can overcome apical dominance, caused by auxins.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Hormone responsible for senescence

response.explanation: ABA or Abscisic acid is responsible for leaf fall or senescence.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Which of the following prevents fall of fruits?

response.explanation: NAA or Naphthalene Acetic Acid is synthetic auxin. It is used to check fruit fall specially in tomato.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Removal of apical bud results in

response.explanation: Apical buds inhibit lateral branching due to apical dominance. Removal of apical bud promotes lateral branching.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Which is employed for artificial ripening of banana fruits?

response.explanation: Ethylene is a plant hormone which has the most remarkable effect of stimulation of fruit ripening.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: ABA is involved in

response.explanation: Gibberellins are involved in shoot elongation. Auxins are important in root elongation and cell division.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Which combination of gases is suitable for fruit ripening?

response.explanation: Ethylene acts physiologically as a hormone in plants. It stimulates the ripening of fruit, the opening of flowers, and the abscission (or shedding) of leaves. Its biosynthesis starts from methionine with 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid (ACC) as a key intermediate.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: A plant hormone used for inducing morphogenesis in plant tissue culture is

response.explanation: Cytokinins are used in tissue culture to induce shooting of the cultural callus.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Gibberellins promote

response.explanation: Some light sensitive seeds like Lectuca sativa (Lettuce) germinate in complete darkness with the help of Gibberellins which otherwise require specific light conditions.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: A chemical believed to be involved in flowering is

response.explanation: Chailakhyan (1936) a Russian investigator who researched on photoperiodism proposed the term 'florigen'. According to him 'Florigen Complex', the true flowering hormone includes two group of substances formed in leaves (i) gibberellins which are necessary for the formation and growth of stem and (ii) anthesins which are necessary for flower formation. Acting together they form the substance named 'florigen'.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Ethylene gas is used for

response.explanation: Ethylene is a gaseous plant hormone which plays an important role in fruit ripening. In the presence of ethylene there is an increase in the rate of respiration.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Movement of auxin is

response.explanation: Auxins are synthesized at the tip of shoot & then transported towards the base i.e. basipetal. In all segments of root at all temperatures, the movement of auxin is polarised acropetally.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Auxetic growth is

response.explanation: Three types of growth are present in multicellular animals : (i) Auxetic growth : Increase in cell volume only, not in number. (ii) Multiplication growth : Increase in number, not in volume. (iii) Accretionary growth : Growth is due to mitotic division of some special type of cells occurring in specific locations of body.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: What is a stress hormone? or The hormone produced during adverse environmental conditions is

response.explanation: Abscisic Acid (ABA) is called stress hormone which works in adverse environmental condition when there is low water content in the atmosphere or in drought conditions. ABA causes the stomatal closure of leaves due to which the water loss by the plant is minimized.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: The regulator which retards ageing/senescence of plant parts is:

response.explanation: Cytokinins help in retaining chlorophyll, hence delay senescence. Cytokinin deficiency causes slow growth of the shoot and morphological changes such as dwarfism and smaller leaves.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Cytokinins

response.explanation: Cytokinins cause delay in senescence (Richmond-Lang effect). Senescence is the phenomenon in which the mature leaves lose chlorophyll, turn yellow and fall off. The Richmond-Lang effect was discovered in 1967 by Richmond & Lang. As per this effect, the lag of senescence of leaves and other parts occurs with the aid of plant growth regulator cytokinin.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Apical dominance is caused by

response.explanation: Apical dominance is the phenomenon by which presence of apical bud does not allow lateral buds to grow. Apical dominance is due to auxin. When shoot tip is cut; then lateral buds start growing.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Bananas can be prevented from over-ripening by

response.explanation: Ascorbic acid is an organic acid with antioxidant properties. Its appearance is white to light yellow crystals or powder. It is water soluble. The L-enantiomer of ascorbic acid is commonly known as Vitamin C. Ascorbic acid is easily oxidized and so is used as a reductant in photographic developer solutions and as a preservative.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: The hormone responsible for apical dominance is

response.explanation: Apical dominance is caused by the action of auxins. IAA (Indole-3-acetic acid) is a naturally occurring auxin.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Abscisic acid causes

response.explanation: Abscisic acid is a stress hormone. During desication abscisic acid is synthesized which reduces transpiration by closure of stomata. It conserves water.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Hormone primarily connected with cell division is

response.explanation: The most important function of cytokinins (zeatin is a cytokinin present in Zea mays - the corn) is the promotion of cell division. These are now established as true cell division factors.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Which of the following movement is not related to auxin level?

options.d: Movement of sunflower head tracking the sun

response.explanation: All movements except nyctinastic movement are related to auxin. Nyctinastic (sleeping) movement of leaves is due to diurnal changes. (changes in day and night).

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Phototropic and geotropic movements are linked to:

response.explanation: Phototropic movements are the plant responses towards light. Generally plant shoot and flower show positive phototropism while geotropism is the plant response to the gravity of earth. Generally roots are positively geotropic. All these movements are linked to Auxin.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Abscisic acid controls

response.explanation: Abscisic acid as the name suggests cause abscission due to which leaves fall. It also acts as a growth inhibitor & induces bud dormancy in various plants.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Highest auxin concentration occurs

response.explanation: Highest concentration of auxins occurs at the growing tips. This was proved by Went in 1928 by his experiment on Avena coleoptile. It was demonstrated that auxins are synthesized at the tips and then translocated downwards where they cause growth.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Moving grass lawn facilitates better maintenance because

options.b: removal of apical dominance and stimulation of intercalary meristem
options.d: removal of apical dominance and promotion of lateral meristem

response.explanation: Apical dominance is a common observation in vascular plants. If apical meristem is intact & growing, the growth of lateral tips is suppressed. According to Thimann & Skoog the auxin, synthesized in apical meristem, is translocated downwards & inhibits the growth of lateral tips. That is why moving grass lawns facilitate better maintenance.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Leaf fall can be prevented with the help of

response.explanation: It is due to Richmond-Lang effect. Cytokinins prevent degeneration of chlorophyll, proteins and nucleic acids. They increase of inflow of auxin and amino acids. It reactivates leaf metabolism.

topic: Plant Growth and Development: Plant Growth Regulators

input.question: Cut or excised leaves remain green for long if induced to root or dipped in

response.explanation: Cytokinins help cells in retaining chlorophyll for longer time. Cytokinins delay the senescence (ageing) of leaves and other organs.

input.question: What is the site of perception of photoperiod necessary for induction of flowering in plants?

response.explanation: During flowering, photoperiodic stimulus is perceived by leaves of plants. In 1920, W. W. Garner and H. A. Allard published their discoveries on photoperiodism and felt it was the length of daylight that was critical, but it was later discovered that the length of the night was the controlling factor.

input.question: Through their effect on plant growth regulators, what do the temperature and light control in the plants?

response.explanation: Flowering is induced by light and temperature. Red light promotes flowering. However, it also encourages vertical plant growth. Too much red at the wrong time will cause your plants to stretch, which results in lower yields and lanky, unstable plants. Blue light is your secret weapon for amping up the concentration of oils and resin.

input.question: Vernalization stimulates flowering in

response.explanation: Carrot is a biennial plant which flowers in the second season. Vernalization is the subjection of seeds or seedlings to low temperature in order to hasten plant development and flowering. Vernalization is commonly used for crop plants such as winter rye and is possible because the seeds and buds of many plants require cold in order to break dormancy.

input.question: Photoperiodism was first characterised in:

response.explanation: Photoperiodism is the response to duration and timings of light and dark period. It was first characterised in tobacco plant.

input.question: Importance of day length in flowering of plants was first shown in

response.explanation: Photoperiodism was first studied by Garner and Allard (1920). They observed that "Maryland Mammoth" variety of tobacco could be made to flower in summer by reducing the light hours with artificial darkening. It could be made to remain vegetative in winter by providing extra light.

input.question: Treatment of seed at low temperature under moist conditions to break its dormancy is called

response.explanation: Treatment of seed at a low temperature under moist conditions to break dormancy is called stratification.

input.question: One set of a plant was grown at 12 hours day and 12 hours night period cycles and it flowered while in the other set night phase was interrupted by flash of light and it did not produce flower. Under which one of the following categories will you place this plant?

response.explanation: Short day plants require long uninterrupted dark period for flowering. They will not produce flower if night was interrupted by flash of light.

input.question: The pigment, that absorbs red and far red light in plants, is

response.explanation: The pigment phytochrome is involved in flowering and many other light-mediated processes. It absorbs red and far red light in plants for photosynthesis.

input.question: Which one is a long-day plant?

response.explanation: Long day plants undergo flowering after receiving light above a critical day length. e.g. Spinach, sugarbeet. Short day plants flower only when they receive light below a critical day length. e.g. Glycine max, Tobacco.

input.question: Proteinaceous pigment which control activities concerned with light

response.explanation: Borthwick & Hendricks (1952) gave the concept of phytochrome. Phytochrome is a coloured protein pigment located in plasma membrane to perceive the photoperiodic stimulus in leaves. It may exist in two interconvertable forms Pr and Pfr (red and far red light absorbing forms).

input.question: The method that renders the seed coat permeable to water so that embryo expansion is not physically retarded is

response.explanation: Scarification is the breaking of the seed coat barriers which can be done by mechanical or chemical methods.

input.question: The response of different organisms to environmental rhythms of light and darkness is called

response.explanation: Photoperiodism is the effect of duration of light and darkness on the growth, development and behaviour of an organism.

input.question: What will be the effect on phytochrome in a plant subjected to continuous red light?

options.d: Destruction and synthesis of phytochrome remain in equilibrium.

response.explanation: Continuous exposure to red light causes • Conversion of Pr to Pfr which is rapidly destroyed. • Inhibition of synthesis of Pr. • Total amount of phytochrome decreases.

input.question: In short day plants, flowering is induced by

options.b: photoperiod below a critical length and uninterrupted long night
options.d: short photoperiod and interrupted long night

response.explanation: A short day plant is one that flowers on photoperiods shorter than the critical day length. It generally flowers when treated by a short day and uninterrupted long night (more than 12 hrs.)

input.question: Flowering dependent on cold treatment is

response.explanation: Vernalization is the method of inducing early flowering in plants by pretreatment of their seeds at low temperature.

input.question: Tendrils exhibit/twinning of tendrils is due to

response.explanation: Twining of tendrils is due to thigmotropism i.e. movement due to the contact with a foreign body (touch). Thigmotropism occurs due to actions of the plant hormone auxin. Touched cells produce auxin which then transfers auxin to non-touched cells. These untouched cells then grow faster causing them to bend around the stimulus. The hormone ethylene helps in changing the shape or turgidity of the cell.

input.question: Which one increases in the absence of light?

response.explanation: In the absence of light stem becomes excessive long due to 'etiolation'. This causes cells of internodes to get enlarged.

input.question: Which of the following hormones can replace vernalisation?

response.explanation: Vernalization is the low temperature treatment for flowering in plants. Plants are treated (seeds and seedlings) with very low temperature to promote germination. A Lang & co-workers demonstrated that the application of gibberellins can replace the cold treatment or vernalization in many plants.

input.question: Phytochrome is involved in

response.explanation: Phytochrome is involved in photoperiodism, which is the response to duration and timings of light and dark period.
